questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall on their outstretched hand. The X-ray image is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Scaphoid Fracture:

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the radial side of the wrist, and the scaphoid bone is one of the bones that forms its floor.
  • A fall on an outstretched hand can cause a scaphoid bone fracture, most common in young adults, particularly males, and is often the result of FOOSH injury with the wrist in extension.
  • Symptoms include tenderness and swelling in the anatomical snuffbox, pain with gripping or squeezing, and limited range of motion in the wrist.
  • It has a high risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.
  • X-ray findings:
    • visualization of the fracture +/- displacement
    • soft tissue swelling and lateral displacement of the adjacent fat pads

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Colles Fracture: Colles fracture is a type of distal radius fracture where the distal fragment is displaced dorsally (backward). It occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hand with the wrist extended. The symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity in the wrist.

Option C - Smith Fracture: It is a type of distal radius fracture where the distal fragment is displaced volarly (forwards). It occurs due to a fall on the back of the hand with the wrist flexed. 

Option D - Galeazzi Fracture: It is a fracture of the distal third of the radius associated with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. It occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hand with the forearm pronated (palm facing downwards). The symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity in the wrist and forearm.

questions.text: A patient has presented with fever and blister on the hand, followed by the development of axillary lymphadenopathy. What will you ask the patient with regard to history?

choices.text: History of similar complaints among family members

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - History of exposure to cat:

  • The presentation of a blister on the hand, followed by axillary lymphadenopathy, is highly suggestive of cat scratch disease among the given options
  • It occurs when an infected cat licks a person’s open wound or bites or scratches a person hard enough to break the surface of the skin.  It is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae, characterized by a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy. 
  • In immunocompromised patients, it causes bacillary angiomatosis, in which vascular nodules appear on skin and mucosa.
  • B. henselae can be demonstrated in lymph node biopsy with Warthin-Starry staining.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - History of rat bite: Rat bite can cause rabies, but it does not present with regional lymphadenopathy.

Option C - History of similar complaints among family members: A history of similar illness among family members is not relevant in the case of blister with regional lymphadenopathy.
Option D - History of louse bite: A louse bite can cause epidemic typhus characterized by fever and a rash starting from the trunk and spreading to the limbs sparing palms and sole without regional lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and intense itching. On examination, the cervix appears strawberry-like. Which of the following statements is false regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It exists in cyst and trophozoite forms
The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM
The treatment of choice is metronidazole

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It exists in cyst and trophozoite forms:

  • The clinical presentation of foul-smelling frothy-vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix is suggestive of trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. 
  • Trichomonas vaginalis is an obligate parasite that exists only in trophozoite form, which is both diagnostic and infective stage.
    Diagnosis by culture is the gold standard test. It is cultured in Cysteine peptone liver maltose media (CPLM).
  • The drug of choice for trichomoniasis is a single dose of 2-gram metronidazole for both partners..

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: These statements are accurate about Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to sterilize a glass petri dish?

choices.text: Autoclaving at 121 degrees Celsius for 30-60 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes
Autoclaving at 134 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30-60 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes:

  • The method used to sterilize a glass petri dish is a hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes.
  • Hot air oven uses dry heat for the sterilization of materials that may be damaged by moist heat or that are impenetrable to moist heat. 
  • This method involves heating the petri dish at a high temperature in a dry oven, which leads to the oxidation of the cell constituents.
  • The most common cycles used are:
    • 170°C for 60 minutes,
    • 160°C for 120 minutes,
    • 180°C for 30 minutes.
  • Materials sterilized are:
    • Glassware
    • Cotton swabs
    • Gel, oil, wax, Dusting powder.
    • Greasy paraffin wax
    • Metallic instruments.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee. A plain radiograph is shown below. What is the best treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tension band wiring with K-wires:

  • The X-ray reveals a two-part fracture of the patella, typically caused by direct impact, falling on a bent knee, or sudden twisting.
  • Such fractures are common among active individuals, especially in sports-related incidents.
  • Tension band wiring with K-wires, utilizing two K-wires and a tension band wire, stabilizes the fracture and promotes healing.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option B - Tension band wiring with cancellous screws treats displaced patellar fractures but poses risks like infection, hardware failure, and knee stiffness.

Option C - Cylinder cast immobilization, used for non-displaced patellar fractures or postoperative care, involves a long-leg cast or brace from hip to ankle, promoting knee joint immobilization for healing.

Option D - Patellectomy, the last resort for severe patellar fractures, involves surgical patella removal, with potential functional limitations, making it unsuitable for all cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases
The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure:

  • Antigenic drift is a phenomenon that occurs in influenza viruses. It involves a gradual sequential change in the antigenic structure of the virus due to mutations in the genes that code for its surface proteins. 
  • These surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are responsible for the recognition and binding of the virus to host cells and the release of newly formed virus particles from infected cells, respectively.
  • The accumulation of these mutations in the HA and NA genes over time can lead to the emergence of new strains. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Causes a sudden increase in the number of cases: This is inaccurate because antigenic drift is less likely to cause major epidemics and pandemics.

Option C - The new antigens formed are unrelated to the previous antigens: The new antigens formed due to antigenic drift are related to the previous antigens, so they react with antisera to the predecessor virus strains to varying degrees.

Option D - Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralize the new variants: Antibodies to the predecessor viruses still provide some degree of cross-protection against the new variants, but the degree of protection may vary depending on the degree of antigenic similarity between the old and new strains.

questions.text: A 38-year-old IV drug abuser presents with a 1-week history of malaise, fatigue, and rigors. His temperature on admission was 38.5° C. Examination revealed a pansystolic murmur, loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Which organism is most likely to be found in his blood culture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • The clinical presentation and history of intravenous drug abuser is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE) with valvular involvement. 
  • In IV drug abusers, the most common organism causing infective endocarditis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Condition

Most common organism

Most common organism (overall)

Staphylococcus aureus

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side)

Staphylococcus aureus

Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side)

Enterococci and Staphylococcus

Single most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organisms causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect: These pathogens do not cause infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers.

questions.text: If a sample is cultured in LJ media, what is the likely staining characteristic of the cultured organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acid Fast:

  • LJ (Lowenstein-Jensen) media is used for the cultivation of Mycobacterium species, which are acid-fast bacteria.  
  • In acid-fast staining, the bacteria are stained with a carbol fuchsin dye and then treated with acid and alcohol. 
  • Acid-fast bacteria retain the red color of the dye even after acid and alcohol treatment, while non-acid-fast bacteria are decolorized and appear blue when counterstained with methylene blue.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the X-ray image of the affected wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteoclastoma:

  • Based on clinical presentation and the X-ray film provided, the most likely diagnosis is osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor. 
  • Osteoclastoma is a benign bone tumor that typically presents as a painful, gradually enlarging mass, most commonly located in the epiphyseal region of long bones. 
  • On imaging, osteoclastoma appears as a well-defined osteolytic lesion with areas of cortical thinning and expansion (soap bubble appearance). 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and young adults. It appears as a destructive bone lesion with an "onion skin" appearance. 

Option B - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor commonly affecting adolescents and young adults. It appears as a destructive bone lesion with areas of new bone formation. 

Option D - Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is characterized by a bony outgrowth that arises from the surface of the affected bone. X-ray imaging shows a bony projection with a cartilage cap.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby is brought to the OPD with a deformity, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the management recommendation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Manipulation and Cast:

  • Clubfoot, also known as congenital talipes equinovarus, is a common congenital deformity characterized by an abnormal inward and downward positioning of the foot.
  • In the initial management of clubfoot, the goal is to gradually correct the deformity while the foot is still malleable such as in this 6-month-old infant. 
  • Manipulation and casting involve gently manipulating the foot and ankle into the correct position, followed by applying a cast that maintains the correction. 
  • This process is repeated every 1-2 weeks until the foot is fully corrected, taking several months.
  • Ponseti method of serial manipulation and casting is the gold standard. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Posteromedial Soft Tissue Release: Postero-medial soft tissue release (PMSTR) is a surgical procedure used to correct clubfoot deformity in older children or adults. It involves releasing the tight tendons and ligaments on the inside of the foot and ankle, which allows the foot to be placed in a more normal position. PMSTR is reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative treatment methods such as casting, bracing, or physical therapy.

Option C - Triple Arthrodesis: Triple arthrodesis is a surgical procedure used to correct severe and rigid clubfoot deformities in older children or adults. It involves fusing three joints in the foot - the subtalar joint, the talonavicular joint, and the calcaneocuboid joint. The goal of the procedure is to create a stable, pain-free foot with improved function.

Option D - Evan’s Procedure:  Evan's procedure is a surgical procedure used to correct clubfoot deformity in older children or adults. It involves removing a wedge-shaped piece of bone from the foot to reposition the foot into a more normal position. The procedure is typically used for patients with severe and rigid clubfoot deformities who have not responded to non-surgical treatments

questions.text: A 34-year-old male has been suffering from a progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past six months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve with exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of arthritis primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints, more common in males and starting in late teens to early adulthood.
  • Key symptoms include morning stiffness and back pain, alleviated by exercise. Other signs may include fatigue, fever, and weight loss. It's often linked with inflammatory bowel disease, like ulcerative colitis.
  • The characteristic "bamboo spine" appearance results from vertebrae bridging.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pott’s spine: Pott's spine, also known as tuberculosis of the spine, presents with similar symptoms to ankylosing spondylitis, but it typically affects only one or two vertebrae and can lead to vertebral collapse and deformity. 

Option B - Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis can affect any joint in the body, but it often affects the fingers and toes. Patients may also develop nail changes or skin lesions. 

Option D - Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis affects smaller joints, such as the hands and feet, and can cause joint pain, swelling, and stiffness.

questions.text: Anaphylaxis occurred in a boy who was eating peanut butter. This scenario exemplifies:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgE-Mediated Reaction:

  • Anaphylaxis is a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction/IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.
  • In response to the allergic food, the immune system produces large amounts of IgE antibodies that bind to mast cells and basophils. This triggers the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators that cause the symptoms of anaphylaxis.

  • This reaction occurs in 2 phases:
    • Sensitization Phase
    • Effector Phase
  • Sensitization Phase:
    • Allergen is processed by APC & peptides of it are presented to CD4 T-cells → activates TH cells → IL4 is released → activates B cells → IgE production → homocytotropism (movement towards the mast cells) and sensitize the mast cells.
  • Effector Phase:
    • Same allergen presented second time → Mast cell degranulation → Primary and secondary mediators.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T Cell-Mediated Cytotoxicity: It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction, for example, Mantoux test and multiple sclerosis.

Option C - IgG-Mediated Reaction: IgG-mediated reactions are seen in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions, for example, Rh incompatibility and blood transfusion reactions. 

Option D - Antigen-Antibody Complex Mediated: It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction, for example, Systemic lupus erythematosus and Henoch schonlein purpura.

questions.text: Which of the following is specifically found in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lipopolysaccharide:

  • Gram-negative bacteria have a distinctive cell wall structure that includes an outer membrane, a thin peptidoglycan layer, and an inner plasma membrane.
  • Lipopolysaccharides serves as an endotoxin and is responsible for the toxic effects associated with gram-negative bacterial infections.

Difference between gram positive and negative bacteria cell wall are:

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: A patient presented with vomiting to medicine OPD. He mentions eating fried rice recently. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bacillus Cereus:

  • Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria that causes food poisoning.
  • It causes two types of food poisoning emetic type and diarrheal type depending on the toxins formed

Features

Emetic type

Diarrheal type

IP

<6 hours

8-16 hours

Food

Chinese fried rice

Meat and milk

Heat

Heat stable

Heat labile

MOA

Increased cGMP

Increased cAMP

Toxins

Cerulide: vagomimetic action

Nhe toxins: secretory diarrhea

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clostridium Perfringens: Clostridium perfringens is also a gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria that can cause food poisoning. It is associated with cold or warmed up meat dishes. 

Option C - Staphylococcus Aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause food poisoning. It is associated with dairy products, meat, and egg dishes that have been left at room temperature for extended periods. 

Option D - Bacillus Anthracis: Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria that causes anthrax. It is not associated with food poisoning.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a step-ladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms gradually worsened over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Widal Test:

  • The patient presents with symptoms of enteric fever, a systemic illness caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. A step-ladder pattern fever is a characteristic feature.
  • The best diagnostic method for enteric fever in the second week of symptom onset is the Widal test, which detects antibodies against S. typhi and S. paratyphi in the patient's serum. 
  • It is a serological test that detects antibodies against O (surface) and H (flagellar) antigens.
  • An antibody titer of greater than 1:60 for O antigen and greater than 1:180 for H antigen, is considered a cutoff level to predict recent infection of typhoid fever in an endemic area.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Stool Culture: This is helpful in diagnosing enteric fever in the 3rd week of infection.

Option C - Blood Culture: Blood culture remains the primary mechanism of confirmation of typhoid fever in the 1st week of the infection.

Option D - Urine Culture: Urine culture is helpful in diagnosing enteric fever in the 4th week of the infection.

questions.text: Identify the hormone present in the contraceptive shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Nonoxynol 9

  • Today is a spermicidal contraceptive. It contains nonoxynol-9, which breaks the outer covering of sperms and kills them, thereby preventing pregnancy.
  • Nonoxynol-9 is a vaginal spermicide used for non-hormonal contraception in conjunction with other modes of contraception. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These are not present in Today's formulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the IUCD with the longest lifespan?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: CuT 380 A

  • CuT 380 A is a copper-carrying intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).
  • CuT has the highest life span of 10 years.
  •  It does not require replacement for long periods and does not interfere with sexual activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Progestasert is a T-shaped device containing progesterone. The hormone released in the uterus forms a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os, which prevents penetration by the sperm and thus exerts an added contraceptive effect. It is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

Option C: Mirena contains LNG and can be retained for 5 years. It is a type of hormone-containing IUD that combines the best properties of IUD and hormonal contraceptives.

Option D: Nova T is a Cu-containing IUD with silver added to the copper wire, thereby increasing its lifespan to 5 years.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complained of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent episodes of pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Tubal block

  • A blocked fallopian tube, or tubal factor infertility, occurs when an obstruction, such as scarring, an adhesion, or infection, prevents the ovum from traveling down the tube.
  • This patient's history of frequent PID, combined with a lack of peritoneal spill of contrast on HSG, indicates a diagnosis of unilateral tubal blockage.
  • Other tests for tubal patency:
    • Laparoscopic chromotubation
    • Sonosalpingography (SSG)
    • Hysteroscopy and falloscopy.
    • Ampullary and fimbrial salpingoscopy

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Endometriosis is the occurrence of ectopic benign endometrial tissues outside the uterus cavity. Endometriosis is not well visualized on HSG.

Option C: Asherman Syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or intrauterine synechiae) occurs when scar tissue forms inside the uterus and/or the cervix. These adhesions occur after surgery of the uterus or after a dilatation and curettage with tuberculosis. On HSG, there are multiple irregular linear filling defects (may give a lacunar pattern), with the inability to appropriately distend the endometrial cavity.

Option D: Bilateral hydrosalpinx is a condition where fluid accumulates in both fallopian tubes, creating blockages. HSG will classically show dilated fallopian tubes, filling with contrast and with absence of free spillage.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is the complete or partial covering of the internal os of the cervix with the placenta.
  • The risk factors that correlate with placenta previa are advanced maternal age, multiparity, smoking, cocaine use, prior suction and curettage, assisted reproductive technology, history of cesarean section, and prior placenta previa.
  • Painless vaginal bleeding during the second or third trimester of pregnancy is the usual presentation. 
  • Diagnosis:
    • Routine sonography in the first and second trimester of pregnancy provides early identification of placenta previa.
    • A patient presenting with vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester should receive a transabdominal sonogram before a digital examination.
    • If there is a concern for placenta previa, a transvaginal sonogram should be performed to confirm its location.
    • Transvaginal sonogram is superior to a transabdominal sonogram and is safe.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Vasa previa: Vasa previa refers to unprotected fetal vessels running through the membranes over the cervix.

Option C: Placenta accreta: The abnormal invasion of placental trophoblasts into the uterine myometrium is referred to as placenta accreta. Based on the degree of myometrial invasion, it is considered to be a spectrum of disorders encompassing placenta accreta, placenta increta, and placenta percreta.

Option D: Abruptio placenta: Placental abruption is the early separation of the placenta from the lining of the uterus before the completion of the second stage of labor.

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Hysterosalpingography

  • The given instrument is The Leech-Wilkinson Intrauterine Cannula which is used in hysterosalpingography. It is a straight instrument with a conical tip. This cone is screwed into the cervix. Then dye is injected.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Myomectomy, sometimes called fibroidectomy, refers to the surgical removal of uterine leiomyomas, also known as fibroids. The instrument used is the Bonney myomectomy clamp.

Option C: Endometrial biopsy is a procedure in which a tissue sample is obtained from the uterus's endometrium (the inside lining) and then observed under a microscope.

Option D: Conization of the cervix or cold knife cone (CKC) is a surgical procedure used to diagnose and treat cervical dysplasia or early cervical cancer. It involves the excision of a cone-shaped portion of the cervix to remove a cervical lesion and the entire transformation zone.

questions.text: A 23 year old woman presented with 8th weeks of gestation following a positive UPT test. The patient is not willing to continue this pregnancy. What is the appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 800 mcg:

  • For medical abortion up to 9 weeks, Mifepristone and Misoprostol are given. The dose of Misoprostol is - 800 mcg. Misoprostol (PG analog) administered (two tablets of 400 mcg) unless abortion has occurred. It causes the cervix to soften and the uterus to contract to expel the pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • These are ineffective doses increasing the risk of incomplete abortion

questions.text: On ophthalmologic examination, the presence of Koeppe's nodules is observed in a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis. In which area of the eye are these nodules typically observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Iris

  • Koeppe's nodules are small, yellow-white nodules that appear on the surface of the iris observed in granulomatous uveitis like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, Vogt-Kanayagi-Harada’s disease, and sympathetic ophthalmitis . 
  • They are typically located at the pupillary margin, which is the border between the iris and the pupil. 
  • These nodules are composed of collections of inflammatory cells.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Koeppe’s nodules are present at the pupillary margin of the iris.

questions.text: Which corrective procedure yields the most favorable obstetric outcome for a 24-year-old woman who visits the infertility clinic due to recurrent abortions and is diagnosed with a septate uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Transcervical septum resection is considered best as it avoids a uterine scar and elective cesarean section needs. The septum is resected with a resectoscope or scissors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Jones Metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

Option B: Strassmann metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that  has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

Option C: Tompkins metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that  has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • It is a case of Asherman Syndrome. Intrauterine adhesions are typically seen on HSG as multiple irregular linear filling defects (may give a lacunar pattern), with the inability to distend the endometrial cavity appropriately.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism caused by necrosis of the pituitary gland

Option B: Endometriosis is the occurrence of ectopic benign endometrial tissues outside the uterus cavity. Endometriosis is not well seen on the X-ray or the ultrasound version of the HSG.

Option D: Pyometra is a serious, life-threatening infection within the uterus. It is typically caused by anaerobic bacteria growth within a poorly draining uterus.

questions.text: Preconceptional use of which of the following leads to reduced incidence of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble B group vitamin. It is present in foods as folate and in supplements as folic acid, which has greater bioavailability. Folate plays an essential role in DNA synthesis and repair, and in cell growth and division. Adequate folate intake protects against neural tube birth defects (NTDs) as it prevents NTDs by rescuing de novo thymidylate biosynthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Iron is in  a negative iron balance during pregnancy, and the dietetic iron is not enough to meet the daily requirement, especially in the second half of the pregnancy. Thus, supplementary iron therapy is needed for all pregnant mothers from 16 weeks onwards.

Option C: Calcium supplementation during pregnancy for women with deficient dietary calcium intake offers modest benefits in terms of preventing preeclampsia and preterm births and improving maternal and infant bone health

Option D: Vit A is a fat-soluble vitamin, and high doses of vitamin A have a potential teratogenic effect and are therefore contra-indicated during pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the fistula labelled in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal opening between the bladder and the vagina that results in continuous and unremitting urinary incontinence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Vesicocervical Fistula is a rare type of urogenital fistula and is usually due to urinary bladder injury, which can occur during cesarean section due to its proximity to the uterus

Option B: Urethrovaginal Fistula is an abnormal passageway that may occur in the urethra and the vagina. It is a subset of vaginal fistulas. It can occur as an obstetrical complication, catheter insertion injury, or a surgical injury

Option C: Ureterovaginal Fistula is an abnormal passageway existing between the ureter and the vagina. It presents as urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency department with intense, sudden onset pelvic pain and profuse bleeding after giving birth at home. Diagnosis pointed towards secondary PPH. When does secondary postpartum haemorrhage develop?

choices.text: Shortly after the delivery of placenta

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 24 hours – 12 weeks after delivery:

  • The American college of obstetricians and gynaecologists defines secondary postpartum haemorrhage as bleeding 24 hours to 12 weeks after delivery. Such bleeding usually stems from abnormal involution of the placental site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D:

  • Hemorrhage occurring within 24hrs following the birth of a baby is called primary postpartum hemorrhage. These are of  two types, 
  • Third stage haemorrhage in which bleeding occurs before expulsion of placenta 
  • True postpartum hemorrhage where bleeding occurs subsequent to expulsion of placenta.

questions.text: Identify the sign that is seen during 8 weeks of pregnancy resulting in a dusky blue color of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Chadwick’s sign also known as jacquemier’s sign is the dusky blue hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Palmer’s sign:  regular and rhythmic uterine contractions elicited during bimanual examination as early as 4-8 weeks is called Palmer sign.

Option C - Hegar’s sign: it is present in two thirds of cases. It can be demonstrated between 6-10 weeks. On bimanual examination abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to oppose below the body of the uterus. This is because the upper part of the uterus is enlarged by the growing fetus, the lower part of the body is empty and extremely soft and the cervix is comparatively firm.

Option D - Osiander’s sign: increase in the pulsations felt on lateral fornix of vagina at 8th week is called osiander’s sign.

questions.text: In cases of genital tuberculosis, which segment of the fallopian tube is frequently affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • In the female genital tract, fallopian tubes are always the first to be involved in genital tuberculosis. The disease is commonly bilateral in distribution.
  • It affects the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male arrived at the emergency ward with sudden vision loss and experiencing painful eye movements. Upon examination, the affected eye shows a relative afferent pupillary defect, a normal optic disc, and a central scotoma. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Optic neuritis:

  • The sudden loss of vision, painful eye movements, relative afferent pupillary defects, and central scotoma are characteristic of optic neuritis.
  • It typically presents with marked sudden vision loss, dark adaptation may be lowered, and decreased contrast sensitivity.
  • On examination RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect), central scotoma, and centrocecal scotoma can be seen.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma is a type of brain tumor that can affect the optic nerve, but it is relatively rare in adults and typically presents with symptoms of optic nerve with proptosis.

Option C - Eale’s disease: Eale's disease is a condition that causes inflammation and occlusion of the retinal blood vessels, leading to vision loss and floaters.

Option D - Optic atrophy: It is characterized by atrophy of the all damaged nerve fibers with total afferent pupillary defect and loss of perception of light.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring benign tumor of the ovaries that affects both sides in women of reproductive age?
questions.solution:
Correct option B. Follicular cysts

Explanation:

Follicular cysts, also known as functional ovarian cysts, are the most frequently occurring benign tumors of the ovaries in women of reproductive age. These cysts form as a result of the menstrual cycle and typically resolve on their own without treatment.

The other options are incorrect because:

Option A. Epithelial cell tumor: Epithelial cell tumors of the ovaries are common, but they are more likely to be malignant rather than benign.

Option C. Sex cord stromal tumor: Sex cord stromal tumors, which include granulosa cell tumors and fibromas, are relatively rare ovarian tumors. They can be benign or malignant, but they are not the most frequently occurring benign tumors.

Option D. Benign teratoma: Benign teratomas, also known as dermoid cysts, are common ovarian tumors, but they often contain a mixture of tissues derived from different germ cell layers, including skin, hair, teeth, and other structures. They are typically found in younger women and are often unilateral.

questions.text: When selecting the strength of an intraocular lens (IOL) for a child under 1 year old, what factors should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • When choosing the power of an intraocular lens (IOL) in a child under 1 year of age, the myopic shift should be taken into account. 
  • A myopic shift is a phenomenon where the eye becomes more myopic as it grows, and this can lead to a child becoming increasingly nearsighted over time. 
  • To compensate for this, a lower power IOL should be chosen to allow for the myopic shift that will occur as the child's eye grows. 
  • The length of the lens capsule and growth of the lens capsule are important factors to consider when selecting an IOL, but they are not the primary factors in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypermetropic shift: Hypermetropic shift is not a relevant factor in choosing the power of an IOL in a child under 1 year of age. The hypermetropic shift is the phenomenon where the eye becomes more hyperopic as it grows, and this is not typically observed in young children.

Option C - Length of the lens capsule: The length of the lens capsule is an important factor to consider when selecting an IOL, but it is not the primary factor in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child.

Option D - Growth of the lens capsule: The growth of the lens capsule is an important factor to consider when selecting an IOL, but it is not the primary factor in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child.

questions.text: Please analyze the image provided and determine the specific abnormality or injury present.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Viral keratitis:

  • The lesion in viral keratitis is typically characterized by dendritic or branching patterns on the cornea, as seen in the image.
  • Viral keratitis is a type of corneal infection caused by a virus, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fungal keratitis: The lesion in fungal keratitis often presents as an infiltrate or ulcer with feathery edges (hyphae) and satellite lesions.

Option C - Bacterial keratitis: The lesion in bacterial keratitis often presents with ulcer, stromal edema, inflammation, and keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis.

Option D - Interstitial keratitis: This is a condition in which there is inflammation of the cornea that affects the middle layer (stroma) of the cornea. The lesion in interstitial keratitis is typically characterized by a hazy appearance of the cornea, with no obvious ulcer or infiltrate.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for a 21-year-old student to have ocular redness, feeling of a foreign object in the eye, and excessive tearing after wearing a soft contact lens, as indicated by the corneal scraping interface contrast microscopy image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acanthamoeba:

  • The clinical presentation of ocular redness, foreign body sensation, epiphora, history of using a soft contact lens, and image showing a cyst of acanthamoeba characterized by outer wrinkled wall is suggestive of acanthamoeba keratitis caused by acanthamoeba a free living protozoan.
  • It is prevalent in individuals using soft contact lens and using tap water for cleaning or swimming with the contact lens in a swimming pool.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Naegleria fowleri: Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare and often fatal brain infection known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Option C - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a parasitic amoeba that can cause amoebiasis, a gastrointestinal infection.

Option D - Balamuthia mandrillaris: Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare and often fatal brain infection known as granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE).

questions.text: What measures can be taken to decrease the likelihood of endometrial cancer in a postmenopausal woman undergoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Adding progesterone to estrogen

Explanation:

  • Estrogen is a hormone that plays a critical role in the growth and development of the female reproductive system. It is responsible for thickening and maintaining the lining of the uterus, or endometrium, during the menstrual cycle.
  • In postmenopausal women, the levels of estrogen decrease significantly, leading to thinning of the endometrium.    
  • However, if postmenopausal women take estrogen-only hormone therapy, it can stimulate the growth of the endometrial lining, which can increase the risk of endometrial cancer. This is because the constant exposure to estrogen can cause the endometrial cells to divide and multiply rapidly, leading to the development of abnormal cells that can become cancerous.
  • Adding progesterone to the hormone therapy can counteract this effect by balancing the growth-promoting effects of estrogen on the endometrium. In postmenopausal women, progesterone can help to thin the endometrial lining and reduce the risk of endometrial cancer. Combined with estrogen, it is referred to as hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

Incorrect Options:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (Option A) : While combined oral contraceptive pills contain both estrogen and progestin, they are not typically used to reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in postmenopausal women as they have different concentrations of progesterone and estrogen. 

Clonidine (Option B):  Clonidine is a medication used to treat high blood pressure but is not typically used to reduce the risk of endometrial cancer. Clonidine works by relaxing blood vessels, lowering blood pressure, and reducing the heart rate. Clonidine is not associated with any significant reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

Vitamin E (Option C): While vitamin E is an antioxidant that may have some health benefits. It is found in many foods, including nuts, seeds, fruits and vegetables, and is also available in supplement form. Vitamin E has not been shown to have a significant effect on the risk of endometrial cancer.

questions.text: What is the recommended approach for managing a middle-aged woman with a progressive pterygium that is extending towards the pupillary area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Excision with conjunctival autograft:

  • The most appropriate management for pterygium encroaching the pupillary area is surgical excision with conjunctival autograft. 
  • This involves removing the pterygium tissue and replacing it with a graft of healthy conjunctival tissue taken from another area of the patient's own eye. 
  • This procedure has been shown to have a low recurrence rate and a high success rate in preventing visual disturbance caused by the pterygium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratoplasty: Keratoplasty involves the surgical replacement of the cornea with a healthy donor cornea. Indicated for corneal opacities, bullous keratoplasty, corneal dystrophies, and keratoconus.

Option C - Observation: If the pterygium is not causing any visual disturbance, observation may be appropriate. However, if it is steadily progressing towards the pupillary area, it is likely to cause visual disturbances and should be managed surgically.

Option D - Beta-radiation: Beta-radiation therapy involves using low doses of radiation to prevent recurrence of the pterygium, not recommended.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who has a painless, firm nodule on the upper eyelid that is growing away from the lid margin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chalazion:

  • A hard, painless nodule that is growing outwards, away from the lid margin is a classic presentation of a chalazion.
  • It is typically painless but can cause discomfort or cosmetic concerns if it becomes large.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stye: A stye, also known as a hordeolum externum, is a painful, red, tender lump in the lid margin pointing anteriorly through the lid margin commonly caused by staphylococcus aureus...

Option B - Entropion: Entropion is a condition in which the eyelid turns inward, causing the lashes to rub against the eye's surface. It can cause irritation, redness, and tearing.

Option D - Blepharitis: Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelids that can cause redness, itching, and flaking of the eyelid skin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 27-year-old male patient who experiences eye trauma from vegetative matter, and currently exhibits symptoms including a corneal ulcer, hypopyon, satellite lesions, mild pain, photophobia, and redness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fungal keratitis:

  • The history of trauma with vegetative matter and the clinical features of a corneal ulcer, hypopyon, and satellite lesions are highly suggestive of fungal keratitis.
  • Fungal keratitis is a serious ocular infection that can result from trauma with vegetative matter, such as plant material, which can introduce fungal spores into the eye. 
  • The symptoms of fungal keratitis include pain, photophobia, redness, and a corneal ulcer with a feathery or irregular border. 
  • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber of the eye) and satellite lesions (smaller ulcers around the main ulcer) are also common in fungal keratitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acanthamoeba keratitis: Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare but serious eye infection caused by a free-living amoeba. It is typically associated with contact lens wear using tap water to clean and can present as painful, red eye with photophobia, blurred vision and ring like lesion n cornea. However, the presence of hypopyon and satellite lesions is not typical of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Option C - Viral keratitis: Viral keratitis is an infection of the cornea caused by a virus, such as herpes simplex virus. It can cause a painful, red eye with photophobia, stellate lesion, dendritic ulcer or geographical ulcer.

Option D - Bacterial keratitis: Bacterial keratitis is characterized by a dry/rough ulcer, with hypopyon (pus cells), stromal edema, descemet's membrane fold, and keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for a patient who experiences considerable discomfort when reading text from paper or a screen, despite having normal visual acuity and other eye examination findings, except for a Schirmer's test result of 5mm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lubricating eye drops:

  • A low Schirmer's test value of 5 mm (15 mm normal value)indicates reduced tear production and dry eye syndrome. 
  • Lubricants such as artificial tears like cellulose derivatives alleviate dry eye symptoms and improve visual comfort. They work by supplementing the natural tears, improving tear film stability, and reducing ocular surface inflammation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. They are not used for the management of Scirmer’s test.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who is experiencing severe itching, and thick discharge from his eyes. Upon examination the following finding as shown in the image was observed.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vernal keratoconjunctivitis:

  • The patient's symptoms of intense itching and thick ropy discharge, along with the presence of hard, flat-topped papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance, are characteristic of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trachoma: Trachoma is a chronic, infectious form of conjunctivitis caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is characterized by conjunctival scarring, trichiasis, and corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness if left untreated.

Option C - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigen, typically seen in children. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near limbus and conjunctival congestion..

Option D - Xerophthalmia: Xerophthalmia is a condition caused by severe vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by dryness and thickening of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can lead to corneal ulceration and blindness.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made, and she was posted for laparoscopic surgery. During the procedure, dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Cystectomy involves removing cysts that have formed on the ovaries, while adhesiolysis involves breaking down adhesions that have formed between organs in the pelvic region. This is a common surgical treatment for endometriosis, and it can help to alleviate symptoms and improve fertility in some patients. This would involve removing the ovarian cysts and breaking down the adhesions that are causing the organs to stick together. This can often help to alleviate the patient's symptoms and improve their chances of conceiving if they are trying to get pregnant.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - LUNA for chronic pelvic pain: Laparoscopic uterine nerve ablation (LUNA) is a surgical procedure that involves cutting nerves in the uterus to relieve chronic pelvic pain. However, LUNA is not typically used for the treatment of endometriosis, and it may not be effective for all patients. 

Option B - Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge: Gestrinone is a synthetic hormone that can help to reduce the production of luteinizing hormone (LH), which can trigger ovulation and lead to the growth of endometrial tissue. However, this medication is not typically used as a first-line treatment for endometriosis, and it may not be effective for all patients.

Option D - Hysterectomy and oophorectomy: Hysterectomy involves removing the uterus, while oophorectomy involves removing the ovaries. This is a more drastic treatment option that is typically reserved for patients with severe endometriosis who have not responded to other treatments, or for those who no longer wish to have children

questions.text: Postmenopausal bleeding is most commonly caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- cervical cancer:

  • MC cause of PMB in India: (MC presentation of Ca cervix , however, is post coital bleeding)
  •  MC cause of post menopausal bleeding: Ca cervix
  •  MC cause of PMB in the world: ca cervix

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B (Decubitus Ulcer): Decubitus ulcers, also known as pressure sores or bedsores, are not a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding. These ulcers occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin and are unrelated to postmenopausal bleeding.

  • Option C (Tubercular Endometritis): Tubercular endometritis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, can lead to chronic inflammation of the endometrium and may cause abnormal uterine bleeding. However, it is not the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding worldwide.

  • Option D (Hormone Replacement Therapy): Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), especially estrogen-alone therapy (unopposed estrogen), can cause postmenopausal bleeding. While this is a recognized cause, senile endometrial atrophy is more prevalent and commonly seen in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A patient with unilateral breast cancer is started on tamoxifen. This will increase the risk of which of the following?

choices.text: Breast cancer in the opposite breast

questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Tamoxifen is a medication that is commonly used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While tamoxifen can be effective in reducing the risk of breast cancer recurrence, it does have the potential to increase the risk of certain other types of cancer. One of the most significant risks associated with tamoxifen use is an increased risk of endometrial cancer. This is because tamoxifen acts as an estrogen antagonist in the breast tissue but acts as an estrogen agonist in the uterus, which can lead to abnormal growth of the uterine lining.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the ovaries, which are the female reproductive organs that produce eggs. Tamoxifen use is not associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer. However, women with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation may be at increased risk for both ovarian and breast cancer, and tamoxifen use may be recommended as a preventive measure.

Option C:  Tamoxifen use is actually used to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence in the same breast or the opposite breast in women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. Women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer in one breast may be at increased risk for developing breast cancer in the other breast, and tamoxifen can help reduce that risk.

Option D: Tamoxifen use is not associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer. However, regular cervical cancer screening is still important for all women, including those taking tamoxifen.

questions.text: In this case, a 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after experiencing bleeding from the vagina, which was preceded by a lack of menstrual periods for 7 weeks. The woman is in a state of hemodynamic shock and has a positive result for serum beta hCG. During the examination, a mass can be felt in the lower abdomen. What is the probable diagnosis in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The presentation of bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks, along with a positive serum beta hCG, and a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, are all suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs outside of the uterus, typically in the fallopian tubes. A ruptured ectopic pregnancy can cause hemodynamic shock and requires immediate medical attention. 
  • Some common causes of ectopic pregnancy include: 
  • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) 
  • Endometriosis Scarring or damage to the fallopian tubes
  •  Previous abdominal or pelvic surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pyelonephritis: This is a type of kidney infection caused by bacteria that have entered the kidneys from the urinary tract. Symptoms may include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and pain in the back or side. While pyelonephritis can be associated with urinary tract symptoms, it is not typically associated with vaginal bleeding or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.

Option B - Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: This is a type of tumor that can develop in the digestive tract, usually in the stomach or small intestine. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors are rare and not typically associated with vaginal bleeding or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, making this option unlikely. 

Option C - Red degeneration of fibroid: Fibroids are non-cancerous growths that can develop in the uterus. Red degeneration is a type of fibroid degeneration that can cause pain and vaginal bleeding. However, it is not typically associated with hemodynamic shock or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.

questions.text: What is the best recommended management in a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The best-recommended management for a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele depends on a number of factors, including the severity of the prolapse, the patient's symptoms, and their overall health. However, option C - both anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy - is a common surgical approach that is often recommended for cases of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele. Anterior colporrhaphy involves the repair of the anterior vaginal wall to correct a cystocele, while posterior colpoperineorrhaphy involves the repair of the posterior vaginal wall to correct a rectocele. These procedures are often performed together to address both the cystocele and rectocele and provide support to the vaginal vault.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:  Anterior colporrhaphy is a surgical procedure that is used to repair a cystocele or bladder prolapse only.

Option B: Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy is a surgical procedure that is used to repair a rectocele or rectal prolapse only. 

Option D: Hysterectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It may be recommended as a treatment option for a vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele if other treatments have failed or if there are other medical indications for the procedure, such as uterine cancer or endometriosis.

questions.text:
A 30 year old G2P2 delivered by normal vaginal delivery with no complications. The study of normal human placenta was done. The normal human placenta is ?


	Discoid 
	Hemochorial 
	Deciduate
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The human placenta is discoid because of its shape. It is hemochorial because of its direct contact of the chorion with the maternal blood and it is deciduate because of the maternal tissue which is shed at the time of parturition.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Other options a, b and c are incorrect.

questions.text: The highest incidence of ureteric injury is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Wertheim’s hysterectomy is also called Radical hysterectomy. Following this procedure, bladder atony or dysfunction is one of the known complications. It occurs due to damage to the ureters during surgery. It can also occur due to the damage or division of the sacral connection of the uterovaginal plexus that supplies the urinary bladder and urethra. In such cases, urinary catheterization is done and the bladder is drained continuously for a period of 6-10 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaginal hysterectomy: Vaginal hysterectomy rarely causes ureteric injury. Even though the postoperative complications are less, some immediate complications of vaginal hysterectomy include vault cellulitis, pelvic abscess, thrombophlebitis, pulmonary embolism. Late complication of vaginal hysterectomy is vault prolapse.

Option C -  Abdominal hysterectomy: Postoperative complications are high in case of abdominal hysterectomy. Some immediate complications include hemorrhagic shock, urinary retention due to pain/spasm, and cystitis. Some late complications include overflow incontinence, fever due to peritonitis, cystitis, vault cellulitis, pneumonia, abdominal wound infections, or vascular complications like DVT, phlebitis, intestinal obstruction, pulmonary embolism, hemorrhage, and hematomas. 

Option D - Emergency caesarean sections: Ureteral injury in cesarean sections are rare. However, it can occur while controlling bleeding from lateral extensions. Other intraoperative complications of cesarean section include uterine lacerations, extension of uterine incision, gastrointestinal tract injury, hemorrhage, bladder injury. Some postoperative complications include postpartum hemorrhage, shock, infections, DVT, wound complications, incisional hernia, menstrual irregularities, scar rupture, intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: In the menstrual cycle, which phase is characterized by the presence of vacuolation as a histological feature?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • In the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, there is involvement of both estrogen and progesterone which are released from the corpus luteum following ovulation. It begins from the 15th day and stops 5-6 days before menstruation. The glands increase in size, the surface epithelium turns more ciliated and columnar. Due to the secretion of glycogen between the basement membrane and nuclei, vacuoles are visualized. This is called SUBNUCLEAR VACUOLATION which is the earliest sign of progesterone effect (appears within 36-48 hours) and persists till the 21st day of cycle. Glands become corkscrew shaped. Marked spiralling of blood vessels are seen. Thickness of the endometrium is highest.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Proliferative phase: Starts from the 5th or 6th day till the 14 day. In this phase, there is rise in estrogen levels which makes the glands tubular, epithelium becomes columnar. Stromal cells become spindle shaped. Spiral vessels extend without giving out any branches below the epithelium. 

Option C - Menstrual phase: During this phase, there is a fall in the levels of estrogen and progesterone due to the regression of corpus luteum which result in the shedding of the endometrium prepared for a pregnancy.

Option D: Subnuclear vacuolation is a histological finding only observed in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. There is another phase called the Regenerative phase which starts before the menstruation ends and stops 2-3 days after the end of menstruation. New blood vessels grow from the stump of old ones.

questions.text: In a 55-year-old woman experiencing post-menopausal bleeding, which investigation is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • During postmenopausal period, endometrial biopsy is mandatory to rule out endometrial carcinoma. It is a well-tolerated and less invasive procedure with minimal complications and is done as an outpatient procedure. Endometrial thickness of more than 4-5 mm on TVS is ,endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.
  • Post-menopausal bleeding is considered abnormal and requires thorough evaluation to rule out underlying pathology, especially endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows the collection of a sample of the endometrial tissue for examination, providing valuable information about the presence of cancer or other abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A -Ultrasound : Ultrasound is often performed initially to evaluate the thickness of the endometrial lining. If the lining appears thickened, further evaluation, such as an endometrial biopsy, is typically warranted.

Option C - Fractional curettage: Fractional curettage is a more invasive procedure which is done under general anesthesia. It is preferred in case of any suspicion of cancer or when endometrial biopsy is inconclusive or cannot be obtained, in cases of cervical stenosis.

Option D - CA-125: Is a tumor marker used to closely monitor the progression and treatment of ovarian epithelial tumors. It is also elevated in endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, breast lung, pancreas or liver carcinomas. However, it cannot be used as a routine screening tool for the general crowd due to the reduced specificity and sensitivity.

questions.text: A nulliparous lady with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done and an image of the same is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • In PCOS, there is elevated androgen secretion by the ovaries which result in hirsutism (male pattern hair growth), hyperinsulinemia, hyperprolactinemia. The given ultrasound shows an enlarged ovary with multiple cysts peripherally arranged which suggests polycystic ovarian syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Tubal block is usually visualized by hysterosalpingogram (HSG). A few causes are salpingitis, benign polyps within the lumen of the tube, tubal endometriosis, tubal spasm and intratubal mucous debris.

Option C: In Multiple fibroids, transvaginal sonograms show enlarged, distorted uterus homogeneous echogenic areas over the fibroid. Majority are asymptomatic, however a few experience menstrual abnormality, dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, pressure symptoms, recurrent miscarriage, pelvic or lower abdominal pain.

Option D: In mesenteritis, ultrasound shows thickened and distorted appearance of the root of mesentery with a halo of sparing surrounding the vessels. Most common symptoms of mesenteritis are fever, abdominal pain, and features of intestinal obstruction may also be present. In some cases, abdominal mass can be felt.

questions.text: Ritodrine, a medication used to prevent premature labor, is associated with several maternal complications, except for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Ritodrine is a betamimetic. It causes hyperglycemia and not hypoglycemia by stimulating the release of glucose from the liver and skeletal muscles, into the circulation and reducing insulin secretion. Betamimetics can also cause a shift in the hormonal balance thereby increasing the glucose levels. Hypoglycemia is a neonatal side effect of betamimetics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • Tremors occur due to stimulation of the sympathetic nervous pathway by betamimetic agents, thereby releasing epinephrine which is responsible for flight and fight responses.

Option B:

  • Ritodrine may lead to maternal tachycardia due to its beta-2 adrenergic agonist properties.

Option D:

  • Pulmonary edema can occur due to increased vascular permeability which causes leakage of fluids into the lungs. Hence, close monitoring is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about radiotherapy for a 52-year-old woman diagnosed with stage 2B cervical carcinoma is incorrect?

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the interna uterine canal
Point A receive a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B received a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.solution:
Option B. Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal.

Explanation:

In the standard radiotherapy protocol for cervical carcinoma, Point A is defined as 2 cm above the external os and 2 cm lateral to the junction of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, not 5 cm lateral. Point B is 3 cm lateral to Point A. These points are crucial in radiation therapy planning for cervical cancer to ensure accurate delivery of radiation to the affected area while sparing surrounding healthy tissues.

Therefore, option b is incorrect because Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 2 cm lateral to the junction of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, not 5 cm lateral.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anaesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Le fort’s repair involves the closure of the anterior and posterior vaginal wall followed by approximation using chromic catgut sutures. This procedure is ideally indicated in elderly women who have severe pelvic organ prolapse, who is unfit for longer duration of surgery, and those who are no longer sexually active. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abdominal wall cervicopexy: Also called as sling operation is indicated in nulliparous or congenital prolapse without cystocele where the cervix is pulled up through abdominal route. A sling is placed anchoring to the anterior abdominal wall and sacrum to provide support to the prolapsed pelvic organs.

Option B - Shirodkar’s sling operation: Also called as anterior colporrhaphy. It is indicated in young women < 40 years of age who are desirous of retaining their childbearing functions. The cervix is not amputated instead it is fixed to the lumbo-sacral fascia using a Mersilene tape, hence pregnancy complications are avoided.

Option D -  Khanna’s sling operation: A mesh sling is placed under the neck of the uterus and is attached to the pubic bone on both sides. The sling supports the mackenrodt’s ligaments. It is similarly indicated in women with grade 2 or grade 3 uterine prolapse who are desirous of retaining their menstrual functions.

questions.text: What might be the likely diagnosis for a 34-year-old woman who has previously given birth once and has experienced abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding during labor, and a lack of fetal movement? She smokes occasionally but does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Upon examination, her pulse rate is 80 beats per minute, blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, and her abdomen feels tense when palpated.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Smoking is associated with premature separation of the placenta (Abruptio placenta) by vasoconstriction of the vessels, thereby reducing blood supply to the placenta. Smoking can result in oxidative damage to the blood vessels, promote platelet aggregation resulting in the formation of blood clots within the placenta. Advancing age of the mother (34 year old) is also a risk factor. All these factors can contribute to the development of Abruptio placenta. The patient usually presents with painful bleeding which is dark coloured. On examination, severe pallor is seen and the patient may be in a state of shock. On abdominal examination, the uterus may feel tense, rigid, and tender, fetal heart sounds are usually absent.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Placenta previa: In placenta previa, the placenta partially or completely covers the lower uterine segment. The patient usually presents with painless, causeless, recurrent bleeding which is bright red in color. On abdominal examination, the uterus is felt soft and relaxed, fetal heart sounds will be usually present. Smoking can cause hypertrophy/increase in the size of the placenta to compensate for reduced oxygenation caused due to carbon monoxide.

Option C - Hydramnios: Polyhydramnios is a condition where excess collection of liquor amnii is more than 2000 ml. However, there is no definitive link between smoking and development of polyhydramnios.

Option D - Preterm labor: Smoking has a close association with preterm labour by reducing the flow of blood and oxygen to the growing fetus. Often children born to smoking mothers weigh lesser compared to normal babies. In this case scenario, the patient will have regular uterine contractions one in every 10 minutes, cervix dilatation > 2 cm with 80% effacement, vaginal bleeding or discharge will be present. Perception of fetal movements would depend on the gestation age. During preterm labor, fetal movements can be less frequent/ less appreciable which would indicate fetal distress.

questions.text: A 27 year old primigravida delivered by normal vaginal delivery has postpartum vaginal discharge. What is the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
Option A. 5-15 days

Explanation:

Lochia is the vaginal discharge that occurs after childbirth. It consists of blood, tissue from the lining of the uterus, and bacteria. Lochial discharge typically occurs for several weeks after childbirth as the uterus sheds its lining. The duration and characteristics of lochia can vary from woman to woman, but it generally follows a pattern:

Option B. Lochia Rubra (Days 1-3): Initially, lochia is bright red and consists mainly of blood. It is often heavy during the first few days after childbirth.

Option C. Lochia Serosa (Days 4-10): As the bleeding slows down, lochia becomes pink or brownish in color due to the presence of red blood cells and serous fluid.

Option D. Lochia Alba (After Day 10): Gradually, lochia changes to a yellowish-white color and decreases in amount. Lochia alba can last for several more weeks and may persist for up to 4-6 weeks after childbirth.

Therefore, the typical duration of lochial discharge is within the range of 5-15 days. Prolonged or heavy lochia, foul odor, or other concerning symptoms should be evaluated by a healthcare provider.

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment for a 55-year-old patient with simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia has 8% chance of progressing to endometrial malignancy. 
  • In simple hyperplasia the endometrium is thick, glands are dilated with invaginations, dense stroma is present.
  • Atypia indicates that the nuclei of the glands are enlarged, irregular in shape and size, with hyperchromasia indicating a premalignant lesion. In this case, a 55 year old postmenopausal woman with simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia would require a simple hysterectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Is given in young premenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia. MPA is given 10mg twice daily. Every 3 months, endometrial sampling is done. However, in case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia, hysterectomy is the mainstay of treatment due to the higher risk of invasive cancer.

Option C - Levonorgestrel: Is indicated in young premenopausal women with cystic or adenomatous hyperplasia without atypia. It is given for a period of 6-9 months. Endometrial sampling is done every 6 months.

Option D - Radiotherapy: Is not ideally the first line of treatment in endometrial hyperplasia. However, who are not fit for surgery or those who are not ideal surgical candidates or those who refuse surgery can receive radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and vaginal discharge. Her friend revealed that she had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, tenderness over the uterus and foul-smelling vaginal discharge were observed; her BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and RR was 36/min. On blood culture, a gram-positive and aerobic bacterium is isolated. Which of the following is a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Streptococcus pyogenes:

In the given scenario, where the patient presents with symptoms of fever, intense lower abdominal pain, pus-like vaginal discharge, hypotension, tachycardia, and a history of unsafe abortion, the most likely causative agents are bacteria associated with septic abortion. The blood culture showing gram-positive and aerobic bacteria responsible for the patient's condition is streptococcus pyogenes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clostridium perfringens: Clostridium perfringens is a gram-positive and anaerobic bacteria responsible for causing septic abortion.

Option C - Clostridium welchii: Clostridium welchii is also a gram-positive and anaerobic bacteria responsible for causing septic abortion.

Option D – Escherichia coli: E. coli is a gram-negative and aerobic bacteria responsible for causing septic abortion.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of a 14-year-old girl's condition, who has not experienced menarche yet, and presents with cyclic abdominal pain and a hypogastric lump visible during per vaginal examination, along with a bluish swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The age of the child, chief complaints and examination findings point towards the diagnosis of imperforate hymen. As the child attains 14-16 years of age, menstrual blood gets accumulated in the vagina behind the hymen. Slowly it distends the vagina first, followed by the uterine cavity, and later it distends the fimbrial ends of the fallopian tubes. Imperforate hymen occurs due to the failure of disintegration of the central cells of Mullerian eminence. Vulval inspection may reveal a bluish bulging membrane. The diagnosis can be confirmed by ultrasonography.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bartholin: Bartholin glands two glands that are situated in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora. Infections involving the bartholin gland are usually polymicrobial. Bartholin abscess is associated with fever and unilateral painful swelling beneath the posterior half of labia majora. Bartholin cyst is a unilateral swelling on the posterior half of labia majora which contains glairy colourless fluid.

Option B - Transverse vaginal septum: A thick band of fibrous tissue separates the vagina horizontally into 2 compartments. This produces symptoms similar to imperforate hymen. In majority, the obstructing membrane is often the transverse vaginal septum which lies in close proximity to the inner aspect of the hymen.

Option D - Endometrioma: Endometriosis is a condition where the tissue that lines the uterine endometrium, grows on sites, like ovaries, and fallopian tubes. Endometriomas are ovarian cysts that form due to endometriosis. As the cyst ruptures, tarry, thick fluid (chocolate material) escapes, hence It is also called a chocolate cyst. It occurs in the age group between 30-45 years of age. 70% present with dysmenorrhoea, 40-60% present with infertility, 20-40% present with dyspareunia.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an 18-year-old girl who has been experiencing low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea for the past six months? During examination, a pelvic mass is detected on the left side, and signs of ascites are evident.
questions.solution:
Correct option D: Genital tuberculosis

  • Considering the age of the child and symptoms like fever, weight loss, 6 month history of amenorrhoea, and examination findings point towards the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis is seen between 20-40 years of age, which is the child bearing age group. Symptoms include low grade fever, night sweats, anorexia. Amenorrhoea occurs due to the suppression of ovarian functions by the tubercular toxins resulting in oophoritis or due to uterine synechiae formation. On abdominal examination, the abdomen may feel doughy due to matted intestines, free fluid may be present in rare cases and sometimes it can mimic an ovarian cyst. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Submucous fibroid: it produces maximum symptoms like menorrhagia, severe dysmenorrhoea, subfertility, pressure symptoms, recurrent miscarriage, preterm labor, abdominal enlargement..

Option B - Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy is seen more often in the postmenopausal age group and there is increased association with nulliparity. Symptoms are nonspecific, including abdominal distension, loss of appetite, pelvic pain. As the tumor grows in size, symptoms become more pronounced. 

  • On per vaginal examination, the uterus may be separated from the mass felt per abdomen. 
  • Ascites are often present due to obstruction in the flow of peritoneal fluid through the diaphragm. 
  • Right pleural effusion may also be present.

Option C - Ectopic pregnancy: The fertilized ovum gets implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. It occurs between 20-30 years of age. 

  • If the diagnosis is ruptured ectopic, symptoms include a short period of amenorrhoea (around 6-8 weeks), colicky type of lower abdominal abdominal pain, vomiting. 
  • Features of shock like pallor, hypotension, cold clammy extremities may be observed. On abdominal examination, no mass is usually felt. 
  • Per vaginal examination may reveal extreme forniceal tenderness or tenderness on movement of the cervix. In unruptured ectopic pregnancy, symptoms like delayed periods or spotting or unilateral flank pain is seen. 
  • On bimanual examination, a pulsatile, small, well circumscribed tender mass can be felt which is felt separate from the uterus.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in the management of a pregnant woman who is 36 weeks pregnant, has a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis, and is currently on warfarin therapy with an international normalized ratio (INR) of 3?
