choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • In this case scenario, since the INR is 3 indicates that the patient has an increased risk of developing bleeding. 
  • Low molecular weight heparins have lesser chances of bleeding compared to warfarin. 
  • They have a longer half-life hence once daily dose is sufficient.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Stop warfarin and start aspirin: Aspirin in high doses during the last trimester can result in premature closure of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, and kernicterus in the baby. Hence, it is generally avoided during pregnancy.

Option C - Continue warfarin: Since this patient’s INR is around 3, it is better to stop warfarin since the chances of bleeding is known to be high. Warfarin can cross the placenta cause fetal complications like embryopathy, nasal hypoplasia, mental retardation, microcephaly, bone stiplings, and optic atrophy.Hence, it is advised to stop warfarin and switch to other safer anticoagulants like low-molecular weight heparin.

Option D - Stop warfarin, star LMWH and aspirin: Starting two anticoagulants simultaneously can increase the chances of maternal bleeds and can cause life threatening complications to both the mother and the baby. Hence, it is ideally not recommended.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, what possible diagnosis can be determined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Pott’s spine: 

  • The given MRI image is suggestive of changes corresponding to Potts's spine. It is suggestive of the Paradisaical type of Potts's spine as the infection is destroying adjacent vertebral bodies causing disc space narrowing and weakness of the spine. Therefore, option d is the correct choice.
  • Pott’s spine is an extrapulmonary manifestation of TB. Disc Space Narrowing, paravertebral abscess, and vertebral lysis are common features observed in the case of Pott’s spine x-ray.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Multiple Myeloma: It shows Cannon ball Metastasis, Decreased Bone thickness, usually present in the elderly age group. On MRI of the lumbosacral spine, collapsed vertebrae are observed. The sagittal T1 image of the lumbar spine should show a salt-and-pepper appearance of the vertebral marrow in the patient. Since none of them are observed, it is an incorrect choice.

Option B - Ankylosis Spondylitis: It shows features of Sacroiliitis, i.e., inflammation of the sacroiliac joint on Radiology, which isn’t observed in the given MRI image. Thus, it is an incorrect choice.

Option C - Pyogenic Spondylitis: It presents with an abscess in proximity to the spine. Regional osteopenia, new bone apposition, and peripheral sclerosis are some of the radiographic features. Since the given MRI doesn’t show any abscess, it is concluded that option c is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 74-year-old man, who comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of substantial unintentional weight loss, lack of appetite, and iron deficiency anemia, after a chest x-ray was performed and the results are provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Given X-ray image is suggestive of Cannon Ball Metastasis to the Lungs. This can be seen in different types of malignancies. Cannonball Metastasis is seen in choriocarcinoma because of the rich vascular supply, due to which metastasis occurs via the vascular route to the lungs.
  • These cannonball metastases appear on chest X-rays as multiple white opacities like the fire of cannonballs. All these white opacities represent metastatic deposits.
  • White opacities are clearly observed in the given X-ray, indicating option c as the correct choice.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Bronchogenic Carcinoma is associated with increased vascularity and mass in the lung that may abut the vessels, and it may be associated with central necrosis and cavitation. It can also be associated with hypercalcemia and calcification deposits in the lungs. So, the X-ray shows central necrosis, cavitation, and hypercalcemia in a patient, which is not observed in the given case. Therefore, option A is an incorrect choice.

Option B: Mesothelioma is associated with pleural plaques and deposits over pleura, which is not seen in the given X-rays, making it an incorrect choice. 

Option D: Pneumoconiosis is seen in X-rays in different patterns depending upon the type of pneumoconiosis. For example, in asbestosis, multiple pleural plaques are observed. Coal worker pneumoconiosis can present with emphysema, multiple pneumoconiotic changes, and hyperinflation. All these changes are not seen in the given x-ray. Thus, option d is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the subject matter of the X-ray image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The X-ray is suggestive of pleural effusion. The given chest X-ray shows obliteration of the left costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung noted tracking along the CP angle and lateral chest wall.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tension Pneumothorax: It has air filling in the pleural cavity causing compression over lung parenchyma resulting in a Visceral pleural line sign which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

Option B - Emphysema: It would show air trapping along with hyperinflation of alveoli resulting in decreased opacity and increased translucency with hyper-inflated lungs, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

Option D - Bronchiectasis: It is associated with a signet ring sign along with dilated central and peripheral airways, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

questions.text: From the provided MRI, please identify the medical condition observed in the lower back of the newborn, which presents as an abnormal lump.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • The given MRI image is suggestive of a meningocele which represents CSF filled cavity in the Lumbosacral region surrounded by meninges, which is making a protrusion over the lumbosacral region. It is a T2 WI image that shows CSF filled white cystic cavity known as a meningocele. 
  • Meningocele is a birth defect where the affected individual has a sac filled with spinal fluid-filled protruding from the spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Myelomeningocele: The MRI image of myelomeningocele shows a protruding neural placode extending beyond the skin surface as an enlargement of the underlying subarachnoid space. Since the given image does not show this, it is suggestive that the option is incorrect.

Option C - Spina Bifida Occulta: A plain radiograph in this condition would show a midline or para-midline bony defect at the posterior arch. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option D - Bone cyst: It is a cystic lesion inside the bone seen on X-ray as a lesion filled with fluid. Since the given findings do not match the description, it is considered an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Which among the following radioactive isotopes is not employed in brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Iodine-131 is used in Systemic Radiotherapy like Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. I-131 is also used for the treatment of benign hyperthyroid conditions. It is, however, not used in any form of brachytherapy. Therefore, option b is the correct answer.
  • In brachytherapy, a radiation source is placed inside the body of tumor tissue or on the body of tumor tissue. This minimizes radiation exposure to the persons handling it and also to the person who is receiving brachytherapy.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Iodine- 125: I-125, with a half-life of 60 days, is the most common radioactive isotope used in permanent interstitial brachytherapy. Hence, it is an incorrect choice.

Option B - Cobalt- 60: These radioactive isotopes are produced by neutron activation of stable cobalt-59. They have a half-life of 5.27 years. These have been used in intracavitary or HDR brachytherapy for a long. Therefore, it is an incorrect choice.

Option D - Iridium-192: Iridium-192 is produced by neutron activation of stable Iridium-191. They have a half-life of 73.83 days. These radioactive isotopes are used in HDR brachytherapy. Therefore, they are incorrect choices.

questions.text: A newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pharyngeal arch 1

  • The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, is a crucial structure in embryonic development, forming part of the head and neck region. It gives rise to various structures that are essential for the formation of the face and neck.
  • Defects in the development of this arch can result in a condition called mandibulofacial dysostosis or Treacher-Collins syndrome, which is characterized by the same features described in the scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pharyngeal arch 2:. Abnormal development of this arch can result in abnormalities of the ear and hearing, but not the features described in the scenario.

Option C - Pharyngeal arch 3: Abnormal development of this arch can result in problems with swallowing and speech, but not the features described in the scenario.

Option D - Pharyngeal arch 4: Abnormal development of these arches can cause problems with speech and breathing, but not the features described in the scenario.

questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pons:

  • The marked structure in the image is the pons.
  • It is visible on an MRI or CT scan as a larger bulge in the brainstem.
  • In a sagittal section, the pons may appear as a larger, oval-shaped structure located below the midbrain and above the medulla oblongata. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Midbrain:

  • In a sagittal section, the midbrain may appear as a small round structure located above the pons and below the thalamus.
  • It is located anterior to the fourth ventricle and has a distinctive "butterfly" shape on axial views.

Option C - Medulla oblongata:

  • The medulla oblongata is visible on an MRI or CT scan as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord.
  • In a sagittal section, the medulla oblongata may appear as a smaller, pointed structure located below the pons.
  • The medulla oblongata appears as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord and is located at the bottom of the brainstem.

Option D - Spinal cord:

  • The spinal cord is located within the spinal canal, which is formed by the vertebrae of the spine.
  • In a sagittal section, the spinal cord may appear as a central canal surrounded by white matter and gray matter.

questions.text: A patient underwent a left submandibular gland excision during which the hypoglossal nerve was injured. Which of the following deficits would be seen in this case?

choices.text: Deviated tongue to the contralateral side
Deviated tongue to the same side
Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Deviated tongue to the same side

  • The hypoglossal nerve innervates tongue muscles, including intrinsic and extrinsic muscles. Injury during submandibular gland excision can lead to weakness or paralysis on the same side, causing the tongue to deviate towards that side when protruded. This happens because the hypoglossal nerve supplies most tongue muscles on the same side, leading to an imbalance in muscle function. The deviation may be subtle or quite noticeable, depending on the severity of the injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Deviated tongue to the contralateral side: Injury to the hypoglossal nerve during submandibular gland excision leads to ipsilateral tongue deviation when protruded, not contralateral. 

Option C - Inability to protrude tongue: While injury to the hypoglossal nerve may cause weakness or paralysis of the tongue muscles, it would not necessarily result in an inability to protrude the tongue..

Option D - Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue:. The hypoglossal nerve is not involved in taste sensation. The posterior 1/3rd of the tongue is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle indicated in the provided image?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option C - Abduction of shoulder joint

  • The muscle marked in the question is the supraspinatus, which is present above the spine of the scapula and helps abduct the shoulder joint. The muscles involved in abducting the shoulder joint are the deltoid muscle, supraspinatus muscle, and the trapezius muscle

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retraction of scapula: The muscles involved in retracting the scapula are the middle and lower trapezius muscles and the rhomboid major and minor muscles.

Option B - Protraction of scapula: The muscles involved in protracting the scapula are the serratus anterior muscle.

Option D - Adduction of shoulder joint: The muscles involved in adducting the shoulder joint are the latissimus dorsi muscle, pectoralis major muscle, and the teres major muscle.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labelled 2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Upper border of L3

  • The abdominal plane labeled as 2 is the Subcostal plane, also known as the "plane of the superior mesenteric artery." It's located just below the costal margin, connecting the 10th costal cartilages bilaterally.
  • In the posterior aspect, it corresponds to the upper border of the third lumbar (L3) vertebra. This plane intersects with the aorta, inferior vena cava, and the third part of the duodenum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - lower border of L1

  • At the lower border of L1 is the location of the transpyloric plane, which is also known as the "plane of Addison."

Option B - Upper border of L1

  • The upper border of L1 does not correspond to the subcostal plane.

Option D - Lower border of L4

  •  The lower border of L4 is the location of the intertubercular plane, which is also known as the "plane of the iliac crests.

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pivot joint:

  • The forearm's radius and ulna bones are connected at the elbow joint to the upper arm's humerus bone. This joint allows for rotational movements like supination (palm up) and pronation (palm down) as the radius rotates around the stationary ulna. It's a pivot joint, permitting movement around a single axis, supported by ligaments and muscles for stability and control of motion range.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Saddle joint: A saddle joint in the thumb enables a wide range of motion in multiple directions but isn't involved in the forearm's rotational movement.

Option C - Ellipsoid joint: An ellipsoid joint is a type of joint found in the wrist. It allows for movement in two planes but not rotation around a single axis.  

Option D - Ball and socket joint: A ball and socket joint is found in the hip and shoulder joints and does not play a significant role in the rotational movement of the forearm.

questions.text: Infer the extent of the thyroid gland from the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A to D

  • A- C5
  • B- C6
  • C- C7
  • D- T1

The thyroid gland is situated in the front of the neck, below the larynx, between the C5 and T1 vertebrae.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - B to D: The structures that extend from C6 to T1 vertebrae include the posterior cervical muscles, including the semispinalis cervicis, splenius cervicis, and longissimus cervicis muscles.. 

Option B - A to C: The structures that extend from C5 to C7 vertebrae include the anterior scalene, middle scalene, and posterior scalene muscles, which form the scalene triangle.  

Option D - C to D: The structures that extend from C7 to T1 vertebrae include the first rib, which is located between these two vertebrae.

questions.text: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria, and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Wallenberg syndrome:

  • Results from acute infarct in dorsolateral medulla region of brainstem.
  • Symptoms: Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), dysarthria (difficulty speaking), gait ataxia (unsteadiness while walking).
  • Dorsolateral medulla: Controls various functions; symptom severity varies based on infarct location and extent

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome:

  • Rare condition from damage to lower part of brainstem.
  • Symptoms: Paralysis of muscles for chewing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Different from Wallenberg syndrome, which involves dorsolateral medulla specifically.

Option C - Babinski-Nageotte syndrome:

  • Babinski-Nageotte syndrome is a term that is not commonly used in medical literature. It may refer to a combination of symptoms involving weakness or paralysis of the arm and leg on one side of the body, along with abnormal reflexes. However, this is not a well-defined syndrome

Option D - Weber syndrome:

  • Results from midbrain damage, leading to weakness or paralysis on one side of the body.
  • Other symptoms: Abnormal eye movements.

questions.text: The image shows the cross-section of the abdominal cavity. Identify the structure marked ‘A.’
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Descending aorta:

  • The diagram focuses on the posterior mediastinum, and the marked structure is descending aorta. The round structure just in front of the vertebral column is descending aorta, slightly towards the left. The descending aorta is located posterior to the diaphragm, in the midline of the body. It is a continuation of the thoracic aorta and descends along the vertebral column in the posterior mediastinum before entering the abdominal cavity. In the abdominal cavity, it descends along the posterior wall, slightly to the left of the midline, and gives off branches to the abdominal organs.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava, found in the superior mediastinum, enters the right atrium of the heart. It is not visible in abdominal cavity cross-sections.

Option C - Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava enters the right atrium from the posterior mediastinum, traveling along the back of the abdominal wall to the right of the midline, collecting blood from the lower body and abdominal organs.

Option D - Ascending aorta: The ascending aorta begins at the left ventricle, ascends to the superior mediastinum, and branches into the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery.

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B

  • The straight sinus, positioned at the junction of the falx cerebri and the tentorium cerebelli, receives tributaries like the great cerebral vein of Galen, formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins. Other tributaries include the inferior sagittal sinus and the occipital sinus. Blood from the straight sinus ultimately drains into the confluence of sinuses, where the superior sagittal sinus, straight sinus, and occipital sinus converge.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A: The superior sagittal sinus drains the blood from the front and top of the brain and empties into the confluence of sinuses, where it meets the straight sinus and other sinuses. 

Option C - C:The transverse sinuses, running horizontally at the back of the skull, receive blood from various sinuses including the superior sagittal sinus and inferior sagittal sinus. They then descend to form the sigmoid sinuses..

Option D - D: The sigmoid sinuses receive blood from the transverse sinuses, petrosal sinuses, and nearby veins, draining into the jugular veins that return blood to the heart.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extensor pollicis longus:

  • The pointed structure in the shown image is the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox which is away from the thumb formed by the extensor pollicis longus muscle. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis brevis muscle in the forearm assists in thumb abduction and borders the anatomical snuffbox.

Option B - Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis muscle, situated in the forearm, extends the thumb and lies alongside the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C - Abductor pollicis longus: The abductor pollicis longus muscle, in the forearm, aids in wrist abduction and lies near the proximal border of the anatomical snuffbox.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The artery palpated in the image shown is the posterior tibial artery; it is palpated between the medial malleolus and Achilles tendon/tendocalcaneous. Locate the medial malleolus (the bony bump on the inside of the ankle). Place your index and middle fingers on the inside of the ankle and move your fingers behind the medial malleolus towards the back of the leg. You should be able to feel the posterior tibial artery pulsations in this area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior tibial artery: To palpate the anterior tibial artery, ask the patient to lie down or sit with their legs slightly bent. Locate the ankle bones (medial malleolus and lateral malleolus) and identify the space between them. Place your index and middle fingers on the space between the ankle bones and move your fingers upwards towards the top of the foot. You should be able to feel the anterior tibial artery pulsations in this area.

Option C - Dorsalis pedis artery: To palpate the dorsalis pedis artery, ask the patient to lie down or sit with their legs slightly bent. Locate the first and second metatarsal bones (the bones that connect to the big toe). Place your index and middle fingers on the top of the foot, just below the space between the first and second metatarsal bones, you can feel the pulsations there.

Option D - Popliteal artery: To palpate the popliteal artery, ask the patient to lie down on their stomach or to sit with their legs hanging off the edge of the exam table. Flex the knee to about 90 degrees. Use your fingers to locate the popliteal fossa, which is the small depression behind the knee joint. Feel for the pulsation of the artery in the middle of the fossa. Press your fingers gently into the popliteal fossa and feel for the pulsation of the artery.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Syndesmosis:

  • The image is of the middle radio ulnar joint which is formed by the interosseous ligament. This is a type of fibrous joint which is syndesmosis. The syndesmosis is a type of joint that is formed by the union of two bones by a strong, fibrous tissue called a ligament. This type of joint is found in areas where stability is more important than mobility, such as the distal tibiofibular joint in the ankle and the distal radioulnar joint in the wrist.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Symphysis: Symphysis joints fuse two bones with fibrocartilage, allowing limited movement crucial for shock absorption and flexibility, like in the pelvis and spine.

Option C - Synchondrosis: Synchondrosis joints are formed by hyaline cartilage connecting two bones, commonly found in areas of growth and development like children's epiphyseal plates. 

Option D - Synostosis: Synostosis occurs when bones fuse due to various reasons like trauma or congenital conditions, leading to no mobility. Examples include cranial suture and radius-ulna fusion.

questions.text: After a fall from a height with his hand outstretched, a man is brought to the emergency department. An X-ray reveals a fracture in the clavicle. Which specific region of the clavicle is the most likely to be fractured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd

  • The junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd of the clavicle. This is the most common site of clavicular fracture, accounting for approximately 80% of all clavicular fractures. This area is also known as the "junction" or "transition zone" because it is where the clavicle changes from a thicker, more rounded bone to a thinner, flatter bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Junction of medial 1/3rd and lateral 2/3rd: Clavicular fractures at this junction are rare due to its thickness and strength, needing considerable force to cause a fracture 

Option C - Junction of middle 1/3rd and medial 1/3rd: Fractures at the middle 1/3rd and medial 1/3rd junction of the clavicle are uncommon due to its thinner and more flexible nature.

Option D - Middle of the clavicle: Mid-clavicular fractures are uncommon and typically result from direct trauma or a fall onto the shoulder, rather than a fall onto an outstretched hand.

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the given structure correspond?

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The marked structure is the umbilicus which lies at the junction of L3 & L4. The umbilicus is located at the level of the intervertebral disc between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, the ureters, and the descending colon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - At the junction of L1 & L2:  Associated structures at this level include the spinal cord, the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the renal arteries and veins, and the ureters.

Option B - At the junction of L2 & L3:  Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, and the ascending colon. 

Option C - At the junction of T12 & L1:  Associated structures at this level include the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the celiac trunk, the superior mesenteric artery, and the renal arteries.

questions.text: Name the dural venous arrow marked in the radiograph.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Straight sinus

  • The marked structure is a straight sinus. The straight sinus is a small midline structure that runs from the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli to the confluence of sinuses. It can be seen in imaging studies such as MRI or CT scans. It appears as a thin curvilinear opacity on the midline of the skull radiograph, just posterior to the frontal bone and anterior to the occipital bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior sagittal sinus: The superior sagittal sinus is a prominent midline structure running from the frontal to the occipital regions atop the brain, often visible on MRI or CT scans.

Option C - Inferior sagittal sinus: The inferior sagittal sinus, a small midline structure, extends along the underside of the brain from the frontal to the occipital regions, visible on MRI or CT scans.

Option D - Confluence of sinuses: The confluence of sinuses is where the superior sagittal, straight, and occipital sinuses meet, a significant neuroanatomical landmark identifiable on MRI or CT scans.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor complains of vision loss in his left eye. He compares the sensation to a curtain being pulled over his affected eye. Additionally, he experienced flashing lights and floaters a week ago. The provided image shows a B-scan of his left eye. What could be the possible diagnosis for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Retinal detachment:

  • The clinical presentation of flashes of light, floaters, and curtain like effect is suggestive of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • B scan reveals the cyst representing vitreous fluid between the neurosensory layer and retinal pigmented epithelium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glaucoma: It is a disease that damages the optic nerve, often caused by high pressure inside the eye. It typically causes a gradual loss or sudden loss of vision but curtain like effect is not seen..

Option B - Posterior vitreous detachment Retinal : It is characterized by floaters, flashes of light, and blurred vision.

Option D - Corneal ulcers: They are painful sores on the surface of the eye that can cause redness, tearing, and sensitivity to light.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has been displaying increased clumsiness for the past 6 months, and upon examination, a cauliflower-like growth, leukocoria, and an absent red reflex in the left eye? Enucleation was performed, and microscopic examination of the specimen reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from immature retinal cells in young children, typically before the age of 5.
  • The tumor can present with leukocoria (most commonest presentation), strabismus , or an absent red reflex on examination.
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a differentiated type of tumor characterized by columnar cells with a central lumen.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are tumors that arise from nerve sheath cells and are often associated with the genetic disorder neurofibromatosis. In plexiform neurofibroma S-shaped deformity of the lid is observed.

Option C - Retinopathy of prematurity: It may cause retinal detachment and leukocoria but there is no history of prematurity and low birth weight.

Option D - Toxcariasis: It is a parasitic infection caused by roundworm Toxocara canis that can be acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or food. It can present with leukocoria, strabismus, floaters, eosinophilia, and hypergammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of cylindrical lenses can be employed for the treatment of astigmatism in the with-the-rule orientation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • In with-the-rule (WTR) astigmatism, more refractive power (and curvature) along the vertical meridian than the horizontal.  A concave cylinder at 180 ± 20 degrees or a convex cylinder at 90 ± 20 is required for this kind of astigmatism. 
  • -3.00 DC x 180, +1.00 DC x 90 - This combination of lenses corrects with-the-rule astigmatism. The powers are reasonable for a typical correction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. +5.00 DC x 180, -3.00 DC x 90: This combination of lenses corrects against-the-rule astigmatism. It cannot be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

Option B.  +7.00 DC x 180, +5.00 DC x 90: This combination of lenses corrects against-the-rule astigmatism. It cannot be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

Option C. -4.00 DC x 180, -5.00 DC x 90: This combination of lenses corrects with-the-rule astigmatism. However, the powers are too high for a typical correction.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of uniocular diplopia in a young boy who has experienced trauma to his right eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Iridodialysis:

  • The most likely cause of uniocular diplopia (persistence of diplopia even when the normal eye is closed) in a young boy with trauma to the right eye is iridodialysis.
  • Iridodialysis refers to a separation or tearing of the iris from its ciliary attachment, which can cause the pupil to become distorted and result in double vision. 
  • Other causes of uniocular diplopia may include Subluxated clear lens or intraocular lens, incipient cataract, and keratoconus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These conditions causes binocular diplopia.

questions.text: For the purpose of preventing surgical site infection, what is the recommended technique and optimal timing for hair removal prior to surgery?

choices.text: On the OT table with electric hair clippers
With a razor 24 hours before surgery
With a hair removal cream on the previous day
On the OT table with a razor

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: On the OT table with electric hair clippers

  • The ideal time and method of removing hair before surgery to avoid surgical site infection are on the OT table with electric hair clippers. This method is preferred over the other options because it is considered to be the safest and most effective method for hair removal. 
  • Electric clippers are less likely to cause nicks, cuts, or skin irritation than a razor or hair removal cream. Moreover, electric clippers are designed to cut the hair close to the skin without causing any damage to the skin itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Removing hair with a razor 24 hours before surgery is not recommended because it can cause microscopic cuts on the skin, increasing the risk of infection. 

Option C: Hair removal creams can cause skin irritation, which can also increase the risk of infection.

Option D: Removing hair on the OT table with a razor is not a recommended method because it increases the risk of infection due to the fact that it is more difficult to maintain a sterile environment in the operating room when using a razor.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department after being involved in a car accident. The patient is experiencing difficulty breathing and their neck veins appear dilated. The x-ray reveals a significant amount of air on the left side. What is the most appropriate course of action for treatment?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space

questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • This scenario's next best management step is the wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space. This is indicative of a tension pneumothorax, which is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.
  • A tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space (between the lungs and the chest wall) and becomes trapped. As more air accumulates, it can cause a shift in the position of the mediastinum (the area in the chest between the lungs that contains the heart, great vessels, and other structures), leading to compression of the lungs and blood vessels. This can result in respiratory distress, hypoxemia (low oxygen levels in the blood), and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Treating of a tension pneumothorax involves relieving the pressure in the pleural space by inserting a needle or catheter into the chest cavity to allow the trapped air to escape. The insertion site is typically in the 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line (i.e., the space between the fifth and sixth ribs, in line with the middle of the collarbone). This procedure is known as needle decompression or thoracostomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Endotracheal intubation involves placing a tube through the mouth or nose into the trachea to provide mechanical ventilation and oxygenation. While this may be necessary in some cases of respiratory distress, it does not address the underlying problem of a tension pneumothorax.

Option C: Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that involves creating a small opening in the neck and inserting a tube directly into the trachea. This is typically done in upper airway obstruction or long-term mechanical ventilation cases. Again, this does not address the underlying problem of a tension pneumothorax.

Option D: Pericardiocentesis involves inserting a needle into the pericardial sac (the membrane surrounding the heart) to drain fluid or blood that may be compressing the heart. While this can be a life-saving procedure in cases of cardiac tamponade (heart compression due to fluid or blood in the pericardial sac), it is not indicated in a tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had acute appendicitis 3 days ago and presented to the surgery department with abdominal pain and tenderness. Which of the following incisions would be appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3:

  • The appropriate incision for acute appendicitis is McBurney's incision.
  • It is in right lower quadrant of the abdomen, approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the umbilicus. The incision is usually 4-5 cm long and is oriented obliquely with the upper end towards the ASIS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1: Kocher's incision is a subcoastal incision to gain access for gall bladder and biliary tree pathology.

Option B - 2: Midline incision -This type of incision is typically used for surgeries involving multiple organs or structures, such as bowel resections

Option D - 5: Lanz incision -It is typically used for surgeries involving the descending colon and rectum.

questions.text: Due to a prolonged period of consuming maize as a main food source, a 34-year-old man developed diarrhoea and exhibited lesions on his neck, as depicted in the accompanying image. This condition is caused by a deficiency in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Niacin

  • The above picture presented above suggests Vitamin B3/niacin deficiency according to clinical features. Pellagra disease is caused by the excessive consumption of a diet made up of maize. Maize/corn has low levels of tryptophan and niacin.
  • Niacin deficiency causes dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia.
  • The neck lesion shows characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, as seen in Pellagra. The Casal necklace or Casal collar is a clinical sign of pellagra that shows erythematous pigmented rash of skin near the collarbone region (dermatomes C3 and C4).  

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Zinc deficiency is found in people with severe diarrhea, liver cirrhosis, alcoholism causes   

Option C - Prolonged deficiency of Thiamine or Vitamin B1 in patients may support sensation loss at extreme level, heart failure symptoms along with hands or feet swelling, demand ischemia related chest pain, double vision, memory loss,    

Option D - Iron deficiency in the body causes anemia. Hence, red blood cells are unable to produce enough hemoglobin in the body that allows them to carry oxygen. Shortness of breath and tiredness are caused as a result of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worm sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Varicocele:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this presentation is Varicocele.

  • A varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum, similar to varicose veins that occur in the legs. It is a common cause of male infertility.

  • The typical presentation of a varicocele is an asymptomatic painless swelling of the scrotum, which may be described as a "bag of worms" sensation on palpation. The swelling is typically more prominent when the patient is standing and may decrease when the patient is lying down.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hydrocele: Hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis (the membrane that covers the testis) that leads to scrotal swelling. It is typically painless and feels like a smooth, round mass on palpation. Unlike varicocele, hydrocele is not typically associated with male infertility.

Option C - Testicular torsion: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord (the bundle of blood vessels and nerves that supports the testis) becomes twisted, cutting off the blood supply to the testis. If not treated promptly, this can lead to severe pain, swelling, and a high risk of testicular loss. Unlike varicocele, testicular torsion is typically associated with severe pain.

Option D - Epididymo Orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is an inflammation of the epididymis (a coiled tube located at the back of the testis that stores and carries sperm) and/or the testis. It is typically associated with pain, swelling, and tenderness of the scrotum, as well as fever and other signs of infection. Unlike varicocele, epididymo-orchitis is typically associated with pain and tenderness.

questions.text: The lab technician observes that a urine sample obtained from a 4-year-old male appeared normal initially, but underwent a change in color as depicted in the image after a few hours. Subsequently, the color intensified over the following hours. Which deficiency can potentially lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Homogentisic acid oxidase:

  • Homogentisic acid (HGA) is a metabolite that is used as the diagnostic substance in the tissues for alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disease that occurs rarely.
  • When Homogentisic-acid oxidase is found deficient in the tissue, then normal procedure of phenylalanine metabolism gets blocked and Homogentisic acid (HGA) becomes unable to break. Hence, urine appears as black and dark-stained nappies, and can be seen as the earliest signs of it.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Beta -carotene is a type of carotenoid that is present in carrots, apricots, and sweet potatoes. It is a provitamin and helps the body to make vitamin A. High doses of beta carotene might turn urine bright orange or yellow. 

Option B - Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency in children causes tyrosine to break incompletely. . Ocular manifestations- Painful corneal erosions and Cutaneous manifestation-: Palmar hyperkeratosis

Option C - Excess vitamin C can change urine colour into dark yellow or orange and vice-versa.

questions.text: Complex IV is inhibited by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Cyanide compound poisons electron transport chain in the mitochondria within the cells. It stops the body from deriving energy (ATP) from oxygen. Specifically, cyanide attaches with the a3 prosthetic group in the complex IV of cytochrome C oxidase (CCOx) and causes death of the cell rapidly. The generation of ATP is shutdown in the aerobic respiration that is recognized as cyanide toxic actions in the eukaryotes primarily.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Rotenone inhibits complex I (NADH CoQ1 reductase) of the respiratory chain and inhibits reduction of ubiquinone.

Option C: Like rotenone, carboxin prevents with ubiquinone reduction at the binding site.

Option D: Antimycin is one of the strong electron transport chains (ETC) inhibitors. It prevents electron transfer from cytochrome b to cytochrome c. Hence, Flow of electrons inhibits through complex III of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Which of the following CT findings is not an indication to perform angiography in a splenic trauma patient under conservative management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subcapsular hematoma covering 40% surface area:

  • Subcapsular hematoma covering 40% surface area alone is not an indication for performing angiography in a splenic trauma patient under conservative management. This is because, according to the AAST grading system provided, a subcapsular hematoma covering 40% of the surface area falls under Grade II, which is considered stable for conservative management.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Significant hemoperitoneum: Hemoperitoneum indicates bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, which can result from splenic trauma, among other causes.

Option C - Presence of pseudoaneurysm: In the context of splenic trauma, the presence of a pseudoaneurysm indicates ongoing arterial bleeding and is a potential indication for angiography.

Option D - Contrast extravasation: In the context of splenic trauma, the presence of contrast extravasation on CT imaging suggests ongoing arterial bleeding and is an indication for further evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes the characteristics of the Michaelis-Menten graph?

choices.text: Km is directly proportional to substrate concentration
Km doesn't vary with the enzyme concentration
Km is indirectly proportional to substrate concentration
Km has no relation to substrate concentration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Km doesn't vary with the enzyme concentration

The Michaelis-Menten equation describes how the rate of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction changes with substrate concentration:

v=Km​+[S]Vmax​[S]​

Where:

v = rate of reaction

Vmax​ = maximum rate

[S] = substrate concentration

Km​ = Michaelis constant — the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax​

 

Km is a constant for a given enzyme-substrate pair and does not depend on enzyme concentration.

 

Km is not directly or inversely proportional to substrate concentration (Option A and C): It represents the substrate concentration needed to reach half-maximal enzyme activity, but it is a fixed value, not a variable with [S]..

Km reflects the enzyme's affinity for the substrate:

  • Low Km = high affinity (enzyme reaches half Vmax at low [S])
  • High Km = low affinity


Km has no relation to substrate concentration (Option D): This is incorrect. While Km is not affected by [S], it describes the substrate concentration needed for half-maximal activity — so it is related, just not variable with it.

questions.text: By the action of the enzyme aromatase, testosterone is transformed into which of the subsequent hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Estradiol:

  • Aromatase enzyme is used in the process of androgen (such as testosterone) to estrogen (such as 17β-estradiol) conversion. Aromatase enzyme is used as a therapeutic target for the treatment process of endocrine-responsive breast cancer. Aromatase also converts androstenedione to estrone. 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - 5-hydroxy testosterone is a metabolite of testosterone, but it is not converted to this hormone by the aromatase enzyme. 5-hydroxy testosterone is produced by the action of the enzyme 5-alpha reductase on testosterone.
  • Option C - Cortisol is a steroid hormone that is produced in the adrenal gland, not in the testis where testosterone is produced. Cortisol is synthesized from cholesterol through a series of enzymatic reactions, but aromatase is not involved in its production.     
  • Option D - Cortisone is a steroid hormone that is closely related to cortisol, but it is not produced directly from testosterone. Cortisone is a metabolite of cortisol, and its production involves a series of enzymatic reactions that are different from those involved in the conversion of testosterone to estradiol.

questions.text: What is the optimal management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain five days after experiencing a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ERCP and stenting:

  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with stenting is the optimal management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain five days after experiencing a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak. 

    • ERCP: This procedure allows direct visualization of the bile ducts and enables interventions such as stent placement to address the bile duct injury. ERCP is a minimally invasive procedure performed by passing an endoscope through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the duodenum to access the bile ducts.

    • Stenting: Stents are inserted during ERCP to facilitate bile drainage and promote healing of the bile duct injury. They also help maintain the patency of the duct and prevent further complications such as bile leakage and bile peritonitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound-guided aspiration: While ultrasound-guided aspiration may be useful for draining a biloma (collection of bile outside the biliary system), it does not address the underlying bile duct injury. Therefore, it is not the definitive management approach for this condition.

Option C - Re-exploration and hepaticojejunostomy: Re-exploration and hepaticojejunostomy involve surgical intervention to repair the bile duct injury by creating a new connection between the bile duct and the jejunum. While this approach may be necessary in some cases, it is usually reserved for more complex or severe injuries. In the presented case, less invasive options such as ERCP with stenting are preferred before resorting to surgical intervention.

Option D - Re-exploration and primary repair: Similar to option C, re-exploration and primary repair involve surgical intervention to directly repair the bile duct injury. This approach may be considered if less invasive options fail or if the injury is severe. However, it is not the initial management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain after a common bile duct injury.

questions.text: A patient sustained a crush injury on their right arm. He was taken to the hospital and on examination, his arm was pulseless, swollen, and dark red. What would be the best way to manage this case?
questions.solution:
• The best way to manage a patient with a crush injury to the arm that presents with a pulseless, swollen, and dark red arm is fasciotomy.
  • A crush injury can result in a significant amount of tissue damage, which can lead to the development of compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome occurs when there is increased pressure within a muscle compartment, which can result in tissue damage, nerve injury, and even loss of limb function. In this case, the patient's pulseless, swollen, and dark red arm is likely indicative of compartment syndrome, which is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent irreversible tissue damage.
  • Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure that involves making an incision into the affected compartment to relieve pressure and improve blood flow to the affected tissues. It is the recommended treatment for compartment syndrome in cases where conservative measures, such as elevation and pain management, are ineffective.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option a: Intraosseous administration of fluids is a method of delivering fluids and medications directly into the bone marrow, bypassing the need for venous access. While this may be useful in certain situations, such as when venous access is difficult to obtain, it is not the appropriate treatment for compartment syndrome.
  • Option b: Acidification of urine may be used in the management of certain types of poisoning, such as aspirin overdose, but it is not indicated in the treatment of a crush injury.
  • Option d: Hemodialysis is a treatment for kidney failure and is not indicated in the treatment of a crush injury.

questions.text: In a fasting state, glucagon promotes the production of glucose by which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is a metabolic process in the body in which glucose is produced from a non-carbohydrate substrate of carbon.
  • Glycogenolysis is biochemical process in which glycogen is broken down into glucose and glucose-1-phosphate.
  • During the fasting state, glucose is produced from glycogen in the liver which is called glycogenolysis and also via gluconeogenesis from glycerol and oxaloacetate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis: Glycolysis is a chain of reactions that produce energy from glucose by breaking into two molecules of three carbon molecule compounds called pyruvates. Hence, this is incorrect.

Option C - Glycogenesis and gluconeogenesis: Glycogenesis is formation of glycogen from primary carbohydrate that is stored in the muscle, liver cells of animals from the glucose molecule. Hence, this is incorrect.

Option D - Only gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis are both pathways used in the production of glucose during the fast.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. An endoscopy was performed, an image of which is given below; what is the probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mallory Weiss Tear:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking who presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood is Mallory Weiss Tear.
  • Mallory Weiss Tear is a condition characterized by a tear between the esophagus and the stomach, known as the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It is commonly associated with alcoholism and binge drinking, as well as with excessive vomiting and retching.

Incorrect Options: 

Correct Option A - Tension pneumothorax: It typically presents with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia and is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.

Option B - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome, also known as Spontaneous Esophageal Perforation, typically occurs due to forceful or repeated vomiting, predominantly affecting males.

Option D - Gastric ulcer perforation: Gastric ulcer perforation is when an ulcer in the stomach lining erodes through the stomach wall, leading to a hole or perforation.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of massive, sudden onset hematemesis in a 50-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease and chronic alcoholism, who has arrived at the emergency department?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bleeding esophageal varices:

  • The most likely cause of massive, sudden onset hematemesis in a 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with a history of chronic liver disease is bleeding esophageal varices.
  • As the portal hypertension worsens, pressure in the veins surrounding the liver increases, leading to the formation of collaterals or new blood vessels. These collaterals are fragile and can rupture easily, leading to massive bleeding.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Mallory Weiss tear: Mallory Weiss tear refers to a tear in the mucous membrane at the junction of the esophagus and stomach, often caused by forceful vomiting or retching.

Option C - Boer-haave’s syndrome: Boer-haave’s syndrome refers to a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus, typically caused by forceful vomiting or retching.

Option D - Perforated ulcer: Perforated ulcer refers to a hole in the wall of the stomach or duodenum, typically caused by an ulcer.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in the management of a 30-year-old breastfeeding mother who is experiencing pain and fever in her left breast? The left breast appears abnormal as depicted in the provided image. There is slight swelling of the lymph nodes in the armpit on the affected side, while the opposite breast appears normal. Despite multiple attempts at draining the fluid with the use of antibiotics, it was unsuccessful. An ultrasound examination revealed the presence of fluid collection.
questions.solution:
Correct choice :

  • Option a :The clinical scenario described suggests that the patient may have developed a breast abscess. Breast abscesses are typically caused by bacterial infection and are more common in lactating women due to the increased risk of bacterial colonization of the breast ducts. The presence of fever, pain, and fluid collection seen on ultrasound are also consistent with a breast abscess.
  • Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover have been unsuccessful, suggesting that the abscess is not resolving with conservative management alone. Therefore, the next best step in the management of this patient would be incision and drainage of the abscess.
  • Incision and drainage is the most effective way to treat a breast abscess, as it allows for the complete removal of the infected material and helps to prevent recurrence. 

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option b: Broad-spectrum antibiotics may be used in conjunction with incision and drainage to treat the infection, but antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of a breast abscess.
  • Option c: Breast conservation surgery typically involves the removal of a breast lump or tumor. Thus, breast conservation surgery is not appropriate management option for a breast abscess.
  • Option d: Punch biopsy is a diagnostic procedure used to obtain a tissue sample for analysis.
  • Thus, punch biopsy is not appropriate management option for a breast abscess.

questions.text: What is the causative agent responsible for causing acne fulminans among the following options?
questions.solution:
• An abnormal immune response to the bacterium Propionibacterium acnes is thought to be the cause of the rare and severe form of acne known as acne fulminans. The exact cause of acne fulminans, on the other hand, is still poorly understood. Genetic predisposition, hormonal imbalances, and certain medications like isotretinoin are additional factors that could contribute to the onset of this condition.
  • The genus of bacteria known as Propionibacterium is commonly found on human skin, particularly in areas of the face, scalp, and upper back that produce a lot of oil. These Gram-positive bacteria are anaerobic or facultatively anaerobic and do not produce spores. Propionibacterium acnes is known to be engaged with the improvement of skin breakout, in spite of the fact that it is likewise a typical occupant of the skin microbiome and plays other helpful parts in the body. 

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Actinomyces: The bacteria of the genus Actinomyces are typically found in the gastrointestinal tract, throat, and mouth of humans and other animals. Gram-positive, anaerobic or microaerophilic, and filamentous, these bacteria produce long, branching structures that are known as filaments. Actinomyces species are essential members of the human body's normal microbiota and contribute to oral and digestive health.
  • Option c. Mobiluncus: The bacteria in the genus Mobiluncus are anaerobic, Gram-variable, and curved or comma-shaped, like shrimps. These bacteria are frequently found in the female genital tract and are linked to bacterial vaginosis (BV), a condition characterized by an overgrowth of certain bacteria in the vagina that can result in itching, odor, and discharge. Mobiluncus microorganisms are much of the time present in big numbers in females with BV, alongside different microscopic organisms, for example, Gardnerella vaginalis.
  • Option d. Bifidobacterium: Bifidobacterium is a variety of microscopic organisms that are normally tracked down in the human gastrointestinal parcel and different pieces of the body, like the mouth and vagina. These microorganisms are anaerobic, Gram-positive, and non-spore-framing, and they have a trademark Y-or Angular shape. Due to their crucial role in maintaining gut health and immunity, Bifidobacterium species are regarded as beneficial or "friendly" bacteria.

questions.text: In the case of a woman who has suffered third and fourth degree burns on her back, what would be the appropriate sequence of steps in her treatment?
questions.solution:
• Third-degree burns affect the full thickness of the skin and can cause damage to underlying tissue, while fourth-degree burns extend into the muscle, bone, or internal organs. Both types of burns require prompt and aggressive treatment to prevent complications such as infection, hypovolemia, and shock.
  • The most appropriate order of sequence in the management of a woman who has sustained third and fourth-degree burns on her back is as follows:
  • Resuscitation: The first step in the management of severe burns is resuscitation. This involves assessing and stabilizing the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Intravenous fluids and electrolytes are administered to prevent hypovolemia and maintain hemodynamic stability.
  • Debridement: Once the patient is stabilized, the next step is debridement. Debridement involves removing all necrotic tissue and debris from the wound to prevent infection and promote healing. Surgical or non-surgical methods can do debridement.
  • Allograft or autograft: After debridement, the wound is covered with either an allograft or autograft. Allografts are skin grafts taken from another person, while autografts are skin grafts taken from the patient's own body. Both types of grafts can provide temporary coverage to the wound and promote wound healing.
  • Therefore, the correct option would be Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option a. Resuscitation – reconstruction – debridement is incorrect because Ressuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.
  • Option c: Debridement – resuscitation – autograft is incorrect because Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.
  • Option d: Reconstruction is not an appropriate step in the initial management of third and fourth-degree burns, as the focus should be on stabilizing the patient and preventing complications. Reconstruction is typically done later in the treatment process once the wound has healed. Thus, Resuscitation – Debridement – Allograft or Autograft is the correct sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a type III choledochal cyst from the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C:

  • Choledochal cysts are rare congenital anomalies that involve dilation of the biliary tree. These cysts can occur anywhere along the biliary tree, from the intrahepatic bile ducts to the common bile duct. Based on the location and extent of the dilation, choledochal cysts are classified into five types.

  • Image C shows a Dilatation of the intraduodenal part of the bile duct (choledochocele); it represents a type III choledochal cyst. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A: Type II cyst is Diverticular dilatation of the extrahepatic bile duct.

Option B - B: Type I cyst is Cystic dilatation of extrahepatic bile duct (most common)

Option D - D: Type V cyst involves multiple dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: What is the appropriate preoperative fasting recommendation?

choices.text: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 2 hours for liquids in adults

  • A preoperative fasting period is a time prescribed before any procedure that involves general anesthesia, sedation, or regional anesthesia.
  • The collective fasting recommendation is two hours for clear and light liquids, four hours for breast milk, and six hours for solid foods, infant formula, light meals, and non-human milk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 4 hours for solids in adults

  • Eight hours of preoperative fasting is recommended for solid food in adults. 

Option C: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

  • Four hours of preoperative fasting is recommended for breast milk.

Option D: 4 hours for solids in infants

  • It is recommended 6 hours for solid foods in preoperative fasting before anesthesia. It should be kept in mind that cereal and baby food are solid foods.

questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia? 

1. Urgency 

2. Enuresis 

3. Hesitancy 

4. Frequency 

5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, 4:

  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland that occurs commonly in men as they age. BPH can cause a range of lower urinary tract symptoms, including both voiding and storage symptoms. Storage symptoms refer to the symptoms related to the bladder's storage capacity and include the following:

    • Urgency: A sudden and strong urge to urinate that may be difficult to suppress.

    • Enuresis: Involuntary leakage of urine that occurs during sleep.

    • Frequency: The need to urinate frequently, often more than 8 times a day.

    • Nocturia - is the complaint that the individual needs to wake at night at least once to void.

    • Urge incontinence (UI) is involuntary urinary leakage, often large volume, immediately preceded by the sensation of urgency. Urgency and episodes of urge incontinence are often associated with an overactive bladder or bladder neuropathy.

  • Voiding symptoms refer to the symptoms related to the emptying of bladder and include the following:

    • Hesitancy: Difficulty initiating urination, often characterized by a delay in the start of the urinary stream

    • Dribbling: A continued leakage of urine after the urinary stream has stopped.

    • Intermittency is the term used when the individual describes urine flow which stops and starts, on one or more occasions, during micturition.

    • Poor flow

    • Incomplete emptying is the sensation that at the end of micturition bladder fullness persists.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is option d, as it includes all the storage symptoms of BPH. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 1, 3, 4: Urgency, hesitancy, and frequency are incorrect.

Option B - 2 and 5: Enuresis and dribbling are incorrect.

Option C - 1, 2, 4, 5: All except dribbling is incorrect, as dribbling is not a storage symptom but a voiding symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following carries the lowest risk of developing invasive ductal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct choice :

  • Option 4 :Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) is the most common type of breast cancer, accounting for around 70-80% of all cases. It develops from the cells that line the milk ducts and can invade surrounding tissues.
  • Squamous metaplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by a change in the normal breast tissue cells to a squamous cell type. Squamous metaplasia is not considered a risk factor for developing breast cancer.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option a: Florid epithelial hyperplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by an overgrowth of cells in the ducts and lobules of the breast. While florid epithelial hyperplasia is not cancerous, it can be a risk factor for developing breast cancer.
  • Option b: Papilloma with fibrovascular core is a benign growth that develops in the ducts of the breast. It is usually small and does not cause any symptoms, but in some cases, it can cause nipple discharge. Like florid epithelial hyperplasia, a papilloma can be a risk factor for developing breast cancer.
  • Option c: atypical hyperplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by abnormal growth of cells in the ducts and lobules of the breast. Atypical hyperplasia is considered a high-risk lesion and is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

questions.text: In the operating theater, you observe the utilization of a particular vaporizer. Which of the listed gases would you anticipate it to comprise?
questions.solution:
Anesthesia vaporizers are employed to vaporize a liquid anesthetic agent so that a controlled amount of it can be delivered to the patient. Three types of vaporizers or concentration-calibrated vaporizers are available in the market such as variable bypass, electronically controlled vaporizers, and heated blenders. These instruments are used in the emergency departments, trauma departments, operating rooms, delivery rooms, ambulatory surgical centers and any needy areas that require inhalation agent administration. Some-times it is mounted on the anesthesia machines.
Heated-blender vaporizers are now only required for desflurane. It is marketed under the trade name “SupraneTM” by Baxter Pharmaceutical Products Division.  

Incorrect Choices:

b. Sevoflurane is a type of volatile anesthetic that can provide analgesia, hypnosis, autonomic blockade, akinesia, amnesia during the procedural and surgical interventions.

  • It is a commonly used volatile anesthetic agent that is used for outpatient anesthesia particularly across all age groups of peoples and in veterinary medicine.

c. Halothane is used as a general inhalation anesthetic. It reduces blood pressure and depresses respiration and decreases pulse rate. It is a man-made vaporizer.

d. Isoflurane is a general inhalation anesthetic for maintenance and induction. It reduces sensitivity of pains induced by altering tissue excitability.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman of age 30 who visits the dermatology outpatient department (OPD) with the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D Chloasma

  • A common skin condition that can occur during pregnancy is chloasma, also known as the "mask of pregnancy." The appearance of brownish or grayish patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, nose, forehead, and upper lip, is a hallmark of this condition. Chloasma is brought on by hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly an increase in estrogen and progesterone levels, both of which can encourage the skin to produce more melanin.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Systemic lupus erythematosus: Lupus, also known as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect a variety of body organs and tissues. It is characterized by the production of autoantibodies that damage and inflame the body's own tissues and cells. SLE is more common in ladies, and side effects can shift generally from one individual to another, contingent upon which organs and tissues are impacted.
  • Option b. Viral infection: The given image is not of viral infection
  • Option c. Rosacea: Rosacea is a long-term condition of the skin that mostly affects the face and causes redness, flushing, and blood vessels to show up. It can likewise cause pimple-like knocks and thickened skin on the cheeks, and brow. Rosacea typically affects fair-skinned adults over the age of 30 who have a family history of the condition.

questions.text: What diagnosis would you suggest for a 10-month-old male baby who presented with an empty scrotum, wherein ultrasonography showed the right testis located in the right inguinal canal and the left testis located in the perineum?

choices.text: Right side undescended testis and left sided ectopic testis
Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Right side undescended testis and left sided ectopic testis:

  • The 10-month-old male baby has been diagnosed with one undescended testis on the right side and one ectopic testis on the left side. An ectopic testis is when a testis deviates from its normal descent pathway and is found outside the scrotum.

  • During fetal development, testes typically descend from the abdomen into the scrotum through the inguinal canal. However, in some cases, one or both testes fail to complete this descent, a condition known as undescended testis or cryptorchidism.

  • In this baby's case, the right testis remains in the right inguinal canal, classified as undescended. The left testis not only fails to descend but also follows an abnormal pathway, ending up in the perineum, classified as ectopic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bilateral undescended testis: Bilateral undescended testis refers to the situation where both testes have failed to descend into the scrotum.

Option B - Bilateral ectopic testis: Bilateral ectopic testis refers to the situation where both testes have followed abnormal pathways and are located outside of the scrotum. 

Option D - Right side undescended testis and left sided ectopic testis: Right side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis would be an incorrect diagnosis for this baby since only one testis is undescended, and the other one is ectopic.

questions.text: Which of the following does not exhibit the Koebner's phenomenon?
questions.solution:
• The development of skin lesions in areas of trauma or injury is referred to as Koebner's phenomenon, also known as the isomorphic response. It is a typical finding in a few skin conditions, including psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo, and morphea.
  • Koebner's peculiarity isn't found in all skin conditions, nonetheless, and one condition in which it is commonly not noticed is rosacea.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Vitiligo: Vitiligo is an immune system sickness. When the immune system attacks melanocyte-containing cells in the body it results in vitiligo. These are pigment-making cells.
  • Option b. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a skin condition that typically manifests as a rash with itchy, scaly patches on the scalp, trunk, knees, and elbows. Psoriasis is a prevalent, chronic, and long-term condition that has no cure. 
  • Option c. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is a condition of the skin, hair, nails, mouth, and genitals. On the skin, lichen planus often appears as purple, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks.

questions.text: Identify the type of psoriasis in the given picture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Guttate psoriasis:

  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate psoriasis is characterized by skin lesions in the shape of small drops. These sores are generally under 1 centimeter in measurement and show up on the storage compartment, appendages, and scalp. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Erythrodermic:  Erythrodermic psoriasis is characterized by widespread skin scaling, inflammation, and redness, frequently accompanied by pain and itchiness.

Option C - Pustular: A form of psoriasis known as pustular psoriasis results in pus-filled blisters on plaques, which are scaly, flaky patches of skin.

Option D - Inverse:  Converse psoriasis. Presents with smooth, red, and inflamed patches of skin that may be itchy, painful, and susceptible to infection are its hallmarks.

questions.text: Which method is considered the most effective for evaluating the extent of muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Train-of-four:

  • The train-of-four (TOF) method is considered the gold standard for assessing the degree of muscle relaxation during anesthesia.
  • It involves stimulating a motor nerve at a high frequency and observing the resulting muscle twitch responses.
  • By comparing the amplitude of the fourth twitch to the first, anesthesiologists can accurately quantify neuromuscular blockade and tailor drug dosages to achieve optimal relaxation while minimizing the risk of residual paralysis..

 

Incorrect Options A, B, and D are not the most effective for evaluating the extent of muscle relaxation.

Option A: Tetanic stimulation:

  • Unlike tetanic stimulation, which induces sustained muscle contraction, TOF delivers a series of four brief stimuli, allowing for the assessment of fade in muscle twitch responses as neuromuscular blockade increases.

Option B: Double burst stimulation:

  • While double burst stimulation delivers two bursts of electrical impulses in rapid succession, TOF provides four individual stimuli, allowing for a more detailed assessment of fade in muscle twitch responses.

Option D: Electromyography:

  • EMG measures muscle electrical activity, which may be influenced by factors other than neuromuscular blockade, such as muscle fatigue or electrode placement.

questions.text: Which drug among the options provided would assist a chronic smoker in their aim to quit smoking?
questions.solution:
Option D - Both A and C:

  • Smoking cessation drugs can be an effective tool to help individuals quit smoking. The following drugs are approved by the FDA for smoking cessation:
    • Both bupropion and varenicline are approved by the FDA for smoking cessation and have been shown to be effective in helping individuals quit smoking. They can be used alone or in combination with nicotine replacement therapy.

Option A - Bupropion: Bupropion is an antidepressant that is also used as a smoking cessation aid. It works by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It is taken orally and is usually started 1-2 weeks before the quit date.

Option C - Varenicline: Varenicline is a prescription medication that is specifically designed to help individuals quit smoking. It works by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms and by blocking the effects of nicotine. It is taken orally and is usually started 1 week before the quit date.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mirtazapine: Mirtazapine is not approved by the FDA for smoking cessation and has not been shown to be effective in helping individuals quit smoking.

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is used to identify the condition depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Wood's light assessment is a symptomatic test utilized in dermatology to assist with recognizing different skin conditions, including contagious contaminations, bacterial diseases, and color problems like vitiligo. Dermatologists are able to observe subtle changes in the skin that might not be apparent under normal lighting conditions thanks to the use of ultraviolet light to highlight fluorescent substances in the skin.
  • The patient's skin is first cleansed, and any cosmetics or lotions are removed during a Wood's lamp examination. The dermatologist applies the UV light from Wood's lamp to the patient's skin in a room that is darkened. The fluorescent substances in the skin mirror the light, making the skin seem an alternate tone, it is inspected to rely upon the condition. For instance, fungal infections can have a yellow-green appearance, while pigment disorders can have a white or blue-green appearance.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Culture: Microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, and fungi can be identified and grown from a sample of tissue or bodily fluid with the help of a culture test in the laboratory. Cultures are frequently utilized in dermatology to diagnose fungal or bacterial skin infections like cellulitis, impetigo, or fungal skin infections.
  • Option c. Gram staining: A laboratory test known as "gram staining" is used to determine the kind of bacteria that is present in a sample of bodily fluid or tissue. In dermatology, it is frequently used to diagnose bacterial skin infections like folliculitis, cellulitis, and impetigo.
  • Option d. Patch test: A diagnostic test known as patch testing is used to pinpoint the substances or allergens that may be triggering allergic contact dermatitis. When the skin comes into contact with a substance that the immune system perceives as foreign and reacts against, this type of dermatitis is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: What does the inclusion of a split-thickness skin graft in wound closure on the thigh entail?

choices.text: Epidermis and variable part of the dermis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epidermis and variable part of the dermis: 

  • STSG (split-thickness skin graft) involves taking a graft that includes the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis.
  • This type of graft allows for a larger area of skin to be harvested compared to full-thickness grafts, which take the entire thickness of the skin.
  • Common donor sites for STSG include the inner aspect of the thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D: Refer to the explanation of correct option.

questions.text: What should be done after immediate defibrillation is performed on a young male patient who was brought to the emergency department unconscious after collapsing at a railway station, with no pulse felt and a monitor showing ventricular fibrillation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Resume chest compressions:
