  • Ventricular fibrillation (V-fib) is a dangerous heart rhythm condition that can cause cardiac arrest. Hence, it is necessary to stop V-fib immediately to restore pulse and blood pressure. The second focus should be on reducing the development of V-fib in the future.  
  • The treatment for ventricular fibrillation(V-fib) includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation, i.e., (CPR). Recent consensus guidelines for CPR advocate that chest compression immediately resumes after the defibrillation process.
  • Pulse checks and rhythm checks can be postponed until the completion of five compressions, minimally for two minutes. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Check for a pulse: The pulse check can be postponed for 2 minutes until the five-chest compression is completed.

Option C - Epinephrine 1 mg IV: Epinephrine, 1 mg, is recommended every 3-5 minutes once IV or IO access is established until the completion of five compressions.

Option D - Amiodarone 300 mg IV bolus: Amiodarone can be provided for ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation (VT/VF) cardiac arrest via intraosseous (IO)/intravenous (IV) infusion as a 300mg rapid bolus. A 150 mg IO/IV additional bolus is provided if VT persists.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of hyperkeratosis . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option b. Psoriasis is a persistent immune system skin jumble that is portrayed by the fast development and shedding of skin cells. As a result, thick, scaly skin patches are often reddish or pink in color and covered in silvery-white scales. Psoriasis can affect any part of the body, but the scalp, elbows, knees, lower back, and genitals are the most common locations

Incorrect choices:

Option a -Atopic dermatitis

  • A group of conditions known as neutrophilic dermatoses (NDs) are characterized by skin lesions for which a histological examination reveals a significant inflammatory infiltrate, primarily composed of neutrophils, without evidence of infection.Red, crusty, itchy, and flaky patches, resembling oval or circular patches on the skin, are typical manifestations of atopic dermatitis.
  • Option c. Pemphigus vulgaris is an uncommon immune system problem that influences the skin and mucous layers. Painful blisters and sores form on the skin as well as inside the mouth, nose, and genital area, indicating this condition.
  • Option d. Pemphigus foliaceus is a skin and mucous membrane-affecting autoimmune disease. The development of crusty, scaly lesions or blisters on the skin, particularly on the face, scalp, and chest, is a sign of this condition. An autoimmune reaction in which the immune system makes antibodies that attack the proteins that hold skin cells(desmoglein-1) together is what causes pemphigus foliaceus.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 39-year-old man who frequently washes his hands (15-20 times a day), leading to a negative impact on his work performance? He attributes this behavior to persistent thoughts that his hands are contaminated with dirt.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Obsessive compulsive disorder:

  • The most probable diagnosis in this case is obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). OCD is a mental health disorder characterized by repetitive, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors (compulsions) that are difficult to control and interfere with daily life.
  • In this case, the patient's repetitive hand washing behavior is a compulsive behavior that is likely driven by obsessive thoughts about contamination. This behavior is interfering with his workplace performance and is causing distress.
  • Therefore, the correct choice is a, obsessive-compulsive disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bipolar disorder: Bipolar disorder is a mental health disorder characterized by episodes of mania and depression. It is not typically associated with the specific symptoms described by the patient.

Option C - Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a mental health disorder characterized by a range of symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and disorganized behavior. It is not typically associated with the specific symptoms described by the patient.

Option D - Mania: Mania is a symptom of bipolar disorder and is characterized by elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, and other symptoms. It is not typically associated with the specific symptoms described by the patient.

questions.text: A known case of asthmatic bronchitis was reported to the hospital with breathlessness, palpitations, and oxygen saturation of 88%. The hospital does not have a ventilator. All the following can be given to the patient, except?

choices.text: Oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir:

  • Bronchial asthma is an inflammatory chronic disease condition of airways that is characterized by paroxysmal wheezing, cough, and chest tightness.
  • Asthma causes tightening of muscles around the airways and causes airways to narrow. Hence, when both acute bronchitis and asthma occur together, this situation is called asthmatic bronchitis. 
  • Currently, nasal cannula, non-breathing bag face mask reservoir, venturi masks, are used in the clinical settings as conventional oxygen therapies. However, non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in airways causes trauma, need for sedation, infections.
  • Conventional oxygen therapy (COT) involves a simple face mask that delivers oxygen.
  • COT is not able to provide sufficient respiratory support to the patients that are suffering from bronchial asthma. As it needs an extra attempt to breath and work for the breathing process to maintain oxygenation. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hydrocortisone: In case of bronchial asthma and hay fever, oral hydrocortisone is an effective therapy for symptomatic relief.

Option B - Theophylline: Theophylline is applied for the treatment of shortness of breath, wheezing, chest tightness caused by asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis and other lung diseases. Lungs passages are opened and relaxed to make breathing easier.  

Option D - Leukotriene antagonist: Chronic asthma/bronchial asthma is treated with Leukotriene-receptor antagonists such as Montelukast and Zafirlukast.

questions.text: What plasma protein is found in the highest concentration?
questions.solution:
• Albumin is present as the most abundant protein of plasma. It is manufactured by liver. Albumin molecules serve as binding proteins for the transport of steroid hormones and fatty acids. Lipids are hydrophobic in nature, so albumin helps their transport in the polar environment of plasma. 

Incorrect Choices:

  • a.    Bence-Jones proteins appear in the urine in many people that have multiple myeloma. Hence, it is not considered as the most abundant protein.
  • b.    Globulins are protein groups that are present in our blood and made in our liver by our immune system. It plays an important role in immune function, blood clotting, liver function etc. Various types of globulins are present in our body such as alpha, gamma globulins etc. It is considered as some of the abundant storage protein.
  • c.    Fibrinogen is considered the least abundant plasma protein in the blood.

questions.text: In a case presented in the outpatient department (OPD), a patient reported experiencing abdominal pain and diarrhea. Upon further examination, the patient exhibited symptoms of cutaneous flushing, extensive wheezing, and tricuspid insufficiency. Subsequent contrast enhanced MRI scans indicated the presence of endocardial fibrosis. As a result of this condition, which substance is likely to be excreted excessively by the patient?
questions.solution:
• Nowadays, carcinoid tumor incidence is rising. The major clinical symptoms include flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm as well as carcinoid heart disease. Expression of its amine or hormones is variable, so it makes diagnosis of disease late or erroneous. 5-Hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is considered as important biomarkers for the disease, while Chromogranin A(CgA), pancreatic polypeptide are also used as non-specific biomarkers for the disease.
  • Primary metabolic substrate of serotonin is 5-Hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Serotonin  gets broken into 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) within the liver.

Incorrect Choices:

  • a. Neuroblastoma are diagnosed by the presence of urinary vanillylmandelic acid and homo vanillic acid (HVA) as biomarkers. 
  • b.   Breast tumors are caused by imidazole-acetic acid and its derivatives. 
  • d. Dietary intake of choline in excess can cause risk of colon and rectum cancer.

questions.text: What is the substance that is most likely to be secreted by the hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hexokinase IV: 

  • A hexose phosphate is produced from hexose which is a six-carbon sugar with the help of a hexokinase enzyme. Glucose is present as the most important substrate for the hexokinases that further produce glucose-6-phosphate as the most important product.
  • Hexokinases I, II, and III are isozymes that have a “low-Km” value; hence, it has a high-affinity process for glucose, even at the low concentrations of it.
  • The hypothalamus releases Hexokinase IV likely.
  • HK IV or Glucokinase is also expressed in the pancreas and liver.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option A - Hexokinase I: HK1 is the most expressed isoform of hexokinase among the four hexokinases ubiquitously. It is expressed in many tissues majorly in the kidney, brain, and red blood cells (RBCs).
  • Option B - Hexokinase II enzyme is encoded by the HK2 gene present on chromosome 2 in humans. It is the most active isozyme of the hexokinase family. It is expressed in the insulin-sensitive tissues.
  • Option C - Hexokinase III is predominantly produced from myeloid cells. HKI and II are able to bind to mitochondria and protect cells against cell death. HKIII is not able to bind mitochondria. Very little is known about its cytoprotective effect.

questions.text: Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cardiac defects:

  • Lithium usage during pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of cardiac defects in the developing fetus.
  • Specifically, the use of lithium in the first trimester has been linked to an increased incidence of Ebstein's anomaly, a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is abnormally formed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Facial defects: Lithium usage during pregnancy is not commonly associated with facial defects in the developing fetus. Various factors can cause facial defects, but lithium is not typically implicated in this teratogenic effect.

Option C - CNS defects: While lithium has been associated with certain risks to the developing fetus, such as cardiac defects, it is not commonly linked to central nervous system (CNS) defects. CNS defects can result from genetic, environmental, and other medication-related factors, but the evidence does not suggest a strong association between lithium usage during pregnancy and CNS defects.

Option D - Urogenital defects: Urogenital defects involving the urinary and genital systems are not typically associated with lithium usage during pregnancy. Lithium's teratogenic effects primarily revolve around cardiac abnormalities rather than urogenital defects.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for a middle-aged man diagnosed with a rare variant of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, resulting in high anion gap metabolic acidosis?

choices.text: High protein and low carbohydrate intake
High carbohydrate and low fat intake
High fat and low carbohydrate intake

questions.solution:
Option C: High fat and low carbohydrate intake

  • This option is the most appropriate because it can help reduce the production of pyruvate, as fats can be converted into ketone bodies, which are an alternative fuel source for the body. A high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet can help mitigate the effects of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency and reduce the risk of metabolic acidosis.
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a neurodegenerative disorder that is associated with abnormal mitochondrial dysfunction. The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is located in the matrix of mitochondria. It acts as a catalyst in the oxidative decarboxylation process of pyruvate to acetyl CoA, which is an irreversible reaction.  Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a rare genetic, life-threatening mitochondrial disorder that is associated with lactic acidosis as well as neurological and neuromuscular degeneration. Developmental delay, lethargy, and hypotonia is usually present in the patients with Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency. 
  • As fat cannot be converted to glucose and low carbohydrate intake will also lead to less production of pyruvate . So, this is the best option.

Incorrect Choices:

  • a.    Lactic acid is built up in the body when pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is present and it causes neurological problems. Hence, high protein and low carbohydrate intake are not allowed in the case of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency. As protein is converted to glucose via gluconeogenesis process.
  •  b. High carbohydrate and low-fat intake is not recommended as it has carbohydrates that are unable to metabolize completely.
  • d. This option includes only carbohydrate intake, henceforth this cannot be recommended because glucose is unable to metabolize completely.

questions.text: In a patient who is tall, obese, known to have hypertension, and has recently been diagnosed with metabolic syndrome during a routine examination, which of the following findings are characteristic findings?

choices.text: Increase in uric acid and insulin
Raised blood pressure and normal insulin
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol
Raised blood sugar and low insulin

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol

  • Metabolic syndrome is a collection of conditions present in the body that occur combinedly. It increases the risk of stroke, heart disease and type-2 diabetes. The main components of metabolic syndrome include obesity, high blood pressure, high blood triglycerides, low levels of HDL cholesterol and insulin resistance. Increased physical activity and healthy eating are the keys to avoid problems related to metabolic syndrome. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Incorrect. Insulin resistance is a characteristic feature of metabolic syndrome, but high serum uric acid levels are not associated with it.

 Option B - Incorrect. Metabolic syndrome is associated with high blood pressure and insulin resistance.

Option D - Incorrect. While metabolic syndrome increases the risk of type-2 diabetes and insulin resistance, excess weight can contribute to insulin resistance, leading to elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who complains of a painless mass in her left breast that can be felt? The mass is highly movable, measures 3 x 3 cm, and has a rubbery texture.
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis, in this case, is fibroadenoma.
  • Fibroadenomas are benign (non-cancerous) breast tumors that are common in women between the ages of 20 and 40. They are made up of glandular and connective tissue and are often hormone-responsive, meaning they can change in size with hormonal fluctuations.
  • On examination, fibroadenomas typically present as a well-circumscribed, mobile, and painless mass in the breast. They are usually rubbery or firm in consistency and can vary in size.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option a: Breast abscesses, on the other hand, are typically associated with redness, warmth, and tenderness in the breast, as well as fever and other signs of infection.
  • Option b: Phyllodes tumors are another type of breast tumor that can be mistaken for a fibroadenoma, but they tend to be larger in size and have a more irregular shape.
  • Option d: : IDC often presents as a breast lump, which may feel hard or have an irregular shape, but it is typically not as mobile or well-circumscribed as a fibroadenoma. IDC may cause the nipple to become inverted or to produce discharge. Invasive ductal carcinoma is not typically associated with redness, warmth, or tenderness in the breast

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain.Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure. The pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option :

  • Option a: The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms, based on the provided information, is rest pain. 
  • Rest pain

  • It is continuous aching in calf or feet and toes or in the region even at rest depending on site of obstruction.

  • It is a ‘cry of dying nerves’ due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. It signifies severe decompensated ischemia.

  • Pain gets aggravated by elevation and is relieved in dependent position of the limb

  • Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure.

  • Rest pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option b: Sciatica is a condition that causes pain, numbness, or weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs due to compression or irritation of the sciatic nerve. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are inconsistent with sciatica.
  • Option c: Neurogenic claudication is another possible cause of the patient's symptoms, which occurs due to spinal stenosis or nerve root compression, causing pain, numbness, and weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of neurogenic claudication.
  • Option d: Venous claudication is caused by chronic venous insufficiency, leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the affected tissues. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of venous claudication.

questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Internal mammary artery:

  • The internal mammary artery is the vessel that provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).

  • Coronary artery bypass grafting is a surgical procedure that is used to improve blood flow to the heart muscle by bypassing blocked or narrowed coronary arteries. During the procedure, a healthy blood vessel from another part of the body is grafted onto the blocked or narrowed artery, creating a new route for blood to flow to the heart.

  • The internal mammary artery is located inside the chest, and it supplies blood to the chest wall and the heart muscle. It is an ideal vessel for CABG because it is resistant to the development of atherosclerosis (a buildup of plaque inside the artery), which can lead to re-narrowing or blockage of the grafted vessel over time.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Long saphenous vein: The long saphenous vein is often used in CABG procedures, may develop atherosclerosis and become blocked over time, leading to the need for repeat surgeries. 

Option C - Poly tetra fluoro eythlene (PTFE): PTFE is a synthetic material that can be used in CABG, but it may also develop atherosclerosis over time. 

Option D - Gastroepiploic artery: The gastroepiploic artery is another option, but it is not as commonly used as the internal mammary artery.

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate presents abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Among the following, which is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CECT abdomen:

  • The most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition in a 3-day-old neonate with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting is a CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography) abdomen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C - Barium swallow, Barium meal & Barium meal follow through:

  • Ingestion of a significant amount of barium, which can be harmful to a newborn's delicate digestive system.

questions.text: In your OPD, a young male patient with a paternal family history of bipolar disorder has presented with three episodes of mania. Considering the most effective treatment, which of the following mood stabilizers can be prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lithium:

  • Mood stabilizers are the primary class of medications used to treat bipolar disorder. They work to help stabilize mood and prevent episodes of mania or depression.
  • In this case, the patient has a family history of bipolar disorder and has already experienced three episodes of mania. Lithium is considered the most effective mood stabilizer for treating bipolar disorder, particularly for preventing future episodes of mania.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Valproate: Valproate is a mood stabilizer that can be used to treat bipolar disorder. However, it is typically more effective at preventing future episodes of depression than mania.

Option B - Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is a mood stabilizer that can be used to treat bipolar disorder. However, it is less effective at preventing manic episodes than lithium.

Option C - Olanzapine: Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic medication that can be used to treat bipolar disorder. It is effective in treating manic episodes but is not typically used as a first-line treatment for bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given radiograph of a newborn.:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imperforate anus:

  • The given radiograph of a newborn indicates the presence of an imperforate anus.
  • The radiograph shows the absence of a normal gas pattern in the rectum and sigmoid colon, which is indicative of an obstruction. This is further supported by the presence of a distended abdomen, which is a common symptom of an imperforate anus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meningocele: This condition is not visible on a radiograph of the abdomen.

Option C - Congenital megacolon: This condition can cause abdominal distension, but it does not involve the anus and would not show an absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

Option D - Pyloric stenosis: This condition can cause vomiting and dehydration, but it would not affect the anus and would not cause the absence of gas in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with psoriatic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture:

  • The image is showing a radiographic view of the male urethra, which is being filled with contrast material from a retrograde cystourethrogram. This is a diagnostic test used to evaluate the urethra, bladder, and sometimes the kidneys. During the test, a catheter is inserted into the urethra and contrast material is injected, followed by X-ray imaging.

  • The stricture is a narrowing of the urethral lumen, which can occur at any point along the urethra, from the bladder neck to the external urethral meatus. In this case, the stricture is located in the penile urethra, which is the portion of the urethra that runs through the penis. Thus the image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethral stricture: The stricture is not located in the membranous portion of the urethra, which is located between the prostate gland and the bulbous urethra.

Option C - Micturating cystourethrography with bulbar stricture: A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is a different type of test used to evaluate the bladder and urethra during urination. A bulbar stricture refers to a narrowing in the bulbar portion of the urethra, which is located between the bulbous urethra and the membranous urethra.

Option D - Micturating cystourethrography with psoriatic urethral stricture: Psoriasis is a skin condition and does not directly affect the urethra.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation to establish a diagnosis of GERD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 24 hours ambulatory pH monitoring:

  • 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring is the best investigation to establish a diagnosis of GERD.
  • It involves the insertion of a small probe through the nose into the esophagus to monitor acid levels in the esophagus over a 24-hour period.
  • This test can help to identify episodes of acid reflux and assess the severity of the condition.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Upper GI endoscopy: It can help to identify esophageal inflammation, ulcers, or other structural abnormalities that may be contributing to symptoms, but it may not always detect the presence of acid reflux.

Option C & D: CECT & MRI are of no use in GERD.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where a patient in the ward responds to the question "what is your name?" by repeating the same sentence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Echolalia: 

  • Echolalia is a language and speech disorder characterized by the involuntary repetition of words or phrases spoken by others. This can occur immediately after hearing the words or at a later time. Sometimes, the individual may repeat words or phrases they have heard on television or in their environment. In the given scenario, the patient is seen to repeat the question asked to him involuntarily. 

  • It is often associated with autism spectrum disorder, but can also occur in other neurological conditions such as dementia, schizophrenia, and traumatic brain injury.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Coprolalia: Coprolalia is a symptom of Tourette’s syndrome, where the person involuntarily utters socially inappropriate words or phrases.

Option B - Echopraxia: Echopraxia is a phenomenon where a person imitates the movements of another person without any apparent purpose.

Option C - Copropraxia: Copropraxia is a symptom of Tourette’s syndrome, where the person involuntarily makes obscene gestures or movements.

questions.text: A 42-year-old alcoholic and a chronic smoker presented with bouts of vomiting and stabbing pain in the epigastrium. He was binge drinking shortly before the symptoms started. He is febrile and tachycardic. The given findings were seen on bedside radiological imaging. Which among the following is a likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Peptic ulcer perforation:

  • The likely cause of the patient's symptoms and findings on the bedside radiological imaging is Peptic ulcer perforation.
  • Bedside radiological imaging may show the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, a classic finding in patients with a perforated peptic ulcer.
  • The patient's fever and tachycardia may be due to the systemic inflammatory response caused by peritonitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tension pneumothorax: Tension pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing compression of the lung and mediastinal shift. 

Option C - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome is a rare but life-threatening condition characterized by a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus, usually because of prolonged vomiting. 

Option D - Mallory Weiss tear: Mallory Weiss tear is a condition in which there is a tear in the mucosa at the junction of the esophagus and stomach, usually caused by excessive vomiting or retching.

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with a history of increased frequency of micturition. On cystoscopy, a pale ureteric orifice was seen. The patient’s KUB x-ray is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bladder tuberculosis:

  • The most probable diagnosis based on the given history, cystoscopic findings, and KUB x-ray is "Bladder tuberculosis."

  • Bladder tuberculosis is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that affects the urinary bladder.

  • The most common symptoms of bladder tuberculosis are increased frequency of micturition, dysuria, and hematuria. In advanced cases, patients may also experience suprapubic pain, urinary incontinence, and bladder dysfunction.

  • The pale ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy is a typical finding in patients with bladder tuberculosis, indicating that the mucosa around the orifice is inflamed and edematous. The KUB x-ray may show calcification in the bladder wall, which is a characteristic finding in bladder tuberculosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bladder carcinoma: Bladder carcinoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the epithelial cells lining the urinary bladder. It can also present with similar symptoms, such as hematuria and urinary frequency. However, the pale ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy is not a typical finding in these conditions.

Option B - Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis is a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma haematobium that can affect the urinary tract and cause bladder inflammation and fibrosis. It can also present with similar symptoms, such as hematuria and urinary frequency. However, the pale ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy is not a typical finding in these conditions.

Option D - Papilloma of urinary bladder: Papilloma of the urinary bladder is a benign tumor that arises from the urothelium lining the bladder. It can also present with similar symptoms, such as hematuria and urinary frequency. However, the pale ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy is not a typical finding in these conditions.

questions.text: The frontal sinus can be viewed by taking an X-ray at a specific angle, which is depicted in the image below. What is the name of the view depicted?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Caldwell's view:

  • The image depicts the head in a chin-down position, and the X-ray beam passing from behind the head at an angle of  15° to the radiographic plate. This description aligns with Caldwell's view, which is primarily used for assessing the frontal and ethmoidal sinuses as well as the nasal septum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Towne’s view:  In this view X-ray beam is passed from above in front at an angle of 30° to the radiographic plate. It is mainly used to visualize the petrous part of the temporal bone and the posterior part of sella turcica. It is used to assess any fracture to the floor of the cranium, acoustic neuroma, and apical petrositis

Option C - Law’s view: It is a lateral oblique view of the mastoid. The patient lies in such a way that the sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film, and the X-ray beam is projected 15°cephalocaudal. Structures seen are (a) External auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal. (b) Mastoid air cells. (c) Tegmen. (d) Lateral sinus plate. (e) Temporomandibular joint. “Key area” of the mastoid, i.e., attic, aditus, and antrum, is not well seen. 

Option D - Stenver’s view: This view is taken in such a way that the long axis of the petrous bone lies parallel to the film. Structures seen are: (a) Entire petrous pyramid. (b) Arcuate eminence. (c) Internal auditory meatus. (d) Labyrinth with its vestibule. (e) Cochlea. (f) Mastoid antrum

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses give the hematological picture as given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Saturnism:

  • Saturnism, also known as chronic lead poisoning, can cause a variety of hematological abnormalities, including anemia, basophilic stippling, and the presence of nucleated red blood cells (RBCs) in the peripheral blood.

  • In severe cases, lead poisoning can also lead to bone marrow suppression, which can result in pancytopenia.

  • However, it is important to note that the hematological picture of lead poisoning can vary depending on the level and duration of exposure, as well as individual factors such as age and nutritional status.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Minamata disease: While it is possible that mercury toxicity may lead to some degree of hematological abnormalities, such as anemia, the typical hematological picture of Minamata disease does not include specific features that would clearly distinguish it from other causes of anemia.

Option C - Chronic iron toxicity: Chronic iron toxicity can lead to a hematological picture of microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is characterized by small red blood cells that contain insufficient hemoglobin. While this is a specific hematological feature that can be seen in chronic iron toxicity, it is not unique to this condition and can also occur in other forms of anemia.

Option D - Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning can lead to a variety of hematological abnormalities, including anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The specific hematological picture may vary depending on the severity and duration of exposure. However, the presence of anemia alone is not specific enough to diagnose arsenic poisoning, as anemia can also occur in many other conditions.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presented with worsening hip and back pain. He also reports weight loss and loss of appetite. His PSA levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Option D - Prostate cancer: 

  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is prostate cancer. Prostate cancer typically presents with symptoms such as urinary frequency, urgency, and difficulty urinating. However, in advanced cases, it can cause hip and back pain, weight loss, and loss of appetite. 

  • Elevated levels of PSA (prostate-specific antigen) in the blood are also a common finding in prostate cancer. Therefore, given the presentation of worsening hip and back pain, weight loss, loss of appetite, and elevated PSA levels, prostate cancer is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Ankylosing spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the joints of the spine and the sacroiliac joint. It typically presents with back pain and stiffness, especially in the morning or after prolonged periods of inactivity. However, ankylosing spondylitis does not typically cause weight loss or elevated PSA levels, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option B - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects children and young adults. It can occur in any bone, but it most commonly affects the long bones of the arms and legs. Osteosarcoma typically presents with bone pain, swelling, and tenderness, but it is unlikely to cause weight loss or elevated PSA levels. Therefore, osteosarcoma is an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option C - Osteoclastoma: Osteoclastoma, also known as giant cell tumor of bone, is a rare type of bone tumor that typically affects the long bones of the arms and legs. It can cause bone pain, swelling, and tenderness, but it is unlikely to cause weight loss or elevated PSA levels. Therefore, osteoclastoma is an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common deficiency observed after gastric bypass /bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Iron:

  • Iron is the most common mineral deficiency seen after gastric bypass surgery. The stomach produces hydrochloric acid, which helps to break down food and release iron from it. After gastric bypass surgery, the amount of stomach acid produced is reduced, leading to decreased iron absorption. This can result in iron deficiency anemia, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Copper: Copper deficiency is also relatively common after bariatric surgery, particularly in people who have undergone malabsorptive procedures, but it is not the most common one..

Option C - Zinc: Zinc deficiency can occur after bariatric surgery, especially in people who have undergone malabsorptive procedures. Symptoms of zinc deficiency include hair loss, skin lesions, and impaired immune function.

Option D - Calcium: Calcium deficiency is less common than iron, copper, or zinc deficiency after bariatric surgery, but it can still occur.

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to 

1. Hypoglycemia 

2. Small volume of food intake 

3. High osmotic load of food 

4. Increased release of insulin 

5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1 and 4:

  • Response, causing a drop in blood glucose levels, resulting in symptoms such as dizziness, fatigue, and tremors.
  • (1) Hypoglycemia & (4) Increased release of insulin
    • Increased insulin release due to the rapid influx of glucose into the small intestine, leading to hypoglycemia.
    • This excessive insulin release exacerbates the drop in blood glucose levels, contributing to the symptoms experienced by the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D: Refer to the explanation of the correct option.

Incorrect Statements

  • (2) Small volume of food intake: Dumping syndrome is characterized by the rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, after consuming a regular or large meal.
  • (3) High osmotic load of food is incorrect because dumping syndrome does involve hyperosmolar contents being rapidly emptied into the jejunum.
  • (5) Increased release of glucagon is incorrect because dumping syndrome leads to an increased release of insulin, not glucagon.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass has filled the nasal cavity and eroded the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mucormycosis:

  • An elderly female diabetic patient with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge, a black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity, eroding the septum, and a hard palate is most likely suffering from mucormycosis.
  • A class of molds known as mucormycetes is the source of mucormycosis.
  • Mucormycosis is rapid growing disease involving the arteries and causing endothelial damage and thrombosis.
  • Immunocompromised people are more likely to develop mucormycosis, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspergillosis:

  • Aspergillus species can produce similar symptoms.
  • Rather than black necrotic mass fungal ball containing cheesy-white or blackish material is usually observed.

Option C - Foreign body:

  • Neither a black necrotic mass nor a foul-smelling discharge would be caused by a foreign body. 

Option D - Rhinosporidiosis:

  • Rhinosporidiosis is a very uncommon chronic illness brought on by Rhinosporidium seeberi, and it usually manifests as a painless, slowly expanding nasal polyp, which is inconsistent with the symptoms that are being reported.

questions.text: A young adult with gastric outlet obstruction presents with vomiting. Which of the following fluids is preferred in this patient for initial resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Normal saline:

  • Normal saline is an isotonic solution that is similar in composition to extracellular fluid. It is the preferred fluid in this condition as it helps to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance, does not affect gastric pH, and does not stimulate gastric secretions. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ringer lactate:  it contains lactate, which can increase gastric acid production and worsen vomiting.

Option C - 5% dextrose in water: 5% dextrose in water are hypertonic solution that can worsen fluid overload and hyponatremia in patients with gastric outlet obstruction. 

Option D - 20% dextrose in water: 20% dextrose in water are hypertonic solution that can worsen fluid overload and hyponatremia in patients with gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 23-year-old farm worker from a remote village was brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite at 5 in the morning. The patient complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness and vertigo and had multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and bradycardia (HR<50). The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the subsequent step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neostigmine with atropine:

  • The subsequent step of management for this patient with snakebite envenomation would be Neostigmine with Atropine.
  • The symptoms described suggest that the patient may be experiencing neurotoxic effects of the snake venom, which can cause respiratory depression, bradycardia, and other neurological symptoms.
  • Antivenom is an important component of snakebite treatment, but it may not reverse the neurological effects of the venom, which can persist even after neutralization of the venom's systemic effects.
  • Neostigmine with Atropine is a treatment option for such cases of neurotoxicity, as it can help to reverse neuromuscular paralysis caused by snake venom.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Check the blood coagulation profile: Checking the blood coagulation profile may be necessary in cases of snakebite envenomation caused by venom that can cause coagulopathy. However, in this case, there are no apparent bleeding manifestations described

Option C - Epinephrine injection: Epinephrine injection is not indicated for this patient because the symptoms described are not consistent with anaphylaxis, which is the primary indication for epinephrine administration.

Option D - I.V hydrocortisone: I.V hydrocortisone is not indicated for this patient because it is not effective in treating the neurotoxic effects of snake venom.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 60-year-old individual with diabetes who is experiencing intense ear pain and otorrhea that is not improving with antibiotics? During examination, the presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal and facial nerve paralysis was observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Malignant otitis externa:

  • Malignant otitis externa is the most likely diagnosis for a 60-year-old diabetic patient with acute ear discomfort, otorrhea that is not responding to treatments, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC), and facial nerve palsy.
  • A severe and sometimes fatal infection of the bones and soft tissue of the external auditory canal is known as malignant otitis externa. Symptoms include extreme discomfort, otorrhea, granulation tissue in the EAC, and cranial nerve involvement, which can result in facial nerve palsy. It is frequently observed in senior diabetic individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Otomycosis: Although otomycosis, a fungus that affects the ear canal, can cause itchiness, pain, and discharge, it is not frequently linked to facial nerve palsy.

Option B - Serous otitis media: The illness known as serous otitis media causes fluid to build up in the middle ear, which might result in hearing loss, although it doesn't often produce excruciating pain or otorrhea.

Option D - Eczematous otitis externa:  Eczematous otitis externa is an inflammation of the ear canal's skin that can result in itching, redness, and discharge, but it is not frequently linked to granulation tissue or facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate term to describe the behavior of a man who consistently derives sexual pleasure from causing physical harm to his partner, often resulting in cuts and burns on their arms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sadism:

  • The behavior described in the scenario is the core characteristic of sadism, which is a sexual disorder that involves gaining pleasure from the experience of inflicting pain, humiliation, or suffering on others.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of observing individuals who are naked or engaged in sexual activity without their knowledge or consent, for the purpose of sexual gratification.

Option B - Fetishism: Fetishism is a type of sexual disorder in which an individual is sexually aroused by non-human objects or specific body parts that are not typically considered sexually arousing, such as shoes, leather, or feet.

Option D - Masochism: Masochism is a sexual disorder in which an individual derives sexual pleasure from receiving pain or humiliation.

questions.text: What is the cause of the 40-year-old female patient's acute onset leg swelling and loose stools, considering her family members also have similar symptoms and mustard oil is a regular part of their diet?
questions.solution:
Sanguinarine 

  • Sanguinarine is derived from Argemone Mexicana oil which is mixed in mustard oil which may lead to epidemic dropsy.
  • MOA of Sanguinarine
    • It inhibits oxidation of pyruvic acid which leads to accumulation of pyruvic acid in the blood.
  • Clinical features of epidemic dropsy:

    • Sudden bilateral non inflammatory pitting edema.

    • Diarrhoea

    • Dyspnoea

    • Cardiac defects

    • Glaucoma, thereby leads to death.

Incorrect choices

Option a: Clavine alkaloids are a type of natural compound found in plants, fungi, and animals. They have a variety of effects on the body, depending on the compound and the dose.

  • Consumption of clavine alkaloids from contaminated grains, such as rye infected with the fungus Claviceps purpurea, can result in ergotism. Ergotism symptoms include vasoconstriction, gangrene, hallucinations, convulsions, and death.

Option c:  BOAA are toxic substances found in other plants, but they are not commonly associated with the symptoms described in this scenario.

Option d: Pyrrolizidine alkaloids: causes Endemic Ascites

  • Occur due to pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are derived from crotalaria plant (commonly used in MP & central parts in different food items)

questions.text: What is the classification of the head injury of a patient involved in a road traffic accident, based on a GCS score of 10?
questions.solution:
Answer option A

  • The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) scoring system is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury. It is a scale that ranges from 3 to 15, with lower scores indicating more severe injury and higher scores indicating a better level of consciousness.
  • In this case, the patient's GCS score is 10, which falls in the range of 9-12. According to the GCS scoring system, this indicates moderate traumatic brain injury.
  • The GCS scoring system classifies traumatic brain injury as follows:
  • Severe traumatic brain injury: GCS score of 8 or less
  • Moderate traumatic brain injury: GCS score of 9-12
  • Minor traumatic brain injury: GCS score of 13-15 with loss of consciousness
  • Mild traumatic brain injury: GCS score of 13-15 without loss of consciousness
  • Therefore, in this case, the patient's head injury is classified as moderate traumatic brain injury based on the GCS score of 10. This indicates that the patient has significant brain injury and may require close monitoring and treatment.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. Severe traumatic brain injury is incorrect because GCS score of the patient is 10.
  • Option c. Minor traumatic brain injury is incorrect because GCS score of the patient is 10.
  • Option d. Mild traumatic brain injury is incorrect because GCS score of the patient is 10.

questions.text: According to the amendment in the medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) Bill of 2020, until what gestational age is it permissible to induce MTP in mentally ill rape victims?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 24 weeks:

  • As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, the limit for termination of pregnancy in a mentally ill woman or a woman who is a survivor of rape has been increased from 20 weeks to 24 weeks of gestation. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 20 weeks: The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, t, has increased the gestational limit for termination of pregnancy in certain cases from 20 weeks to 24 weeks.

Option B - 22 weeks: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill, 2020, the gestational age limit for termination of pregnancy in cases of rape, incest, and vulnerable women, including mentally ill women, has been increased from 20 weeks to 24 weeks.

Option D - 28 weeks: Beyond 24 weeks, termination of pregnancy is only allowed in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities or if the continuation of the pregnancy poses a risk to the life of the mother.

questions.text: What could be the potential clinical diagnosis for a 35-year-old man who visited the clinic reporting intermittent dizziness, sensation of pressure and fullness in the ear, reduced hearing, and a low-frequency roaring sound in the ears?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -  Meniere’s disease:

  • The patient is likely suffering from Meniere’s disease, It is characterized by:
    • Spontaneous attacks of vertigo,
    • Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and
    • Tinnitus and Aural fullness
  • Diuretics to lessen fluid buildup in the inner ear, medicines to decrease vertigo and nausea, and in extreme cases, surgery to alleviate pressure in the inner ear are all possible treatments for Meniere's disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo: A common cause of vertigo known as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by transient episodes of vertigo brought on by changes in head position. BPPV is not often accompanied by hearing loss or tinnitus, unlike Meniere's illness.

Option C - Labyrinthitis: Inflammation of the inner ear called labyrinthitis can result in vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. The onset of symptoms, however, can be abrupt and is frequently accompanied by fever and earache.

Option D - Syncope: The symptoms mentioned in the scenario are not often linked to syncope, which is a sudden loss of consciousness or fainting.

questions.text: As an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic, you are handling the case of a patient who has chronic renal disease and needs hemodialysis. You provide dietary and fluid management recommendations and closely monitor the patient. Unfortunately, the patient decides to take ayurvedic supplements and occasionally disregards your instructions without informing you. Consequently, the patient's condition deteriorates, leading to respiratory distress. Subsequently, the patient's attendant files a legal complaint, accusing the doctor of negligence. Which of the following can serve as a defense for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contributory negligence

 

Explanation:

 

Contributory negligence is a valid legal defence in medical negligence cases. It applies when the patient (or their caregiver) fails to follow medical advice or engages in actions that contribute to their own harm, which reduces or nullifies the liability of the doctor.

In this case:

  • The doctor gave appropriate care and advice.

  • The patient disregarded medical instructions and used alternative (ayurvedic) therapies.

  • These actions directly contributed to the deterioration of the condition.

  • Indian courts recognize contributory negligence as a valid defense in medical negligence cases. If it is shown that the patient’s non-compliance or independent actions played a role in the adverse outcome, the doctor’s liability can be reduced or even negated

Thus, contributory negligence can protect the doctor from full liability.

 

Vicarious liability (Option A):

  • Refers to liability of an employer (e.g., hospital) for the actions of its employee.

  • Does not apply to a private consultant being sued personally.

Res Ipsa loquitur (Option B):

  • Means "the thing speaks for itself".

  • Used when negligence is obvious, e.g., leaving a surgical instrument inside the body.

  • In this case, the deterioration was not clearly due to the doctor's action.

Therapeutic misadventure (Option C):

  • Refers to an adverse event despite proper therapy, typically unavoidable or rare.

  • Not applicable here as the decline was due to non-compliance, not an unexpected drug reaction or intervention.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a primipara who is experiencing hearing impairment that has worsened during her pregnancy? The Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, while the Weber's test shows lateralization to the right side. The otoscopy reveals normal tympanic membranes, and audiometry indicates a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz.
questions.solution:
The patient appears to have conductive hearing loss in the right ear, according to the clinical findings. Bone conduction is preferable to air conduction, which is indicative of conductive hearing loss, according to the negative results of the Rinne test in both ears. 
Otosclerosis, a disorder in which there is abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that interferes with sound transmission, is the most likely reason for conductive hearing loss in a pregnant woman. The preferred method of treatment for otosclerosis is stapedotomy. A small hole is drilled or laser-cut into the footplate during stapedotomy to allow for the insertion of a prosthesis through the footplate.
Therefore, the correct treatment for the condition is stapedotomy.

Incorrect choices:

Option a: Sodium fluoride: While sodium fluoride may be used in some circumstances to slow the development of otosclerosis, it is not a guaranteed cure. In circumstances when otosclerosis has been diagnosed but the patient has not yet had hearing loss, sodium fluoride may be used to treat mild cases of the condition.

Option b: Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical treatment used to reconstruct the middle ear or repair a damaged eardrum. It might be necessary if there has been trauma or infection that has damaged the eardrum or middle ear.

Option c: Stapedectomy: Stapedectomy is a procedure by which the entire stapes footplate is removed which can cause more postoperative complications, thus stapedectomy is not preferred over stapedotomy.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical swallowtails. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lacerated wound:

  • The wound described in the scenario is most likely a lacerated wound due to its ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallowtails’.

  • Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs.

  • Lacerated wounds are typically caused by blunt force trauma and have an irregular shape with jagged margins. They can also be caused by tearing, such as in cases of dog bites or machinery accidents. Therefore, the wound should be documented as a lacerated wound.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Incised wound: An incised wound typically has clean and sharp margins and is caused by a sharp-edged instrument like a knife. The edges of an incised wound are not ragged, irregular, or uneven, and there are no tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound or "swallow tails."

Option B - Chopped wound: A chopped wound is a type of wound caused by a heavy, sharp-edged object, such as an axe or a machete. It typically has a clean, straight edge with minimal tissue damage. 

Option C - Stab wound: A stab wound typically has a narrow and deep wound track with straight or slightly curved margins, and a clean and smooth wound surface. It is caused by a pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or ice pick penetrating the skin and underlying tissues.

questions.text: For which of the subsequent conditions is Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) implemented?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Congenital external auditory atresia:

  • The use of Bone Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA) is frequently advised when a person has congenital external auditory atresia, a condition in which the external ear canal is absent at birth or is undeveloped. It works by bypassing the outer and middle ear and directly stimulating the cochlea . However, other conditions like sensorineural hearing loss, acoustic neuroma, or otitis media are not treated with BAHA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sensorineural hearing loss: Because the issue is unrelated to the external ear canal or middle ear, bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA) are not typically used to treat sensorineural hearing loss, a type of hearing loss that arises from damage to the inner ear or the auditory nerve.

Option B - Acoustic neuroma: The benign tumor known as an acoustic neuroma, which develops on the nerve that controls hearing and balance, is typically treated with surgery or radiation therapy rather than BAHA.

Option D - Otitis media: Otitis media is a frequent form of middle ear infection that is often treatable with antibiotics and other treatments, and it usually does not cause irreversible hearing loss. Otitis media is not routinely treated with BAHA.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Leading questions are not allowed:

  • Leading questions are not allowed is an incorrect statement regarding cross-examination in a court of law. In fact, leading questions are often used during cross-examination to elicit specific information or to challenge the witness's testimony, under section 143 IEA. Therefore, the statement "Leading questions are not allowed" does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Witness is examined by the defense lawyer: That statement applies during cross-examination in a court of law. The defense lawyer has the right to cross-examine the witness in order to test their credibility and the reliability of their testimony.

Option C - Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent: The objective of cross-examination is to challenge the credibility, accuracy, and completeness of the witness's testimony, and to weaken the case presented by the opposing party. The cross-examining lawyer aims to extract information that may undermine the witness's testimony or support their own case.

Option D - There is no time limit to cross examination: The specific time limits may vary depending on the jurisdiction and the specific rules of the court, but they are generally in place to ensure that the trial proceeds in an efficient and timely manner.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the signs and symptoms caused by hormones released from tumor tissue, which cannot be explained by the tumor's anatomical distribution?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Paraneoplastic syndrome:

  • Paraneoplastic syndrome refers to a group of signs and symptoms that occur because of hormones or other substances produced by tumor cells but are not related to the primary tumor's location or direct invasion of surrounding tissues. These symptoms may be the first indication of an underlying malignancy and may even precede the diagnosis of cancer.
  • Characteristics:
    • Paraneoplastic syndromes can affect various organ systems.
    • They often manifest as neurologic, endocrine, dermatologic, rheumatologic, or hematologic abnormalities.
    • These syndromes may precede the diagnosis of cancer, occur simultaneously, or follow the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Pretumor syndrome: Pretumor syndrome is not a recognized medical term, and there is no established definition or diagnostic criteria.

Option C - Para tumor syndrome: Para tumor syndrome is also not a recognized medical term and has no defined meaning.

Option D - Autocrine phenomenon: Autocrine phenomenon refers to the production and secretion of a hormone or other signaling molecule by a cell, which then acts on the same cell or nearby cells through specific receptors. This term is not specific to cancer and can occur in various physiological and pathological contexts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the next step in the management of an old patient who has undergone complete excision of glioblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Radiotherapy:

  • After complete excision of glioblastoma, the next step in management typically involves adjuvant therapy to target any residual tumor cells and prevent recurrence.

  • Radiotherapy, also known as radiation therapy, is a crucial component of adjuvant treatment for glioblastoma.

  • It helps to destroy any remaining cancer cells in the brain following surgery, reducing the risk of tumor recurrence and improving overall survival rates.

  • Therefore, radiotherapy is the appropriate next step in the management of an old patient who has undergone complete excision of glioblastoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chemotherapy with Bevacizumab:

  • While chemotherapy is an essential component of the treatment for glioblastoma, particularly in conjunction with radiotherapy, the use of Bevacizumab (Avastin) specifically is not typically the next step after complete excision of the tumor.

  • Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and is often used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma or as a second-line therapy.

  • It is not typically the first choice for adjuvant treatment immediately following surgical excision.

Option B - No further management:

  • This option is incorrect because after surgical excision of glioblastoma, adjuvant treatment is essential to target any remaining cancer cells and prevent recurrence.

  • Without further management, there is a high risk of tumor recurrence, which can lead to worsening symptoms and reduced survival rates.

  • Therefore, no further management is not an appropriate option in this scenario.

Option C - Chemoradiation:

  • While chemoradiation (combining chemotherapy and radiotherapy) is a common treatment approach for glioblastoma, it is typically used as initial treatment or as adjuvant therapy following partial surgical resection.

  • Complete excision of the tumor reduces the need for immediate chemoradiation as the primary treatment modality.

  • Therefore, opting for chemoradiation immediately after complete excision may expose the patient to unnecessary side effects without clear benefit.

questions.text: Which test is employed to distinguish human blood from blood of other species among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Precipitin test:

  • The precipitin test is used to differentiate human blood from the blood of other species.

  • This test is based on the principle that antibodies in serum will react with and precipitate their corresponding antigens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Teichman test: This test is used to detect the presence of hemoglobin in a blood stain.

Option C - Barberio test: This test is used to detect seminal stains.

Option D - Takayama test: This test is used to detect the presence of blood in a forensic sample,

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and right ear pain. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. Moreover, decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma:

  • The given symptoms are consistent with Trotter's Triad, which is associated with malignant nasopharyngeal carcinoma invading the lateral wall.
  • Trotter's Triad:
    • Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube ·
    • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to Vth nerve involvement.
    • Palatal paralysis (10 nerve involvement)
    • It is diagnostic of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Adenoid cystic cancer: Typically, adenoid cystic cancer develops in the salivary glands without showing any symptoms like conductive hearing loss or restricted soft palate movement.

Option C - Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Adolescent males are typically affected by juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a rare non-cancerous tumor that seldom results in symptoms like conductive hearing loss or restricted soft palate mobility.

Option D - Quinsy: Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, is a complication of tonsillitis that results in a severe sore throat, fever, and trouble swallowing but does not frequently cause symptoms like conductive hearing loss or constrained soft palate movement.

questions.text: In the context of biomedical waste disposal, which type of waste is discarded in a yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Blood bag

  • The yellow bag is used to dispose of infectious or pathological waste, including blood-soaked items such as blood bags, blood-stained bandages, and cotton swabs. Blood bags contain blood and blood components, which may pose a significant risk of infection if not disposed of correctly.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option b: Gloves - Gloves are non-infectious waste and are disposed of in a Red bag. Solid contaminated recyclable waste.
  • Option c: Sharps - Disposed in White box. Sharps are disposed of in a puncture-resistant container labeled with the biohazard symbol.
  • Option d: Urine bag - Urine bags contain human waste, and is disposed of in a red bag.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with a true bruise?

choices.text: Progression of the color of bruise over time

questions.solution:
Option D. Presence of vesicles:

  • Itching is not typically associated with true bruises. This symptom is more characteristic of artificial bruises caused by substances that irritate the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Negative chemical tests:

  • True bruises usually test negative for the presence of certain chemicals that might be used to create artificial bruises. This is consistent with the definition of a true bruise, which results from the extravasation of blood due to blunt force trauma, not chemical irritation .

Option B. Progression of the color of bruise over time:

  • One of the hallmark characteristics of true bruises is the progression of color changes over time due to the breakdown of hemoglobin in the tissue. This progression typically goes from red or purple to blue, green, yellow, and finally fading away .

.Option C. Irregular margins:

  • True bruises often have irregular, diffuse margins due to the spread of blood within the tissues. This is in contrast to artificial bruises, which typically have well-defined, regular margins due to the application method of the irritant substance .

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency room. On examination, his PR is 50 bpm, BP is 80/60 mmHg, RR is 7 breaths/min and his temperature is 95° F. He has a pinpoint pupil and is disoriented. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Opioid intoxication:

  • Opioid intoxication is characterized by respiratory depression, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Benzodiazepine overdose: Benzodiazepines are central nervous system depressants that can cause respiratory depression, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. However, benzodiazepine overdose is less likely to cause bradycardia and pinpoint pupils. The patient's presentation is more consistent with opioid intoxication.

Option B - Cocaine intoxication: Cocaine is a stimulant drug that can cause tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, and agitation. The patient's presentation is inconsistent with cocaine intoxication. Cocaine use is more likely to cause hyperthermia, tachycardia, and dilated pupils, rather than hypothermia, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils.

Option C - Opioid withdrawal: Opioid withdrawal is characterized by symptoms such as sweating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dilated pupils, and agitation. The patient's presentation is inconsistent with opioid withdrawal. Opioid withdrawal is more likely to cause tachycardia, rather than bradycardia, and elevated respiratory rate, rather than decreased respiratory rate.

questions.text: Which fungal infection is frequently observed in the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aspergillosis: 

  • Aspergillosis is the most common fungal infection of the maxillary sinus, caused by Aspergillus fumigatus. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blastomycosis:  It is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. In immunocompetent, it primarily causes pulmonary infections and skin lesions, and in immunocompromised, it causes CNS infections. 

Option C - Candidiasis: It mainly causes opportunistic infections, with diabetes mellitus being the most common predisposing factor. It is often implicated in cutaneous, mucosal, intestinal, bronchopulmonary, and systemic infections.

Option D - Histoplasmosis: Histoplasma capsulatum is a species of fungus that causes histoplasmosis.  It is primarily a pulmonary infection but can also cause cutaneous and disseminated disease. It can cause infection in both immunocompetent and compromised patients. Histoplasma-causing sinusitis is uncommon.

questions.text: Which of the following options can be employed for the treatment of Kesari dal toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C: 

  • Kesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) is a legume that is widely consumed in India and other countries. When consumed in large quantities over time, the dal contains a neurotoxin called beta-N-oxalyl-L-alpha-beta diaminopropionic acid (BOAA), which can cause a neurological disorder called lathyrism.
  • Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a role in lathyrism due to its potential protective effects against the toxic effects of β-ODAP. β-ODAP is known to induce oxidative stress and damage to neurons. Vitamin C is an antioxidant that can counteract oxidative stress by neutralizing harmful free radicals and protecting cells from damage.

Incorrect choices

  • Option a: Some evidence suggests that sodium bicarbonate may exacerbate the effects of Kesari dal toxicity. This is due to the fact that bicarbonate can increase ODAP absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and thus increase its toxicity. As a result, using sodium bicarbonate to treat Kesari dal toxicity is generally not advised.
  • Option b: There is no evidence that vitamin A has any effect on Kesari dal toxicity or Lathyrism. However, adequate vitamin A intake is required for healthy vision, immune system function, and cell growth and differentiation.
  • Option d: Kesari Dal toxicity is not treated with IV immunoglobulin because it is not a viral or immune-mediated condition. It is most commonly used to treat autoimmune and immune-mediated disorders, as well as some cases of primary immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is not recommended for a 4-year-old boy presenting with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days? The examination shows a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. The chest x-ray reveals subglottic narrowing resembling a steeple.
questions.solution:
Option B. Parenteral cefotaxime:

  • Indication: Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections.
  • Mechanism: It is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic effective against a broad spectrum of bacteria.
  • Recommendation: Not recommended for croup, which is typically caused by a viral infection. Antibiotics like cefotaxime are not effective against viruses and therefore are not used in the treatment of viral croup unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, which is not indicated in this case.

Other Options

Option A. Nebulized racemic epinephrine:

  • Indication: Used for moderate to severe croup to reduce airway swelling and relieve symptoms of stridor.
  • Mechanism: Acts as a vasoconstrictor to reduce edema in the subglottic space.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate for the treatment of croup.

Option C. Helium oxygen mixture (Heliox):

  • Indication: Used in severe cases of upper airway obstruction to improve airflow and reduce the work of breathing.
  • Mechanism: Heliox is a mixture of helium and oxygen that is less dense than air, allowing it to flow more easily through narrowed airways.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate as an adjunctive treatment in severe cases of croup to reduce respiratory distress.

OptionD. Intramuscular dexamethasone:

  • Indication: Used to reduce inflammation and edema in the airway.
  • Mechanism: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that decreases inflammation and swelling in the subglottic area.
  • Recommendation: Appropriate for the treatment of croup. It has been shown to reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.

questions.text: What would be the next step in managing the symptoms of a 7-year-old child who underwent a tonsillectomy and now presents with snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing, a slight hearing loss, a high arched palate, and a decline in school performance, causing concern to the mother?
questions.solution:
The next course of treatment for this youngster would be an adenoidectomy with grommet insertion based on the symptoms and examination results. Snoring, mouth breathing, and a minor loss of hearing in the children are indications that the upper airway may be blocked, possibly as a result of swollen adenoids. The child's breathing would be made better by an adenoidectomy by removing the adenoids. Grommets would facilitate greater middle ear fluid outflow, enhancing the child's hearing. Adenoidectomy and grommet insertion may help the child's symptoms, which may also be caused by the child's high-arched palate.

Incorrect choices:

Option a: Adenoidectomy: In some instances where swollen adenoids are the cause of upper airway obstruction, adenoidectomy alone may be adequate. However, the child in this instance also has a high arched palate and a slight hearing loss, which indicates that there may be additional factors causing his symptoms.

Option b: Myringoplasty: A surgical treatment called myringoplasty can be used to seal an eardrum hole. However, in this instance, the child's primary symptoms are obstruction of the upper airway. Myringoplasty is not a suitable course of treatment for this reason.

Option d: Conservative management: For some cases of upper airway blockage brought on by enlarged adenoids, conservative care, such as observation and symptomatic treatment, may be suitable. The child's symptoms are, however, impacting his academic performance in this instance, and consequences could arise if the obstruction is not removed. The child's symptoms may not be sufficiently addressed and his quality of life may not be improved by conservative management, for this reason.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification occurs in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Atheroma:

  • The type of calcification seen in atheroma is dystrophic calcification.
  • Metastatic calcification:
    • Metastatic calcification is caused by increased calcium phosphate in the blood and may result from hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, or both.
    • It is commonly associated with hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, metastatic disease, and myeloma.
  • Dystrophic calcification:
    • The deposition of calcium salt in degenerated tissues in the absence of a systemic imbalance is called dystrophic calcification.
    • It is mostly associated with trauma, inflammation, or infection.

​​​​​​​Incorrect Options:

  • Metastatic calcification occurs in options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Birth Rate Falls below Death Rate:

  • In the fifth stage of the demographic cycle, birth rates decrease below death rates, leading to population decline.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Birth Rate Remains Unchanged: Birth rates remaining unchanged is not characteristic of this stage.

Option B - Death Rate Increases: Increased death rates are not expected in this stage.

Option C - Demographic Gap is Positive: The demographic gap doesn't describe birth rates falling below death rates, which is characteristic of this stage.

questions.text: You see a child with delayed speech development as part of a health visit at a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serous otitis media:

  • Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for this case would be Serous otitis media. Serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion, is characterized by the presence of non-infected fluid in the middle ear. It can cause conductive hearing loss, leading to speech and language delays, especially in children. A hearing loss of 20 dB fits the profile of serous otitis media.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute suppurative otitis media: Acute suppurative otitis media typically presents with symptoms such as ear pain, fever, and drainage of pus from the ear. It is an acute infection of the middle ear.

Option C - Chronic suppurative otitis media: Chronic suppurative otitis media is characterized by recurrent or persistent ear discharge through a perforated tympanic membrane. It involves ongoing infection of the middle ear space.

Option D - Glomus tumor: Glomus tumors, also known as paragangliomas, are rare neoplasms arising from the glomus cells. They can occur in the middle ear and may cause hearing loss, but they usually present with pulsatile tinnitus and are not a common cause of speech delay in children.

questions.text: What is the method used to assess the relative risk (RR)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cohort Study:

  • Measure of association strength between incidence in exposed and non-exposed called relative risk (RR).
