  • Track group with shared exposure or risk factor over time, comparing outcome incidence.
  • Typically used in cohort studies to estimate relative risk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Case-Control Study: Compares cases and controls to identify potential risk factors, using odds ratio.

Option C - Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): Assigns participants randomly to intervention groups to assess treatment effectiveness.

Option D - Cross-Sectional Study: Gathers data on exposure and outcome at a single point in time.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the staff of an urban primary health center?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5 Multiskilled staff nurse :

  • The statement is not correct about the staff of the Urban Primary Health Center (UPHC). 
  • There are 2 Multiskilled staff nurse in UPHC.

Incorrect Options :

  • Option a: 2 doctors In UPHC is correct statement.
  • Option c: 1 lab technician  In UPHC is correct statement.
  • Option d: 1 pharmacist  In UPHC is correct statement.

questions.text: According to the NACO guidelines, what level of prevention is achieved when an HIV patient undergoes counselling and screening for TB at an ICTC clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Primary and Secondary:

  • NACO guidelines recommend both primary and secondary prevention measures for TB screening at ICTC clinics for HIV patients.
    • Primary prevention involves counseling to address risk factors.
    • Secondary prevention entails screening for early diagnosis and treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primordial: Not applicable.

Option B - Primary prevention: Incomplete; counseling also serves as secondary prevention.

Option C - Secondary prevention: Incomplete; screening also serves as primary prevention.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate measure of central tendency when there is a diverse range of values within a community?
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - Median:

  • The median serves as the most accurate indicator of central tendency in groups where values span a wide spectrum.
  • A data set's median is the value in the middle, with half of the values being greater than the median and the other half being less than the median. Extreme values or outliers, which have a significant impact on the mean, have no effect on the median.

Incorrect Options

  • Option A: Extreme values or outliers in the data set have an impact on the mean because they can significantly deviate the mean value from the majority of the data. 
  • Option B: Another way to measure central tendency is by using the mode, but this method is not appropriate for continuous data or data with a wide range of values. 
  • Option D: The standard deviation is not a measure of central tendency; rather, it is a measure of variability or spread in the data.

questions.text: What does the provided population pyramid indicate, with the exception of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Developed Countries:

  • Developed countries show more even age distributions with smaller bases, reflecting lower birth rates and higher life expectancy. Sex ratio graphs often display symmetry.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Developing Countries: Developing countries have broad-based pyramids, indicating high birth rates and lower life expectancy, often with asymmetrical sex ratios.

Option C - Increasing Population: Developing countries exhibit increasing population trends with wide bases and narrow tops due to high birth rates and improved healthcare, often with asymmetrical sex ratios.

Option D - More Young Population: Developing countries typically have younger populations with wide bases and narrow tops, reflecting high birth rates and fewer elderly individuals, often with asymmetrical sex ratios.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T cells:

  • When a graft is transplanted into a recipient, the immune system recognizes the graft as foreign and triggers an immune response.
  • This response is primarily mediated by T cells, which can recognize and respond to specific foreign antigens.
  • The T cells recognize and bind to the foreign antigens expressed by the graft.
  • This triggers the activation of other immune cells, such as macrophages, which can help to engulf and destroy the foreign tissue.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the term commonly used to describe a mode of communication wherein 4-8 speakers engage in a discussion on a specific topic in front of a large audience, without following a specific agenda, predetermined speeches, or a set order of speaking, and eventually interact with the audience?
questions.solution:
• A panel discussion is a type of communication where a group of experts or professionals share their views on a given topic or problem in front of a sizable audience, without a set agenda, speech, or order of speaking, and with audience interaction at the conclusion.

Incorrect choices

  • Option b: Symposium - A symposium is an expert-led series of presentations on a particular subject or theme, usually more formal and structured than a panel discussion.
  • Option c: Workshop - A workshop is a practical educational experience where participants learn new skills or techniques. series of more than 4 meetings.
  • Option d: Seminar - A seminar is a lecture-style presentation where a speaker provides information on a particular subject, and the audience is then given the opportunity to ask questions or participate in a discussion. It may have a set agenda or speech.

questions.text: What is the increase in resistance of an artery if its radius is reduced to one-third?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 81 times:

  • According to the Hagen–Poiseuille equation, resistance can be directly measured by the following formula.
  • R = 8ηL/pr4
  • Where,
    • R = resistance.
    • η = viscosity.
    • L = length.
    • r = radius of the vessel.
  • From this equation, the resistance of a vessel is inversely proportional to its r4 (radius). If other parameters remain constant.
  • So, if the radius is reduced by 1/3rd of the original, then resistance will be:
    • R = 1/ (1/3)4.
    • R = 81.
  • So, the resistance will increase by 81 times.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A boy was diagnosed with a medical condition that is believed to have been passed down from his grandmother to his father, and now to him. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Autosomal Dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when the gene responsible for the condition is located on one of the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes), typically on one of the numbered chromosomes.
  • In this pattern of inheritance, a single copy of the gene is sufficient to express the trait.
  • If the boy inherited the condition from his grandmother and his father, it indicates that the gene is on one of the autosomes and is dominant.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by

choices.text: ↓ Permeability of glucose across cell membrane
↑ Reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A

  • Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that plays a critical role in regulating glucose metabolism. Insulin acts on the cell membrane of target cells, such as muscle, liver, and adipose tissue, to facilitate glucose uptake and utilization.
  • Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by increasing the number of glucose transporters, such as GLUT4, on the cell surface of target cells. This leads to an increased uptake of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Therefore, option a is the correct choice.

Incorrect Choices

  • Option b. ↓permeability of glucose across the cell membrane: Insulin does not decrease the permeability of glucose across the cell membrane. Instead, it increases the number of glucose transporters on the cell surface, which leads to an increased uptake of glucose into the cells.
  • Option c. ↑reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules: Insulin does not increase the reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules. Instead, it acts on target cells, such as muscle, liver, and adipose tissue, to facilitate glucose uptake and utilization.
  • Option d. ↑glucose reabsorption from intestine: Insulin does not increase glucose reabsorption from the intestine. Instead, it acts on target cells to facilitate glucose uptake and utilization.

questions.text: What type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor is responsible for recurrent episodes of secretory diarrhea?
questions.solution:
• VIPoma is a rare type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), a hormone that regulates various physiological processes in the body, including intestinal motility and secretion. VIPoma is also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, and Achlorhydria).
  • The excessive production of VIP by the tumor leads to recurrent episodes of secretory diarrhea, which can be severe and debilitating. Diarrhea is typically watery and voluminous, and it may be associated with abdominal cramping, nausea, and vomiting. 

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. Glucagonoma: Glucagonoma is a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces glucagon, a hormone that regulates glucose metabolism. Glucagonoma is associated with a characteristic rash called necrolytic migratory erythema, as well as diabetes mellitus, weight loss, and anemia. Glucagonoma does not typically cause secretory diarrhea.
  • Option c. Insulinoma: Insulinoma is a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that produces insulin, a hormone that regulates glucose metabolism. Insulinoma is associated with hypoglycemia, which can cause symptoms such as confusion, weakness, and sweating. Insulinoma does not typically cause secretory diarrhea.
  • Optiond. Zollinger Ellison disease: Zollinger Ellison disease is a condition caused by a gastrin-secreting tumor, typically located in the pancreas or duodenum. The excessive production of gastrin leads to hypersecretion of gastric acid, which can cause peptic ulcers and other gastrointestinal symptoms. Zollinger Ellison disease does not typically cause secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is macrocytic anemia seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Liver disease:

  • There are several potential pathological mechanisms of macrocytic anemia associated with liver disease.
  • First, patients with liver disease are more likely to have vitamin B12 or folate deficiencies, which directly result in macrocytic anemia.
  • Vitamin B12 and folate coenzymes are required for thymidylate and purine synthesis; thus, their deficiencies result in retarded DNA synthesis and eventually will develop into macrocytic anemia.
  • Second, macrocytic anemia in liver disease may be due to an increased deposition of cholesterol on the membranes of circulating RBCs.
  • This deposition effectively increases the surface area of the erythrocyte.

Incorrect Options:

  • In options A, B, and C, macrocytic anemia is not seen.

questions.text: On ocular examination, a teenage girl with low body weight is observed to have the following finding. Which WHO grade corresponds to this finding?
questions.solution:
Option B - 1B

  • The ocular examination findings in this question suggest that the adolescent girl has Bitot's spots, which are a sign of vitamin A deficiency.
  •  Bitot's spots are characterized by small, raised, foamy patches on the conjunctiva, and are graded as 1B by the WHO.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a: A normal optic disc that shows no signs of damage or abnormalities is referred to as WHO grade 1A. The optic disc, which is located where the optic nerve enters and leaves the eye, is in charge of carrying visual data from the eye to the brain. A grade 1A finding denotes the absence of any signs of disease or damage to the optic disc, and the likelihood that the visual function is normal.
  • Option c: Individuals with mild visual impairment are given the WHO grade 2A. In their better eye, people with 2A visual impairment have a visual acuity between 6/18 and 6/24 after correction (such as glasses or contact lenses), according to the WHO. 
  • Option d: The WHO classifies moderate visual impairment as grade 2B. It is indicated by a central visual field diameter of less than 20 degrees in the better eye, or by visual acuity in the better eye ranging from 6/18 to 6/60 (inclusive). As a result, while someone with a 2B visual impairment may be able to see some detail, their visual field is constrained, and they may find it difficult to perform tasks that call for fine visual discrimination or mobility.

questions.text: In the peripheral tissue, which enzyme is accountable for converting T4 to T3?
questions.solution:
• T4 (thyroxine) is the main hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, but it is relatively inactive. T3 (triiodothyronine) is the active form of thyroid hormone that exerts most of the biological effects in the body. The conversion of T4 to T3 occurs primarily in the peripheral tissues, such as the liver, kidney, and skeletal muscle.
  • The enzyme responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3 is iodothyronine deiodinase I (D1). D1 is expressed in various tissues, including the liver, kidney, and thyroid gland. D1 catalyzes the removal of an iodine atom from the outer ring of T4, producing T3.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. Iodothyronine deiodinase III: Iodothyronine deiodinase III (D3) is an enzyme that can inactivate thyroid hormones by removing iodine atoms from the inner ring of T4 and T3. D3 is not involved in the conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Option c. Iodothyronine deiodinase II: Iodothyronine deiodinase II (D2) is another enzyme that can convert T4 to T3, but it is primarily expressed in the thyroid gland and pituitary gland. D2 plays a role in the regulation of thyroid hormone levels in these tissues, but it is not as important for the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Optiond. Iodotyrosine deiodinase: Iodotyrosine deiodinase is not a known enzyme involved in the conversion of T4 to T3, it helps the thyroid iodide salvage by catalyzing the deiodination of mono- and diiodotyrosine, the halogenated waste products of the manufacture of thyroid hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Perls Prussian Blue:

  • Hemosiderin is an iron-containing pigment that is produced by the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  • It is commonly found in macrophages and can accumulate in various tissues in the body under certain conditions, such as hemorrhage, inflammation, and iron overload disorders.
  • Perls Prussian blue stain is a commonly used stain for the detection of hemosiderin.
  • The stain is based on the reaction of potassium ferrocyanide and hydrochloric acid with iron in hemosiderin, which produces a blue color.
  • The staining is often performed on tissue sections from biopsy or autopsy specimens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mason-Fontana stain:

  • This stain is based on the oxidation of melanin by potassium permanganate, which results in the formation of brown or black pigment.
  • The stain is commonly used for the detection of melanin pigment in tissues, such as the skin, hair, and eyes.

Option B - Oil Red O:

  • This stain is a lipophilic dye that is used to detect lipids, such as triglycerides and cholesterol esters.
  • The dye binds to the lipid droplets in tissues, producing a bright red color.
  • The stain is commonly used for the detection of fat in frozen sections of tissue samples.

Option C - Sudan black:

  • This stain is a lipophilic dye that is used to detect lipids in tissues.
  • The stain binds to the lipid droplets in tissues, producing a dark blue-black color.
  • The stain is commonly used for the detection of fat in frozen sections of tissue samples.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not influenced by estrogen?
questions.solution:
• Puberty is a period of development during which the body undergoes significant changes, including the development of secondary sexual characteristics. Estrogen is a hormone that plays a key role in many of these changes, especially in females.
  • Hair growth is not mediated by estrogen during puberty. Androgen hormones, such as testosterone, are responsible for the development of pubic, facial and axillary hair in both males and females.
  • Therefore, option a is the correct choice.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option B) Cervical mucus secretion: Cervical mucus secretion is mediated by estrogen during puberty. Estrogen stimulates the production of cervical mucus, which helps to facilitate the transport of sperm through the female reproductive tract.
  • Option C) Vaginal cornification: Vaginal cornification is mediated by estrogen during puberty. Estrogen stimulates the growth and development of the vaginal epithelium, leading to the thickening and cornification of the cells.
  • OptionD) Menstruation: Menstruation is mediated by estrogen during puberty. Estrogen promotes the thickening of the endometrial lining of the uterus, which is shed during menstruation.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has a prior history of trauma and is currently experiencing symptoms such as double vision, nosebleeds, and limited eye movements, based on the provided CT image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Blow-out fracture:  

  • The CT shows a fracture of the floor of the orbit, with the contents of the orbit herniating down (teardrop sign) and a hematoma in the maxillary sinus; of the given options, the most likely option that fits the description of this injury is a blow-out fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Le-fort fracture: Le-fort I would show a trans maxillary fracture. Le-fort II and III involve fractures of the floor of the orbit, but in addition to this, teeth and the nasal bone are involved in Le-fort II, and an extensive mid-facial discontinuity between the midface and base of the cranium is seen in Le-fort III. 

Option B - Fracture maxilla: A fracture of the maxilla is a break in the top jawbone.

Option C - Fracture zygomatic: This would show a defect/dip in the lateral orbital wall and may or may not involve the floor of the orbit.

questions.text: What is the affinity of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin in comparison to oxygen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 250: 

  • The affinity of carbon monoxide for hemoglobin is approximately 250 times greater than the affinity of oxygen for hemoglobin. This means that when both gases are present, carbon monoxide will bind to hemoglobin preferentially, reducing the amount of oxygen that can bind and be transported to the body's tissues. This can lead to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) and can be life-threatening.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of surgical emphysema in a patient following an emergency tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Tight suture around tracheostomy site (Correct Answer)

  • Tight suturing around the tracheostomy site can obstruct the normal passage of air, causing air to escape into the surrounding subcutaneous tissues. This can lead to the accumulation of air under the skin, resulting in surgical emphysema.
  • The tight suture creates a seal that prevents air from escaping through the tracheostomy tube, forcing it into the surrounding tissues instead.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. High tracheostomy:

  • A high tracheostomy refers to a tracheostomy performed above the second or third tracheal cartilage.
  • While a high tracheostomy can cause complications, such as injury to blood vessels or the thyroid gland, it is not directly associated with surgical emphysema.

Option B: Tear in posterior tracheal wall

  • A tear in the posterior tracheal wall can lead to air escaping into the mediastinum and potentially causing pneumomediastinum rather than subcutaneous emphysema.

Option C. Block in tracheostomy:

  • A block in the tracheostomy tube can lead to respiratory distress and the buildup of secretions. While it requires immediate attention, it is not directly related to surgical emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the options below can be used to elucidate the mechanism by which ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) exerts its effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - cGMP:

  • ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) is a hormone that is produced by the heart and plays a role in regulating blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. ANP acts on the kidneys to increase the excretion of sodium and water, which helps to reduce blood volume and lower blood pressure.
  • The mechanism of action of ANP involves the activation of cGMP (cyclic guanosine monophosphate). ANP binds to its receptor on the surface of target cells, which activates the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. Guanylyl cyclase then converts GTP (guanosine triphosphate) to cGMP, which acts as a second messenger to mediate the effects of ANP.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - cAMP: Hormones acting through this pathway are ACTH, TSH, FSH, LH, catecholamines, somatostatin, glucagon, and secretin.

Option C - IP3-DAG: Hormones acting through this pathway are TRH, GnRH, GHRH, Oxytocin, and ADH (V1 receptor).

Option D - JAK/STAT: Hormones acting through this pathway are growth hormone and prolactin hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a secondary messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - cAMP: 

  • cAMP and calcium act as secondary messengers for the hormones acting on the H+ K+ ATPase in the parietal cell.
  • cAMP and calcium activates protein kinase A, which phosphorylates the H+/K+ ATPase pump, increasing acid secretion into the lumen.
  • Hormones acting through cAMP as a secondary messenger are prostaglandin E2 and histamine.
  • Hormones acting through calcium as a secondary messenger are gastrin and acetylcholine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - cGMP: While cGMP is involved in the regulation of some gastrointestinal functions, such as smooth muscle relaxation.

Option C - CCK-B receptor: The CCK-B receptor is involved in the regulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction.

Option D - Ach: While Ach is involved in the activation of parietal cells, it is not a secondary messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: What is true about oxytocin among the options provided?

choices.text: It can be given by oral route
It is secreted by anterior pituitary
In higher doses, it exerts diuretic like action

questions.solution:
• Oxytocin is a hormone that is produced by the hypothalamus and released by another gland, the posterior pituitary gland. It plays a role in a variety of physiological processes, including labor and lactation, social bonding, and stress response.
  • One of the effects of oxytocin is its ability to stimulate milk ejection (galactokinesis) during lactation. Oxytocin acts on myoepithelial cells in the mammary glands, causing them to contract and expel milk from the alveoli into the ducts.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. It can be given by oral route: This statement is incorrect. Oxytocin is not effective when given by oral route because it is rapidly degraded by enzymes in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Option c. It is secreted by anterior pituitary: This statement is incorrect. Oxytocin is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland, not the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Optiond. Oxytocin is known to have antidiuretic properties. Therefore, in higher dose it will result in extreme water intoxication. Hence, option d is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial point of contact for individuals seeking medical assistance within a community?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Sub-centre:

  • The first and most fundamental component of India's primary healthcare system, a sub-center serves as the community members' first point of contact when seeking medical attention.

Incorrect Options :

  • Option a: PHCs act as a referral link between the Sub-centres and higher-level healthcare facilities, like Community Health Centres (CHCs) and District Hospitals.
  • Option b: PHCs and other lower-level healthcare facilities can be referred to CHCs, which are typically found in semi-urban or rural areas.
  • Option d: A district hospital acts as a referral hub for primary care clinics (PHCs) and community health centers (CHCs), which are among the lower-level healthcare facilities.

questions.text: What hormone is responsible for the breast cramps experienced by a mother while breastfeeding her child?
questions.solution:
• Oxytocin is the hormone responsible for the let-down reflex during breastfeeding. It is released from the posterior pituitary gland in response to nipple stimulation, and it causes the contraction of the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli in the breast. This contraction leads to the ejection of milk from the alveoli into the ducts, where it can be accessed by the infant.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is oxytocin.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option a. Progesterone: Progesterone is involved in the development of the mammary glands during pregnancy, but it is not responsible for the cramps that the mother is experiencing during breastfeeding.
  • Option b. Estrogen: Estrogen is involved in the development of the mammary glands during pregnancy, but it is not responsible for the cramps that the mother is experiencing during breastfeeding.
  • Option c. Prolactin: Prolactin is involved in milk production in the mammary glands, but it is not responsible for the cramps that the mother is experiencing during breastfeeding.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is similar to cervical dilation and delivery occurring during uterine contraction?
questions.solution:
• Cervical dilation and delivery during labor are controlled by the contraction of the uterine muscles. These contractions are stimulated by the hormone oxytocin, which is released by the pituitary gland in response to the stretching of the cervix and uterus. Oxytocin causes the uterine muscles to contract, which in turn leads to cervical dilation and delivery.
  • The mechanism of cervical dilation and delivery on uterine contraction is similar to milk ejection by oxytocin. During lactation, oxytocin is also released in response to suckling by the infant, causing the contraction of the myoepithelial cells in the mammary glands and the ejection of milk.
  • Therefore, the correct choice is option a, milk ejection by oxytocin.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. Water retention by ADH is not related to cervical dilation and delivery during labor. ADH is involved in the regulation of water balance in the body by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys.
  • Option c. FSH secretion by the anterior pituitary is involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and the growth and development of ovarian follicles, but it is not related to cervical dilation and delivery during labor.
  • Optiond. None of the above is an incorrect option as cervical dilation and delivery during labor is similar to milk ejection by oxytocin.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent effects of puberty are not influenced by estrogen?
questions.solution:
• Puberty is a stage of development when sexual maturity is reached, and it is driven by a complex interplay of hormones. Estrogen is one of the major hormones involved in female puberty, and it is responsible for several changes in the body.
  • During puberty, estrogen stimulates the growth of pubic and underarm hair, but it does not directly mediate hair growth on other parts of the body, such as the legs and arms. Therefore, the hair growth during puberty is not mediated by estrogen, which make option a, the correct choice.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option b. Cervical mucus secretion: Cervical mucus secretion, that is the production and release of fluid from the cervix is regulated by estrogen levels, which increase during puberty. Thus, option b is incorrect choice.
  • Option c. Vaginal cornification: Vaginal cornification is regulated by estrogen levels, which increase during puberty.
  • Option d. Menstruation: Menstruation is triggered by estrogen, which stimulates the growth of the endometrium in preparation for pregnancy. Thus, option d, is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a primary healthcare center (PHC)?

choices.text: There is 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas
Type A PHC conducts <20 deliveries per month
Provides maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP

questions.solution:
Correct Option-D: Is the first referral unit

They are the most peripheral and basic units of the healthcare system, and their primary role is to provide primary healthcare services, preventive care, and basic treatment. PHCs are not equipped to handle complex medical conditions or provide specialized care beyond primary healthcare.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. There is 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas - This statement is generally accurate. the ratio of 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas is a common guideline for healthcare infrastructure planning.

Option B. Type A PHC conducts <20 deliveries per month - This statement is generally accurate. PHCs conduct a limited number of deliveries per month.

Option C. Provides maternal and child health care, family planning, and MTP - This statement is accurate. PHCs play a vital role in providing maternal and child health services, family planning, and medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) services, among other primary healthcare services.

questions.text: Which of the following pubertal changes in a 12-year-old girl, specifically breast development and pubic hair scale at stage 4, is not exclusively caused by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B. Pubic and axillary hair growth: The growth of pubic and axillary (underarm) hair is influenced by androgens, particularly testosterone. Androgens play a crucial role in the development of secondary sexual characteristics, including body hair. While estrogen does have some influence on body hair growth, the primary driver for the development of pubic and axillary hair is androgens, particularly testosterone. Estrogen contributes to other pubertal changes, but hair growth is not exclusively caused by estrogen.
 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Vaginal cornification: Vaginal cornification, also known as the appearance of cornified epithelial cells in vaginal smears, is influenced by estrogen. This is one of the effects of estrogen on the genital tract during puberty.

Option C. Cervical mucus production: Estrogen is responsible for cervical mucus production during puberty. Increasing levels of estrogen lead to changes in the cervical mucus that are favorable for sperm penetration and fertility.

Option D. Menstruation: Menstruation, or the onset of the menstrual cycle (menarche), is primarily triggered by increased levels of estrogen and its interactions with other hormones. It is considered a key milestone in female puberty and is indeed influenced by estrogen.

So, the correct answer is Option (B) "Pubic and axillary hair growth."

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in his big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were found to be elevated. After acute treatment, the patient was put on a maintenance regimen with a drug which is considered first-line management for chronic gout; What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Xanthine oxidase inhibitor:

This patient after initial treatment of acute gout flare should be treated with Xanthine oxidase inhibitors which are considered first-line in management of chronic gout, to prevent relapses.

  • Gout is a type of arthritis caused by an accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joints, leading to inflammation and pain. 

  • Xanthine oxidase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of purines, which are converted to uric acid. 

  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors block the activity of this enzyme, resulting in reduced uric acid production and lower levels of uric acid in the blood.

  • Allopurinol and febuxostat are two commonly used xanthine oxidase inhibitors in treating gout.

  • These drugs are considered first-line agents for managing gout in chronic gout, because they effectively reduce serum uric acid levels and prevent gout flares.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pyrimidine antimetabolites: Pyrimidine antimetabolites are drugs that interfere with the synthesis of nucleic acids, specifically pyrimidines, and are used in cancer treatment. They have no role in the treatment of gout.

Option B - Inhibitor of neutrophil recruitment: Inhibitors of neutrophil recruitment are drugs that prevent the migration of white blood cells called neutrophils to the site of inflammation. colchicine works by this mechanism of action, but it is not used in maintenance treatment of gout, instead it is used in acute gout flare.

Option C - Uricosuric drug: Uricosuric drugs are a class of medications that increase the excretion of uric acid by the kidneys, resulting in lower serum uric acid levels. They are used in patients with gout who have under-excretion of uric acid as the cause of their hyperuricemia. However, they are not considered first-line agents in gout treatment and are generally used in combination with xanthine oxidase inhibitors or as an alternative in patients who cannot tolerate xanthine oxidase inhibitors.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent cause of macrocytic anemia among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Option c: Alcohol

  • Macrocytic anemia, also known as megaloblastic anemia, is a type of anemia where the red blood cells (RBCs) are larger than normal. 
  • Alcohol use accounts for the majority, followed by deficiencies in folate and vitamin B12 and medications.
  • Autoimmune causes are more common in middle-aged women. Hypothyroidism and primary bone marrow disease account for more cases of macrocytic anemia in older patients.

Incorrect choices

  • Option A : Vitamin B12 - this is 2nd most common cause.
  • Option b: Bone marrow disorders: Bone marrow disorders like myelodysplastic syndrome can cause macrocytic anemia, but they are less common.
  • Option d: Drug-induced: Certain medications, like chemotherapy and anticonvulsants, can cause macrocytic anemia, but they are not as common.

questions.text: Which among the following is not preferred as an analgesic in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ketorolac:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by joint inflammation and pain. The goal of treatment in rheumatoid arthritis is to reduce pain, inflammation, and joint damage. Analgesics are medications that are used to relieve pain.

  • Ketorolac is also an NSAID, but it is not preferred for use in rheumatoid arthritis due to its potential side effects. It is a potent analgesic that works by blocking the production of prostaglandins. However, it is associated with a higher risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, kidney damage, and other serious adverse effects. Ketorolac is typically used for short-term pain relief in conditions such as postoperative pain, renal colic, and migraines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tramadol: Tramadol is an opioid analgesic commonly used to manage pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It has both opioid and non-opioid mechanisms of action and is considered effective for moderate to severe pain. 

Option C - Naproxen: Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used to manage pain and inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis. It works by blocking the production of prostaglandins, which are responsible for pain and inflammation. However, long-term use of NSAIDs may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, cardiovascular events, and kidney damage.

Option D - Oxycodone: Oxycodone is another opioid analgesic sometimes used to manage pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It is more potent than tramadol and may be used for severe pain. However, tramadol may cause side effects such as nausea, dizziness, and constipation.

questions.text: In a community, an awareness session on handwashing was organized. The appropriate order of events in this session is:
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The proper procedure for a community handwashing awareness program is:Awareness > Interest > Evaluation >Adoption

Incorrect choices

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: A tourist with a travel history to India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute watery diarrhea after eating at a restaurant in India → most likely traveler’s diarrhea, commonly caused by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC).

  • Rifaximin is a non-absorbable antibiotic effective for traveler’s diarrhea due to noninvasive E. coli. It is the recommended treatment.

Octreotide (Option A): It is used for secretory diarrhea (e.g., carcinoid syndrome, VIPoma), not traveler’s diarrhea.

Loperamide (Option B): It can reduce stool frequency but is not preferred alone in infectious diarrhea; risk of worsening disease if invasive pathogen is present.

Bismuth subsalicylate (Option D): can be used for prevention and mild symptoms, but not the main treatment once diarrhea is established.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is unemployed because he is unable to walk after an accident. His unemployment is classified as a:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Handicap:

  • Man's inability to walk after an accident has left him unable to work.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Disability:

  • Doesn't address his inability to work.

Option C - Disease/disorder:

  • Focuses on illness rather than work limitation.

Option D - Impairment:

  • Doesn't specify work limitation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not treated with high-ceiling diuretics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pulmonary hypertension:

  • High-ceiling diuretics, also known as loop diuretics, are medications commonly used to treat conditions characterized by fluid overload. Loop diuretics act on the ascending limb of loop of Henle, a section of the kidney tubule, to inhibit sodium and chloride reabsorption by the Na+-K+-2Cl-, leading to increased urinary output and fluid loss. They are considered the most potent diuretics available and are effective in rapidly reducing fluid volume in the body.

  • Pulmonary hypertension, on the other hand, is a condition characterized by increased pulmonary vascular resistance in the lungs blood vessels, which can lead to symptoms such as shortness of breath and chest pain. PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil or tadalafil are used for Pulmonary hypertension treatment. While loop diuretics may be used as adjunctive therapy in treating pulmonary hypertension, they are not typically used as the primary treatment for this condition.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A -  Generalized edema: Generalized edema refers to fluid accumulation in the tissues throughout the body, typically due to conditions such as heart failure, liver disease, or kidney disease. Loop diuretics are commonly used in the treatment of generalized edema.

Option B - Cerebral edema: Cerebral edema is characterized by fluid accumulation in the brain, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and neurological symptoms. Loop diuretics and osmotic diuretics are often used in conjunction with other treatments, such as corticosteroids or osmotic agents, to manage cerebral edema.

Option C - Acute pulmonary edema: Acute pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, typically due to heart failure. Loop diuretics are commonly used in the treatment of acute pulmonary edema to reduce fluid accumulation and improve respiratory function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the treatment of a farmer presenting with symptoms of diarrhea, sweating, excessive tearing, and salivation in the emergency department is not accurate?

choices.text: Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning
Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning
Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning:

  • This statement is incorrect. Pralidoxime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning, but it does not reverse the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase by carbamates. Pralidoxime is used for nicotinic effects of organophosphates.
  • The scenario described in the question is consistent with organophosphate or carbamate poisoning. The symptoms are caused by the buildup of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, in the body.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Carbamates bind to acetylcholinesterase irreversibly: This statement is true. Carbamates and organophosphates inhibit acetylcholinesterase, which leads to an accumulation of acetylcholine at nerve synapses and neuromuscular junctions. Carbamates bind to the enzyme irreversibly, whereas organophosphates bind reversibly.

Option B - Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning: This statement is true. Atropine is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning. It blocks the effects of excessive acetylcholine in the body but does not reverse the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase.

Option D - Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation: As Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent that can cause a rapid rise in potassium levels, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest. Its use is generally avoided in patients with known or suspected hyperkalemia, severe burns, or skeletal muscle injury.

questions.text: What is the most common side effect of Lamotrigine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rash:

  • Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug that is also used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It works by stabilizing the activity of nerve cells in the brain that are involved in seizures and mood disorders.

  • The most common side effect of lamotrigine, an antiepileptic and mood-stabilizing medication, is a rash. In clinical trials, approximately 10% of people taking lamotrigine experienced a rash, especially during the initial weeks of treatment. The rash can range from mild to severe, and in rare cases, it can be a sign of a serious allergic reaction such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis, which requires immediate medical attention. Other less common side effects of lamotrigine may include dizziness, headache, double vision, nausea, vomiting, and somnolence (sleepiness).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diplopia: Diplopia or double vision is an uncommon side effect of lamotrigine. It occurs in less than 1% of patients and usually resolves independently or with reduced drug dosage.

Option B - Tremors: Tremors are a rare side effect of lamotrigine. They occur in less than 1% of patients and may be related to the drug dosage. Tremors usually resolve with a reduction in the dose or discontinuation of the drug.

Option C - Neutropenia: Neutropenia, which is a low level of white blood cells called neutrophils, is a rare but potentially serious side effect of lamotrigine. It occurs in less than 1% of patients and can increase the risk of infection. Blood cell counts should be monitored in patients taking lamotrigine, especially during the first few months of treatment.

questions.text: In how many days should the post exposure Measles vaccine be given?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Option B - Within 3 days:

  • Incubation period for measles is 10-14 days.
  • 10th day- fever stars
  • 14th day -rashes start
  • IP of vaccine-induced measles is 7 days.
  • Post-exposure vaccine must be used with in 3 days of exposure

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Digoxin:

  • Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is a common condition in which the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. Several drugs have been shown to improve symptoms and reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF.

  • Digoxin is a medication used for many years to treat heart failure. While it can improve symptoms such as shortness of breath and fatigue, it has not been shown to reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF. However, digoxin may still have a role in managing symptoms in certain patients with HFrEF.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Beta-blockers: Beta-blockers such as metoprolol, carvedilol, and bisoprolol are among the most effective medications for treating HFrEF. They work by reducing the workload on the heart and improving its pumping ability. Beta-blockers have been shown to reduce mortality by about 30% in patients with HFrEF.

Option C - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril, enalapril, and ramipril are another class of effective drugs in treating HFrEF. They work by dilating blood vessels and reducing the workload on the heart. ACE inhibitors have been shown to reduce mortality by about 20-25% in patients with HFrEF.

Option D - Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate: Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate, sometimes used in patients with HFrEF who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). Hydralazine is a vasodilator that relaxes blood vessels, while isosorbide dinitrate is a nitrate that also dilates blood vessels. This combination has reduced mortality by about 25% in African-American patients with HFrEF.

questions.text: Which among the following is a short-acting beta blocker?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Esmolol:

  • Esmolol is a short-acting beta blocker used in hospitals to control rapid heart rates or high blood pressure during surgery or other procedures. It has a half-life of only about 9 minutes, meaning its effects wear off quickly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nadolol: Nadolol is a long-acting beta blocker taken once a day. It has a half-life of about 20-24 hours, meaning it stays in the body long. Nadolol treats high blood pressure, angina, and heart failure.

Option B - Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker used to treat high blood pressure, angina, migraines, and other conditions. It has a half-life of about 4-6 hours, which means it is a relatively short-acting agent.

Option D - Atenolol: Atenolol is a selective beta-blocker for treating high blood pressure, angina, and other conditions. It has a half-life of about 6-7 hours, which means it is a relatively short-acting agent.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia and hepatosplenomegaly. On investigation, Hb-11 g/dL, platelet count-95,000 platelets/mm3, and WBC count-45000 cells/mm3. A bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity, with many blast cells that are peroxidase-negative and non-specific esterase-positive. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5):

  • The patient's presentation with bleeding gums, gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone marrow biopsy findings, which indicate 100% cellularity with many blast cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive, is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5).
  • Acute myeloid leukemia M5 (AML M5) is also known as acute monocytic leukemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M2 (AML M2): It is characterized by the presence of abnormal promyelocytes in the bone marrow and blood.

Option B - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M0 (AML M0): It is characterized by the absence of surface markers on the blast cells.

Option D - Acute Myeloid Leukemia M7 (AML M7): It is characterized by the presence of abnormal megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, which can lead to thrombocytopenia and bleeding.

questions.text: At what age is the first dose of hepatitis B vaccine given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - At Birth:

  • First dose of hepatitis B vaccine: Administered within 24 hours of birth
  • Provides timely protection against transmission from mother to baby
  • Subsequent doses: At 1-2 months and 6 months of age to complete the series
  • Recommended as routine childhood vaccination by WHO and CDC

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 6 weeks: Safe to administer at 6 weeks but recommended to complete series as soon as possible

Option C - 10 weeks: 10 weeks would be too long a delay

Option D - 6 months: Vaccine is safe and effective after 6 months, but recommended to administer as early as possible, ideally within 24 hours of birth

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern observed in neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Neural tube defects (NTDs) are a group of congenital malformations that affect brain and spinal cord development. Examples of NTDs include spina bifida, anencephaly, and encephalocele.

The pattern of Inheritance in NTDs is complex and can involve multiple genetic and environmental factors. While no single gene has been identified as causing NTDs, there is evidence to suggest that multiple genes may be involved.
In addition to genetic factors, environmental factors such as maternal folic acid deficiency, certain medications, and exposure to toxins can also increase the risk of NTDs.

Therefore, the inheritance pattern in NTDs is considered to be multifactorial, meaning that genetic and environmental factors contribute to the development of the condition.

 

Incorrect Choices:

a. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance occurs when a single copy of a mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs

b. X-linked dominant: X-linked dominant inheritance occurs when a mutated gene on the X chromosome is responsible for the disease. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs

c. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance occurs when an individual inherits two copies of a mutated gene, one from each parent. This is not the pattern of inheritance in NTDs.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR):

  • Measures maternal deaths during antenatal, delivery, or within six weeks postnatal, excluding accidental causes.
  • Formula: MMR = (Total maternal deaths / Live Births) × 100,000.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maternal mortality rate: Calculated per women in reproductive age group (15-49 years), not per live births.

Option C - Infant Mortality Rate: Measures infant deaths under one year per 1,000 live births, indicating overall child health and healthcare system effectiveness.

Option D - Perinatal Mortality Rate: Combines stillbirths and early neonatal deaths per 1,000 total births, indicating infant health during perinatal period.

questions.text: The X-ray of a middle-aged man showed multiple lytic lesions, following which a urine examination was done. The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgG:

  • The patient's presentation with multiple lytic lesions on X-ray and Bence-Jones proteins in urine examination is suggestive of multiple myeloma.
  • In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells accumulate in the bone marrow and produce excessive amounts of a single type of antibody, or immunoglobulin.
  • Bence Jones proteins are fragments of immunoglobulin light chains that are filtered by the kidneys and excreted in the urine.
  • The most common immunoglobulin associated with multiple myeloma is IgG, which accounts for about 50% of cases.
  • IgA is the second most common type, accounting for about 20-25% of cases.
  • IgM is rare in multiple myeloma, and IgD is not typically associated with this condition.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old girl who presents with cramping abdominal pain, rashes on the back of her legs, buttocks, and extensor surface of her forearms, along with proteinuria and microscopic hematuria upon laboratory analysis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of cramping abdominal pain, rashes on the back of legs, buttocks, and the extensor surface of the forearms, along with laboratory findings of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria, suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) as the most likely diagnosis.

HSP is a systemic vasculitis affecting small vessels, primarily in children. The classic presentation includes palpable purpura on the lower extremities, abdominal pain, arthritis or arthralgia, and renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria, and occasionally, nephrotic syndrome). The diagnosis of HSP is made based on clinical features and laboratory findings, and a renal biopsy is rarely necessary.

Incorrect Choices:

a. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) typically presents with more symptoms, including fatigue, joint pain, and skin rashes, and is less common in children. Laboratory findings in SLE include positive antinuclear antibodies and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies, which are not seen in HSP.

c. post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) typically presents with edema, hypertension, and oliguria following an upper respiratory or skin infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. Hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts are commonly seen on urinalysis. HSP is not typically associated with preceding infections and does not have hypertension or oliguria.

d. Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) typically presents with the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. While HSP can cause renal involvement, it typically presents with isolated proteinuria and microscopic hematuria without the other features of HUS.

questions.text: A labourer’s younger child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has mostly fed rice water in his diet. On investigations, the child was found to have low serum protein, low serum protein, and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Kwashiorkor:

  • The patient's presentation with a swollen abdomen and a tired-looking face with low levels of serum protein and albumin on investigation and a history of consumption of rice water as a major part of the diet are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.
  • Kwashiorkor is a type of protein-energy malnutrition that can occur in children with inadequate protein intake.
  • The disease is characterized by a swollen belly, a dull face, and edema in the limbs.
  • Low serum protein and albumin levels can lead to edema in Kwashiorkor.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Marasmus: Marasmus is a type of protein-energy malnutrition characterized by severe calorie deficiency, which leads to muscle wasting and weight loss.

Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis:

  • Indian childhood cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease of childhood characterised by cirrhosis of the liver associated with the deposition of copper in the liver.
  • It primarily affects children of 1–3 years of age and has a genetic predisposition.

Option D: Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness that affects young children and causes inflammation in blood vessels.

questions.text: What is the best way to use a graphical representation to illustrate patterns and changes in the occurrence of diarrheal disease within a specific region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Line graph

  • A line graph is the best way to plot trends in the incidence of diarrheal disease in a given area. 

A line graph effectively displays trends in diarrheal disease incidence over time. It utilizes an X-axis for time (e.g., years) and a Y-axis for incidence rate (e.g., cases per 100,000). By connecting data points with lines, it provides a clear visualization of changing trends and patterns in disease incidence

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Histogram

  • Histograms are useful for analyzing large datasets and identifying patterns or trends.

Option C: Ogive

  • An ogive, or cumulative frequency curve visually illustrates how cumulative frequency increases with rising variable values..

Option D: Tree diagram

  • A tree diagram visually represents potential outcomes of a choice or process.

questions.text: A patient came to the causality with acute bronchial asthma after treatment for glaucoma. Which of the following is a most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Timolol:

  • The patient's history of glaucoma treatment suggests the possibility of medication-induced bronchial asthma. Certain drugs used to treat glaucoma can cause bronchospasm in susceptible individuals. 

  • Timolol is a non- selective beta blocker commonly used to treat glaucoma by reducing intraocular pressure. However, it can also cause bronchospasm in patients with a history of asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This is because beta blockers can block the beta-2 receptors in the lungs, which can lead to constriction of the airways.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Betaxolol: Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used to treat glaucoma. It is less likely to cause bronchospasm than non-selective beta blockers like timolol.

Option C - Latanoprost: Latanoprost  is a prostaglandin analog used to treat glaucoma by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor from the eye. It does not directly affect the airways and is unlikely to cause bronchospasm.

Option D - Bimatoprost: Bimatoprost  is another prostaglandin analog used to treat glaucoma. Like latanoprost, it is unlikely to cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth chart shows a BMI between the 85th and 95th percentile. Which of the following categories would you place him in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Overweight:

  • In children, BMI is calculated using age, sex, height, and weight, and the result is plotted on a growth chart to determine the child’s BMI percentile.
  • BMI percentiles in children are classified as follows:
    • Underweight: Less than 5th percentile
    • Healthy weight: 5th percentile to less than 85th percentile
    • Overweight: 85th percentile to less than 95th percentile
    • Obese: Equal to or greater than 95th percentile
  • In this case, the child’s BMI falls between 85th and 95th percentile, which places him in the overweight category. This means that the child’s weight is higher than what is considered healthy for his age, sex, and height.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D: The BMI in the given clinical scenario does not fit into any of these categories.

questions.text: A child visited the hospital with her mother with complaints of severe fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and irritation. She has a known case of iron deficiency anemia and is on oral iron supplements. On reviewing the child, the physician in charge plans to start IV iron supplementation. What is the next best test to be done in assessing this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serum ferritin:

  • Serum ferritin is considered the most sensitive and specific test for the diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia.
  • It reflects the amount of iron stored in the body and is considered an indirect measure of iron stores.
  • A low serum ferritin level is the earliest indicator of iron deficiency anemia, and it can be used to monitor the effectiveness of iron therapy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not specific to iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: What is the primary factor responsible for the demographic burden?
questions.solution:
Correct Options D - Increased old age dependency ratio

  • Increased dependency ratio of the elderly: Proportion of elderly (65 and above) compared to working-age population (15-64).
  • Primary contributor to demographic burden: Places pressure on working-age population to support elderly's needs (healthcare, social security).
  • Economic and social ramifications: Can lead to strain on resources, affecting economic growth and social welfare.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased old-age dependency ratio: It is associated with economic growth, as working-age population is relatively high compared to elderly.

Option B - Increased young-age dependency ratio: High proportion of young dependents (under 15) compared to working-age population (15-64).

Option C - Decreased young-age dependency ratio: Fewer young dependents compared to working-age population, reducing dependency burden and contributing positively to economy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not routinely screened before conducting a blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hepatitis A:

  • Hepatitis A is not routinely screened before conducting a blood transfusion. This is because Hepatitis A is typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route and not through blood transfusions. It is an acute, self-limiting disease, and does not cause chronic infection.

  • Screening for infectious diseases such as Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV, malaria, and syphilis is mandatory before a blood transfusion. These infections can be transmitted through blood and blood products, and therefore, blood donors are routinely tested for these pathogens

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A mother expresses concern about her child's unwillingness to eat properly. Her 15-month-old son's length falls 2 standard deviations below the median for his age. What is the most probable medical condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Moderate stunting:

  • Stunting is defined as a length-for-age more than two standard deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. This indicates that the child has not grown adequately in height and is considered short for age. In this case, the child’s length-for-age is ≤ -2 SD below the median, which indicates moderate stunting.
  • The reluctance to take feeds appropriately may be one reason for the child’s stunted growth. Poor nutrition, frequent infections, and inadequate stimulation can also contribute to stunting.
  • Stunting is associated with impaired cognitive development, poor school performance, and reduced economic productivity in adulthood

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute malnutrition: Acute malnutrition refers to a recent and severe deficiency of energy, protein, and other nutrients that can lead to wasting and/or edema. The child in this scenario is not showing signs of acute malnutrition.

Option B - Severe wasting: Severe wasting is defined as a weight-for-height greater than three standard deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. The child’s weight is not provided in the scenario.

Option C - Moderately underweight: Moderately underweight is defined as a weight-for-age greater than two standard deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. The child’s weight is not provided in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following demographic indicators is used to compare the life expectancy of two different countries?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HDI:

  • Used to compare life expectancy between nations.
